label: PGY1 Ready

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
History Taking:  Vincent's history taking skills became much more efficient as the rotation progressed. He demonstrated an ability to listen to the patient and search the EHR for relevant data. Patients felt that he was attentive to them and was thorough in the information he gathered.
Physical Exam:  Vincent performed very thorough physical exams.  He routinely asked to confirm exams with his preceptors when he found abnormalities.
Fund of Knowledge:  Vincent had a strong fund of knowledge, at the level of most 4th year students. He was a very motivated learner who would research what he didn't know and then come back to the preceptor after reading to educate the preceptor as well.
Clinical Reasoning:  Vincent was able to handle patients with multiple serious medical and psycho-social conditions efficiently and generate a thorough differential. His plans were appropriate.
Clinical Presentation:  Vincent's presentations were efficient and concise.  It was easy to understand his thought process.
Patient Management:  Vincent was able to manage very complex patients, and also followed up on their issues after the visit.
Patient Communication and Counseling:  Vincent developed very good rapport with patients and I could often could hear them laughing with him. Like most of us, he still needs to work on using non-clinical language with patients.
Professionalism:  Teamwork and Communication:  Vincent was very diligent, and extremely professional. He had good rapport with office staff as well as physicians.
Lifelong Learning Skills:  Vincent was always motivated to do and read more, and circled back to attendings to fill them in on what he'd learned.
Summary:  Vincent was a pleasure to work with. He is a mature, motivated, diligent and well organized student with strong communication skills.  He was able to manage very complex patients.

Clerkship Didactic Review:
Review of Med U Formulations Statements: Vincent's formulation statements were missing pertinent information from the history and/or physical.  
Social Determinants of Health Interview:  Vincent interviewed a disabled wheelchair bound patient who lived in an extremely poor rural community without transportation or running water and was very isolated. Vincent interviewed this patient during a home visit, and was struck by this patient's very challenging living conditions, and how significantly they contributed to his inability to care for his many chronic conditions. Vincent's essay demonstrated a real understanding of the importance of social determinants on the health of the patients he cared for, as well as the value of home visits in truly understanding the lives of patients and the challenge of delivering medical care in underserved communities..

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Dudley is a very conscientious hard working student. He loves what he does and cares about his patients and learning. Dudley is very compassionate. He loves to do the best for his patients at all times. He will be an outstanding physician,and will have a great professional future.

Clerkship didactic review

Social Determinants of Health
Dudley submitted an excellent social determinants of health write-up. He interviewed a recent immigrant and thoughtfully contrasted his quality of life and experience with health care in 3 countries.

Med U case summary statements
Dudley made steady progress on his med U summary statements. It was clear that he was paying attention and after a few practices, Dudley was able to identify nearly all of the  key concepts in cases.  Dudley's summary statements did get more concise as the block went on. He can continue to work on this by trimming down contents and using semantic qualifiers.   The goal of the summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a very compact and predictably structure. This cognitive exercise will allow you, as well as others listening on rounds, to be triggered by these key words and more easily generate as well as narrow down potential differentials and next steps in patient care.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: This is a real strength for Dudley. His thought process is well organized and he demonstrates outstanding oral presentation skills. He is confident in his communication at the bedside.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
In summary, Luna performed very well, at or above the level expected of her current training. She was a pleasure to have in our office and we all expect that her skills will continue to grow with experience 
  

Clerkship didactic assignment feedback:

Luna was proactive and attentive to her didactic and administrative tasks in this block.
 
Med U summary statements-  Luna summary statements were well written, informative, and communicated her ability to recognize and highlight most of the key findings in cases.  In some cases Luna can further highlight relevant social social context that may guide medical decision making.


Social Determinants of Health writeup - In her thoughtful write-up Luna reflected on an interplay of social determinants of health (unsafe housing, disjointed medical care) and her patient's medical condition -anxiety disorder.   Luna suggested ways for health care providers and systems to better serve patients who struggle with self care and engagement with medical services.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
(The above evaluation represents the input of all the clinical faculty working with the students at our site.)
Seamus is a diligent and engaged learner in the ambulatory setting who is appropriately developing his clinical skills, knowledge base, and bedside confidence during this first clinical rotation.  He demonstrates outstanding professionalism and team spirit, it was a pleasure working with him. 



Clerkship didactic assignment feedback-

Seamus was proactive and attentive to his didactic and administrative tasks in this block. 

Med U summary statements- Seamus did a good job writing his med U summary statements and got better at identifying and communicating key clinical findings in cases. He can continue to work on becoming more concise by weeding out redundant content and highlighting key facts (including psychosocial context) that will guide his readers/listeners to generate differentials and conceptualize care plans. 

Social Determinants of Health assignment-Seamus submitted a thoughtful write up detailing the challenges encountered by a patient he interviewed. Seamus identified numerous barriers caused by both medical and social conditions, and provided comprehensive recommendations to deliver better and more patient centered care.

label: Advanced MCY Learner

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Oliver displayed growth in his management plans for his patients throughout the rotation. He clearly applied information learned from patient care and didactic sessions earlier in the rotation, for example in diabetes, to patients seen later in the rotation. As he expands his medical knowledge base he will continue to develop skills in managing patients, particularly those with complex medical problems. Oliver also showed growth in his understanding of psychosocial and socioeconomic considerations in our patient population.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Oliver's key strength during this rotation was his natural, excellent ability to establish rapport with patients and maintain open, caring, non-judgemental communication that promotes patient engagement and autonomy. He has an empathic listening style and inherent sensitivity to patient concerns, particularly in sensitive areas such as psychosocial concerns. He was able to make patients comfortable by conversing with them in fluent Spanish. He used reflective listening effectively and encouraged patients to express their concerns and preferences; motivational interviewing skills seem natural to him and I encouraged him to continue building sophistication in this area.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Oliver gave very detailed presentations with relevant clinical information. He can continue to work on making his presentations more organized and including all the pertinent information in each topic. This is particularly the case for patients with multiple complex problems, which is commonly seen with the aging population seen in the ambulatory setting.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Oliver was a delightful, engaged, diligent and hard-working addition to our team. He was eager to see more patients, expand his medical knowledge, contribute to the team and follow up with patients. We felt his absence after the rotation because of the contribution he made to helping us see patients and improving our workflow.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
It was a pleasure to have Oliver in our clinic, with his positive attitude, enthusiasm for engaging patients and natural curiosity.  Oliver has exceptional interpersonal skills and clinical confidence, and did really well in patient communication and teamwork. One memorable case to highlight is a middle age woman who had a complex cognitive and psychiatric presentation; Oliver skillfully interviewed her in Spanish, carefully clarifying all the history and her concerns as well as her husband's, which enabled us to develop an understanding of her condition that would not have been possible without such a thorough and considerate history. 

Clerkship Didactic Review

MCYF social determinants writeup
For his SDH assignment, Oliver thoughtfully reflected on the illness experience of an undocumented patient whose illness was negatively impacted by finacial barriers and poor literacy. Oliver proposed practical ways for the ideal care system to better serve pts like her.

Med U case summary
Oliver made progress with the med U summary statement writing. As the rotation went on, Oliver demonstrated the ability to hone in on all the key elements in the cases.   To get even better,  work on being more concise with formulations. Just identify 3 things= epi, timing, key findings.    The goal of the summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a VERY compact and predictably structure. This cognitive exercise will allow you, as well as others listening to you on rounds, to be triggered by these key words and quickly generate as well as narrow down potential differentials and plans.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
History Taking:  Cho collected appropriate information and was able to provide excellent histories on her patients.  
Physical Exam:  Cho's physical exam skills were excellent.  She was thorough and detailed, noting abnormalities most others would have missed. 
Fund of Knowledge:  Cho demonstrated an exceptional fund of knowledge and applied it very well.
Clinical Reasoning:  Cho was able to develop a broad differential diagnosis. 
Clinical Presentation:  Cho's notes were excellent and thorough.  In the ED setting, her write-ups were a little long for an ER note but they were well-written and right on track.  She presented patients in a clear manner.  She should continue to practice her oral presentations of patients in a step-by-step organized way similar to her notes.
Patient Management:  Cho did a very good job summarizing and developing a plan for treatment.  She shared thoughtful insights that were helpful in the management of patients.
Patient Communication and Counseling:  Cho develops good rapport with patients.  She has a transparency in speaking with patients and discussing work-up and treatment that patients respond to enthusiastically.  She works hard to achieve mutual understanding with patients regarding their medical plan.
Professionalism:  Teamwork and Communication:  Cho is very energetic and willing to help do anything (even more menial tasks) to help with clinic flow. She had great communication skills, both with patients and with staff.  She demonstrated a willingness to see all patients and stay late if needed to finish up with a patient.  Overall, she was a pleasure to work with and got along very well with the entire staff. 
Lifelong Learning Skills:  A particular strength of Cho's is her curiosity. She wondered about how the disease presented itself, which got her wondering what having the disease meant to the patient, how the patient could cope with it on a day-to-day basis and then how she could help the patient to own the disease and personally manage it.  She was always very motivated to see patients and expand her knowledge base.
Summary:  Cho has kindled her first clinical exposure at this somewhat alien and confounding setting with grace and vivid enthusiasm.  She was well-liked by our patients and helped provide excellent care for them. Her heart and her head are in a good place. She is non-judgmental she can get along with people in a genuine sense, and that will carry her far in her career.  Our staff really appreciated her energy. It's easy to let time pass without really engaging yourself and Cho kept up a good spirit and work ethic the whole time.  In her research project, she took an active interest in pursuing projects helping WRSU understand the role of lead poisoning in our pediatric population. Great initiative!  

Clerkship Director Assignment Review
Med U Summary Cases:  Cho was concise and able to identify most of the key concepts in the cases. Two recommendations to improve further: 
1.	Be sure to always communicate all three elements of Epidemiology/risk factors, chronicity of symptoms, and key history and physical findings. 
2.	Stay with a consistent format that places history ahead of exam findings. This will allow others to more easily follow you.   
The goal of the summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a very compact and predictable structure. This cognitive exercise will allow you, as well as others listening on rounds, to be prompted by these key words and quickly generate and narrow down potential differentials and plans.
Social Determinants of Health Interview: Cho demonstrated an excellent understanding of social determinants of health in her interview with an Apache patient with end stage liver disease.  She discussed the environmental, social and financial factors affecting his health, and thoughtfully reflected on the "historical trauma" which impact the health of many on the reservation and in other marginalized communities.  Her review of the NYC data added to her understanding of how health care disparities impact the health of a variety of other populations.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: see below

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
History Taking:  Hermione obtained thorough, comprehensive histories and was able to address patient complaints and concerns. She was working on prioritizing which patient issues/concerns were most important for the visit.
Physical Exam: Hermione had good physical exam skills and obtained physical exams that were appropriate for the chief complaint.
Fund of Knowledge:  Hermione was curious, engaged, asked good questions that had a clear basis in a robust fund of knowledge, and would come prepared, having read up about her patients in advance.
Clinical Reasoning:  Hermione took appropriate time to formulate her assessments and plans. Her assessments were generally spot on, with a good consideration of the available data gathered.
Clinical Presentation:  Hermione's presentations were always well organized, comprehensive and yet concise.
Patient Management:  Hermione was working on developing appropriate, comprehensive management plans for her patients.
Patient Communication and Counseling:  Hermione would speak in patient friendly language to her patients.
Professionalism:  Teamwork and Communication:  Hermione was a great team player with an excellent work ethic.
Lifelong Learning Skills:  Hermione was constantly reading up about patients and new medical problems she had seen and would come prepared to clinic to discuss these issues.
Summary:  Multiple attendings noted Hermione was engaged, intellectually curious, and hard working. She exhibited a great work ethic and would clearly come prepared to clinic, having read up about the patients she would see. She asked good questions and had a robust fund of knowledge. Her histories were thorough and extremely comprehensive, and she had good physical exam skills. She generally formulated an expansive differential diagnosis and she was working on developing her management plans. Her presentations were well organized. Hermione was receptive to feedback. Her end-of-rotation presentation/chart review reviewed statin and ACE inhibitor use among women of childbearing age and reviewed the literature about risks of these medications during pregnancy. The presentation was well-researched and extremely well presented; several attendings commented it was the best student presentation of the year.

Clerkship Director Assignment Review
Med U Summary Cases: Hermione's Med U summary statements were very concisely written. Her organization developed quickly and she was able to identify most of the key concepts in these cases.   To further improve, Hermione should continue to take stock of all key clinical elements, and to be sure to include psychosocial contributors in the cases.   The goal of the summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a very compact and predictable structure. This cognitive exercise will allow you, as well as others listening to you on rounds, to be prompted by these key words to quickly generate and narrow down potential differentials and plans on rounds.   
Social Determinants of Health Interview: Hermione demonstrated a very good understanding of social determinants of health, specifically how an unstable family situation may have interfered with a child's language development and reflected on the social barriers in evaluating the child.  Hermione noted that adverse childhood events and other social determinants of health are similar in such diverse environments as the Z P and Washington Heights.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
History Taking:  Gregory consistently was able to gather substantial medical histories and social histories from complex patients with multiple medical problems and psychiatric comorbidities. He was able to keep patients at ease and appropriately gather information a timely manner.
Physical Exam:  Gregory demonstrated excellent cardiac examination skills, frequently hearing murmurs and detecting arrhythmias when appropriate.
Fund of Knowledge:  Gregory frequently was able to generate broad differential diagnoses based upon his clinical knowledge.
Clinical Reasoning:  Gregory was able to use his physical examination skills and a broad differential diagnosis to generate appropriate plans of care or to recommend further lab tests and radiographic studies. He was able to adjust to the workup of patient's in a rural health care practice and became aware of the community resources available and necessary for patients with complex medical problems.
Clinical Presentation:  Gregory was able to efficiently and consistently present patients. 
Patient Management:  Gregory was able to generate appropriate assessments and plans that included medical management, lab and radiology studies as well as referral to subspecialty consultations.  Gregory was able to demonstrate management skills that took into account the patient's stage of life, other medical comorbidities, and psycho-social implications.
Patient Communication and Counseling:  Patients frequently commented on Gregory's ability to obtain a history and perform a physical exam in a confident and appropriate way. He effectively used motivational interviewing skills in discussing weight loss, oral tobacco use, and tobacco cessation.
Professionalism:  Teamwork and Communication:  Gregory arrived early daily. He had excellent interactions with nursing staff. 
Lifelong Learning Skills:  Gregory frequently demonstrated his independent learning by giving feedback on cases previously discussed.
Summary:  Gregory showed commitment and was very eager to learn throughout his rural primary care rotation. He demonstrated strong professionalism, knowledge, and had substantial improvement in his oral presentations of patients. His documentation in the medical record was strong. His histories, physical examinations, assessments, and plans were thorough. He generated broad differential diagnoses and was very knowledgeable about  tests, radiographs and medications. By the end of his rotation, he was able to demonstrate management of a large majority of issues in primary care.

Clerkship Director Review of Assignments
Med U Formulation Statements: Gregory was well organized in the structure of his summary statements and made progress recognizing chronology and key concepts.  It was clear he paid close attention to the cases and was able to identify most of the important facts.  He can further edit some of the formulations to be more concise and therefore more effectively communicate key information in fast-paced setting such as rounds.  
Social Determinants of Health Interview: Gregory demonstrated a very good understanding of how social determinants impacted the health of a patient who is an immigrant from Italy with severe social stressors and lack of support.  Gregory discussed possible solutions to the challenges the patient faced obtaining mental health services for himself and  managing his daughter's obesity. Gregory's review of the NYC data added to his understanding of other factors that impact the health of uninsured patients.

She was highly motivated and proactive in seeing patients independently and following up with them after visits, which is a key role for students on our rotation. Clerkship Didactic Review

Case Summary Statements
Pansy did a really nice job on her Med U statements. It was clear that she paid close attention to the cases and was able to identify most of the key facts in the cases. She made some progress in editing down the included content so the summary statements can be more concise and easier to comprehend for others on rounds and in clinical notes. 


Social Determinants of Health
Pansy demonstrated a sophisticated understanding of SDH, as she reflected on the illness experience of a 58 year old man with chronic pain. Through his story telling, she highlighted numerous barriers to his care, and recommended ways for an ideal health care system to attend to the needs of vulnerable patients.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
History Taking:  From the start of his primary care rotation, Viktor took the initiative to see patients independently.   He was efficient in his history taking. Attending physicians felt they could rely on Viktor's history for medical decision-making.
Physical Exam:  Viktor's physical exams were efficient and appropriate. He could perform a practiced cardiovascular exam and did so on the majority of patients. He was able to recognize the need for more specific exams, including musculoskeletal and neurological exams. He was able to perform exams independently. 
Fund of Knowledge:  Viktor has the medical knowledge necessary to evaluate complicated patients in the outpatient setting. He is able to synthesize guidelines with his knowledge of pathophysiology to make reasoned clinical decisions when guidelines are not available, as he demonstrated in his presentation on non-cigarette tobacco use.
Clinical Reasoning:  Viktor was noted to generate broad differential diagnoses, which were well supported and thought-out for all of his diagnoses. He was able to see complex patients with multiple, disparate complaints, and synthesize their symptoms and exam findings into a workable differential.
Clinical Presentation:  From the get-go, Viktor's patient presentations were organized, efficient, and accurate. His presentations included all relevant information without burdening the listener with an excess of data. When interrupted for clarification during presentations, he invariably both had the answer and was able to return to the presentation at the point without losing his flow.
Patient Management:  Viktor incorporated patients' perspectives and psychosocial background into plans. He has learned to incorporate preventive care into his plans consistently.
Patient Communication and Counseling:  Viktor has great communication skills and really made his patients feel at home. He is good at active listening and helping his patients feel, and be, heard. Multiple patients mentioned that they would like to continue care with Viktor as their primary doctor. His motivational interviewing, as observed, was empathetic and nonjudgmental.
Professionalism -- Teamwork and Communication:  Viktor was hard working, proactive, and professional in his time at Farrell clinic. He solved problems independently. He was reliably on time and well prepared for clinical sessions.
Lifelong Learning Skills:  Viktor was eager to learn; he took part in clinical discussions, pre-read on his patients, and accepted feedback well.
Summary:  Viktor was a pleasure to have at Farrell for his primary care rotation. He showed himself to be hardworking and advanced in his medical care, and above all to be a good listener to patients as well as to teachers.

Clerkship Director Review of Assignments:
Med U Formulation Statements:  It was evident that Viktor paid close attention to the cases and was able to identify and communicate the key facts.  His statements were very thorough and comprehensive, but all very long--the goal is to include only pertinent positives and omit negatives and ROS.  The utility of summary statements increases when the key words and concepts are organized into a very compact format, which efficiently and effectively communicates information in fast-paced settings. 
Social Determinants of Health Interview: Viktor demonstrated an excellent understanding of social determinants of health in his interview with a Spanish speaking patient who was unable to access care due to language and financial barriers. Viktor thoughtfully reflected about possible system improvements such as a discharge process that ensures outpatient followup.  His review of the NYC data added to his understanding of other factors that impact the health of minority underserved communities.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
History Taking:  Dean is able to efficiently obtain histories from complex case. He asks insightful and in-depth questions that help with patient care.
Physical Exam:  Dean's exams are completely reliable. He performs complex exam maneuvers well and is very good at checking blood pressures. His exams are appropriate for the clinical situation.
Fund of Knowledge:  Dean applied his strong knowledge base well to clinical situations.  In addition to his strong baseline medical knowledge, he was able to demonstrate significant improvement during this rotation. In particular, he has strong knowledge of pathophysiology.
Clinical Reasoning:  Dean was able to formulate differential diagnosis in a time efficient manner. 
Clinical Presentation:  Dean consistently gave crisp, clear, concise and clinically relevant presentations.  His notes were very good and completed efficiently.
Patient Management:  Dean has good clinical skills and is able to manage most medical problems independently. The majority of the time,  I agreed with Dean's assessments and plans. 
Patient Communication and Counseling:  Dean reads patient's emotions and comfort level well.  He is able to work with all personality types and patients of different socio-economic status. He interacts well with children and their parents and places them at ease.
Professionalism:  Teamwork and Communication:  Dean enthusiastically would see more patients and stay late to enhance his learning experience. He worked well with nursing and clerical staff and went out of his way to interact with them and showed appreciation for their efforts.
Lifelong Learning Skills:  Dean would research and read up on topics enthusiastically. He was adept at using medical literature to improve his medical knowledge. When he used original articles, he was able to critically assess their merits.
Summary:  Dean met all of my expectations for an exceptional medical student. Midway through the rotation, I gave suggestions for improvement and he followed through and met all goals. His enthusiasm to learn and see more patients was noteworthy. He would take every opportunity to learn more, and stay late to finish documentation and reading. His histories and exam were in depth. He was able to see patients and complete notes efficiently, which were crisp, concise, and insightful. At the end of the rotation, I would rarely have to make any changes to his documentation. Time management skills were excellent. Dean consistently displayed a positive attitude and fit in very nicely in our office. His rapport with patients and staff was beyond what I would expect. He has no weaknesses and performs at an exceptional level in many clinical areas. His enthusiasm and strong performance made this a very pleasant month for myself.

Clerkship Director Review of Assignments
Med U Formulation Statements: Dean did a great job on the Med U formulations.  He was concise and well organized in the structure of his summary statements, and it was clear he paid close attention to the cases and was able to identify the important facts.  He can further edit the formulations to be more concise and therefore more effectively communicate key information in fast-paced setting such as rounds.  
Social Determinants of Health Interview:  Dean wrote an extremely thoughtful reflection on a patient with PTSD and PMR which demonstrated an excellent understanding of social determinants of health and their impact on chronic disease management.  His review of the NYC data added to his understanding of other factors that impact the health of underserved communities.

label: Advanced MCY Learner

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Neville is respectful, punctual, and personable. He had stage appropriate skills and knowledge. He demonstrated strength in oral case presentations and interacted with the patients in an engaging and calm fashion.   He worked well with the staff and faculty.   Neville also made progress in his primary care knowledge this block.  He was constantly reading and studying and was very open to learning.  His preventive presentation was very well researched and covered a topic highly relevant to our practice. 

Clerkship didactic assignment review

Med U case summary statement 
Neville submitted concisely written med u summary statements. This efficiency in communication is appreciate,  but some of the statements should have incorporated more key concepts  to help paint a more nuanced clinical picture (chronology sx, key physical findings, psychosocial elements). Going forward, make sure to always identify 3 things in your case summaries, epi/risk factor, timing, major H&P findings.    The goal of the summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a VERY compact and predictable structure. This cognitive exercise will allow you, as well as others listening to you on rounds, to be triggered by these key words and quickly generate as well as narrow down potential differentials and plans.   

Social Determinants of Health Interview
Neville demonstrated a very good understanding of social determinants of health in his interview with an immigrant family who spoke a Pakastani dialect not accessible via the phone interpreter. Neville noted the strong social supports in this family, as well as the cultural and linguistic barriers that complicated their medical care.  He thoughtfully reflected how important the social determinant of poor health literacy is in many immigrant populations, which negatively impacts their health outcomes.  He did not discuss how his understanding of these barriers compared to the data collected by the DOH.

question:
Confidential Areas for Improvement:

Please comment on areas where this student's performance needs to improve prior to graduation. these comments will be shared with the student but will not be included in the Dean's (MSPE) letter.

Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
It was a pleasure working with Ginny this block. She is smart, capable, and motivated to learn. Ginny demonstrated excellent oral presentations skills and her clinical notes were well written.  Ginny worked well with the team and was open and receptive to constructive feedback. Ginny read a lot this block and is clearly focused on building her medical knowledge.  She made progress in her clinical skills and knowledge base and became more comfortable at the bedside speaking with patients. Her prevention presentation demonstrated her ability to teach and to analyze information critically in a sophisticated manner.   

clerkship didactic assignment review

Med U summary statements

Ginny's med U summary statements were well written. It is clear she was paying attention to the modules as these statements captured all of the key concepts in the cases. To get to the next level, work on whittling down the content so you can be more concise and focused. The goal of these summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a very compact and predictably structure. This cognitive exercise will allow you, as well as others listening on rounds, to be triggered by these key words and quickly generate as well as narrow down potential differentials and plans.  


Social Determinants of Health Interview
Ginny demonstrated a very good understanding of social determinants of health, specifically how homelessness, lack of finances resulting in insecure and unhealthy diet, affected the health of a patient with substance abuse and diabetes.  Ginny suggested several practical and multidisciplinary approaches that can assist the patient.  Her review of the NYC data clearly added to her understanding of how social factors played out in the patients she cared for during MCY.

answer_text:
Penelope is an extremely intelligent and clinically strong student clinician who consistently demonstrates impressive intellectual and humanistic approach to patient care. Her clinical skills were quite advanced and Penelope demonstrated confidence and comfort at the bedside. Penelope takes ownership of her patients, she pays close attention to details, and goes the extra mile on their behalf to ensure that all aspects of their care were addressed. Penelope is enthusiastic and engaged during didactic sessions and is clearly a self-motivated learner.


Clerkship Directors' didactic assignment review

Med U summary statement
Penelope's med U statements were organized and informative and consistently well constructed. It was clear that she was attentive to medical and psychosocial factors in the illness experiences.  As you know, the goal of the case summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a very compact and predictable structure. This cognitive processing involved allows you, as well as others listening, to be triggered by key words and quickly generate as well as narrow down potential differentials and plans.  

Social Determinants of Health Interview
Penelope demonstrated a very good understanding of how social determinants of health, particularly financial stressors, exacerbated the asthma of a janitor who was under-insured and unable to afford his medication. Penelope suggested that involving social work early can be very helpful and that health care teams were instrumental in assisting this particular patient. She did not discuss how the DOH data addressed how similar financial and insurances stressors impacted the health of the wider NYC community.

answer_text: Lee has a well developed and sophisticated "bigger picture" understanding of our patients' illness experiences. question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Lee is able to perform detailed history and physical exams and demonstrate the ability to interpret and synthesize data. He is sincere, respectful, and caring with all, and a great team player.  Lee is  confident and and demonstrates superb communication skills. Lee is able to generate a solid plan of care, and he is attentive to preventive care for the elderly population seen at the VA.  He made progress in expanding differentials, learning about treatment options, and understanding the interplay of medical and psychosocial factors. His quality improvement project was excellent and very enlightening and practical. It was a pleasure having him at the VA.

Clerkship Didactic Assignments

Social Determinants of Health
On his MCY F writeup- Lee reflected on a patient with presumed chronically uncontrolled conditions who ultimately experienced complications resulting in cognitive and functional impairment. Despite not harboring the traditional social barriers to care, this patient faced a discoordinated care network, seeing numerous clinicians overwhelmed and daunted by the task at hand with limited time to collaborate, recognize, and address this individual's needs.  With so much that has happened to this patient, it would have been interesting to explore the SDH barriers that may have existed 10 or 20 yrs ago (access, financial, education, behaviorial) to result in such poor downstream outcome.  Sadly it sounds like this patient is no longer able to participate in this discussion.

Med U Case Summary Statement
Lee is quite concise in his summary statement writing.  He made progress during the block in finding and communicating all the key discoveries in an organized fashion.  To get even better, work on organizing the format, and identifying all the key triggers (including psychosocial context that may impact care) in the cases.   The goal of these summary statements is to bring together key concepts and findings into a very compact and predictably structure. The cognitive processing ritual will allow yourself as well as others (on rounds/reading your notes) to be quickly triggered by these key words to generate and narrow down diagnoses and care plan.

answer_text:
Ron was a pleasure to have on the rotation. He functioned at the level of a PGY-1 resident for the most part. He was courteous, professional, and efficient. He was able to obtain complex patient histories, in timely manner. His patient presentations were concise and accurate. His office notes showed that he was thinking about differentials and work up during the patient encounter. He continued to read during the rotation, and demonstrated a commitment to patient care and medicine. The staff and I truly enjoyed working with him. 

Case summary statements (FM Cases)
Ron did a very good job on the case summary statements.  He was able to identify many of the key concepts in each of the cases. The organization and layout of his statements improved with practice (for example putting exam after history). To get even better, make sure you are always communicating 3 elements, Epi (risk factor, exposure, including psychosocial risks), timing, and key H&P findings. The goal of writing summary statements is to consolidate key words/concepts into a very compact and predictable summary. The cognitive exercise will hopefully allow you, as well as others listening to you on rounds, to be triggered by the key words/concepts to generate and narrow down potential differentials.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Harry was a dedicated student throughout his primary care presentation. His history and physical, professionalism, and management skills were at an aspirational level.  He developed a thorough understanding of multiple core primary care disease and treatments including Type II diabetes, essential hypertension, depression, anxiety, asthma, and COPD. For the first time in 10 years as a student preceptor, I received a letter from a complex geriatric patient inquiring and requesting that a medical student (Harry) whom they interacted with consider practicing in the area upon his graduation. That speaks more than highly of his professionalism and abilities to interact with complex patients. Harry will be an asset to any residency program, as he demonstrates the balance of medical knowledge and professionalism needed in the field of medicine.


FM cases summary statement review
Harry did a good job and made progress in recognizing and accurately communicating most of the key findings in cases.    To get even better, work on consistency in organizational layout (history ahead always of exam findings), and aim to communicate three things: epi (risk factors, exposures, psychosocial context), timing, H&P findings.    The goal of the summary statement is to consolidate key words and concepts into a compact and predictably structure. This cognitive exercise will allow you, as well as others listening to you on rounds, to be triggered by these key words and quickly generate as well as narrow down potential differentials and plans.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: It was truly inspirational to watch Fleur do motivational interviewing with an elderly woman with reactive depression due to the loss of her husband.  Fleur was able to introduce the concepts of mindfulness, meditation and possibly yoga to this woman, and to generate in the patient a true excitement about this approach to her sadness.  I am sure that she changed the patient's outlook on life that day.  She left smiling and very grateful for the time that Fleur spent with her.  Fleur also had a big impact on the aforementioned patient with complicated mental health needs, who was quite worked up and difficult to direct the day that Fleur spoke with her.  That patient also left the office saying that she had truly appreciated Fleur' concern and advice that day, and that she would try to make changes in her life.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Colin would consistently review things we had seen during the day and on a few occasions we actually had him research something and come back with it. From a personal learning standpoint, there was a particular moment his last week that impressed me. We had been working on knee exams  and he saw a patient where knee pain was only part of several complaints.  Colin had taken a history, done an exam made an assessment. We went back together, repeated the exam and asked a few more questions and made the diagnosis which was different than his assessment. Colin spontaneously (with no encouragement) said- "I'm disappointed in my knee exam and history." He went on to assess what he could have done differently in both exam and history. I was impressed at his immediate self assessment and evaluation.

question: Summary Comments: Please add summative, additional comments in any area beyond those provided above. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
This evaluation reflects the input of all the clinical faculty at our site. 
Cedric is an engaged learner in the ambulatory setting.  He is poised at the bedside, and demonstrates thoughtful and holistic approaches to patient care.   Cedric is open to feedback and developing his organizational skills and independent decision making capacity.  

Cedric did really well on the adult internal medicine shelf exam, scoring almost 2 SD above rotation mean. 

Clerkship Didactic Feedback

Cedric was proactive and very on top of his clerkship didactic and administrative requirements.

Med U Summary statement  - Cedric did very well with writing Med U summary statements. He was able to identify a large number of key concepts in each of the cases. He should continue to practice with a focus on being organized and concise.  

MCY F writeup- Cedric wrote a very thought provoking piece. In it he explored the impact of the new political environment as it relates to the medical care of undocumented immigrants who have severe illnesses like HIV.  Cedric spoke about the vital role and voice of physicians in health care advocacy.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Cedric demonstrated appropriate development of patient management skills with increasing independence in proposal of proactive management plans and preventive care interventions as the rotation progressed.  He incorporated important psychosocial perspective in his assessments and management plans with an holistic approach to patient care.

question: <b>Comments: Refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Cedric demonstrated an adequate medical knowledge base for his level of training. His understanding of underlying pathophysiology and clinical applications at the bedside progressed nicely this block.   He also developed familiarity with primary care prevention guidelines through out the rotation.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text:
Made progress in 1-week rotation in understanding flow/operation of ICU. Very good knowledge base--learning to probe/target with more specific questions depending upon patient's needs/problems. 
Read more about specific disease processes. 
Although fairly thorough in most aspects, I think what will help Colin develop further, as he progresses in his career, is to become quicker in his history taking and physical examination. It is a challenge that everyone encounters, when taking that next step in their career, however developing it early, while in school will make the transition smoother from a student to an intern. A practical step that could be implemented would be to try to commit to memory as much of the history and physical, rather than writing everything down. Overall, I think Colin is well on his way to become a fabulous doctor.

Colin did an exemplary job during his rotation.  He was passionate about his patients and really worked to get an excellent history for each of his patients.  

Overall Colin was a pleasure to work with. He frequently checked in to ask questions and to assist with addition work as needed. When provided with tasks, these are usually completed, although occasionally may need a reminder. Would recommend that on the sub-internship service, discharge summaries should be started and updated for patients that he is carrying. 

During rounds, would stick with being consistent with stuctured presentations including brief patient ID (i.e. age, primary complaint) => overnight events => any updated labs/studies that were pending => exam/vitals that are changed => assessment based on problems. Recommend being consistent with presenting patients with problem based assessment and plan as when they do get more complicated, it is difficult to keep tract of these issues unless the presentation is organized this way.

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Cho was a wonderful addition to our preceptor group. She is smart, cheerful, upbeat and a great colleague, who demonstrates professionalism in every interaction. Her fund of knowledge is strong and grew significantly over the course of the clerkship. Cho was an avid reader, and always sought to fill in gaps in her knowledge base.  By the end of the clerkship, Cho's write ups were very inclusive and she was able to generate an appropriately hierarchical assessment and plan. She is an excellent teacher of her peers, and organized two well reasoned presentations to the group (on approaches to jaundice and lymphoma) that were interactive, and balanced didactic teaching with good use of patient cases. Cho was very comfortable in the clinical arena, and immediately put her patient at ease in her observed history and physical. She performed a very complete history on a patient who was a tangential historian. Cho accepts and incorporates feedback quickly. She is compassionate with patients, and a great team member. Her enthusiasm when she "gets it", whether that is in drawing out a reticent patient or making a pathophysiologic  connection in her own mind, is palpable. Cho will make an excellent physician.

question: Comments on the Observed H and P
answer_text: Fleur quickly and easily engage this patient who responded to her with rapt attention.  Her queries were open ended.  She then followed with appropriate mere directed questions.  She was well organized and comfortable at the bedside.  Would perform more detailed lymph node exam on this patient with lymphoma.  All in all excellent.

Initially she had to make adjustment for how to collect clinical data about the patients in palliative care, but she learned that very quickly. She also has deep insight for the treatment plan and was ready to discuss it with me. 

Very professional and hard working. Great enthusiasm for learning. Excellent bedside manner. Always stepped up and offered to help out with other cases. A true team player.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Fund of knowledge: Lee had an impressive fund of knowledge for an early third year medical student. This was evident in both his focused relevant patient presentations. He quickly caught on to the relevant data for heart failure and cardiac patients in general. He also did excellent didactic presentations to the team regarding pulmonary hypertension and the WHO classification and also on hypernatremia and its management.
Patient care skills: would perform detailed physical exams on his patients every morning and had the knowledge base to update his patients and review plans of care with them.
Presentations: were very clear and concise and demonstrated strong fund of medical knowledge.
Communication skills: communicated well with patients. Got comfortable calling consults and gave detailed didactic presentations with ease. Advanced for an early third year Med student.
Professionalism very professional. No issues
Team work: fantastic team member
Teaching: fantastic job teaching. This is really an area where Lee shined. His didactic talk on pulmonary hypertension was very helpful to the team and helped advance team understating of etiologies, work up and management of pulmonary hypertension overall and as it related to his patient. 

Lee was a wonderful student to work with and for his very first rotation of MCY year, he did a fantastic job. He was compassionate and kind to all of his patients, a team player, and fun to work with. He thought carefully about each of his patients, rose to the challenge of admitting difficult patients and was inquisitive in his H&P and assessments. His professionalism is excellent and he has a solid foundation for his fund of knowledge.  

I only worked with Lee for a few days - he had a great fund of knowledge and was always eager to learn more. He has a phenomenal bedside manner and made meaningful relationships with his patients. He also advocated for his patients frequently. His follow-up presentations were succinct and largely from memory. He was a great team player and always remained professional 

I would like to comment on my experience working with Lee Jordan on Gen Med 2 a few weeks ago. Lee was an inquisitive, highly-motivated, and thoughtful member of our wards team. He carried multiple patients at a time and presented them both as admissions and follow-ups on rounds. His notes were well-crafted and his differentials though-out and deliberate. On multiple occasions he sought to teach the team about topics pertinent to his own patients. I am sure he will develop into a well-rounded and knowledgeable house-staff officer. 

Lee was a valuable team member. His presentations were thorough and he demonstrated a good understanding of pathophysiology. He gave a good talk on hyponatremia to the team during the rotation.  

Great medical student with excellent fund of knowledge! Excellent presentations. A pleasure to work with. 



ATTENDINGS

I am continually impressed and amazed by the very high quality of the Medical Students on my rotations and this time was no exception.  Lee Jordan was extremely intelligent with a very strong fund of knowledge and the motivation to improve.  He gave excellent presentations on a number of different topics and asked very astute questions which indicated to me his interest and involvement at a very high level.  Lee did a terrific job of taking a history, doing a physical exam and synthesizing a meaningful presentation in a way that was extremely mature for this stage of his training.  He interacted very well with patients, nurses and physicians.  He was a valued member of the team and his participation and contributions was welcomed and valued.  I have only the highest praise for him and for his remarkable performances.  If there are any questions about this please do not hesitate to contact me.  

Lee was an outstanding medical student. He has an excellent bedside manner. His presentations were always on point with well thought out assessments and plan. He was self motivated and often read and brought primary literature to the group. He also was an incredible asset to the team by always being available. I would have never guess our rotation was Lee's first ward month. He is well beyond his point in training.  

Lee Jordan: he knows far more than I would expect for someone at his stage of training.  His presentations were outstanding, and his final presentation of the rotation was particularly impressive.  The case was straightforward, but his approach to the differential diagnosis"Ósorting through each alternative diagnosis and the data that did or did not fit with that diagnosis"Ówas something that I would expect from a mid-level or senior resident rather than a medical student just beginning his clinical training.  He seems to have a naturally curious, questioning mind.  Overall, a pleasure to work with.  

Lee Jordon:
Fund of knowledge : very good knowledge; showed willingness to learn 
Patient care skills: very thorough; addressed every concern that patient raised and advocated for patients
Presentations: excellent presentations  
Communication skills: good communications skills
Professionalism good raport with patients
Team work: pleasant to work with, well integrated with the team
Teaching: excellent presentations

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Very professional student, team player, contributes good ideas to the team and truly cares for patients. 
Excellent communication skills. Professional behavior. Punctual. Courteous towards patients, patient's family members, as well as other team members and staff. Interested in learning and committed to improving medical knowledge. 
His history taking skills were above average and often uncovered details that others did not discover that were critical to a new diagnosis or influenced patient care. His presentation of new patients and on rounds were clear and succinct in a way medical students often struggle with. He was an eager learner and asked questions during rounds and contributed to the learning of others. He immediately incorporated suggestions for improvement into his practice such as note writing and physical exam skills. His interpersonal skills are exemplary and I allowed him to share test results with patients independently. 
Colin is always very prepared to see his patients. Colin knows the important questions to ask based on the patient's problem. Colin does thorough work. His presentations to the team were informative and accurate. Colin's patients like him. 
Colin has excellent communication skills and data collection ability. He can critically assess data and can come up with diagnostic and therapeutic plan.
Enthusiastic and outstanding in case presentation. 
Colin effectively gathered and interpretted patient information in the direct patient interview format. He was professional and developed good repo with the patients. The presentations were efficient and accurate. The patients appeared to enjoy his interaction. In discussion of the cases, Colin was open and honest with his understanding of the data's relationship to pathophysiology. Most importantly, he understand the relationship of disease to the person as a whole. 
I have worked with Mr. Creevey intermittently over the last year. He was on my Teaching Team in the spring 2017 and was thoughtful, intelligent and inquisitive. During that time, we spent some time reviewing how to perform a thorough H & P and on presentation skills. By his next rotation in July 2017, I was pleasantly surprised at the degree of improvement he had made. Mr. Creevey took the recommendations I made and ran with it. His History taking was thorough, and demonstrated his intellectual and personal curiosity about each patient. It was clear; he did not simply go through the motions and ask the questions he knew he was supposed to ask. The information he garnered showed a depth and thoughtfulness some physicians never demonstrate. He clearly surpasses his level of education in his ability to see the patient in the context of not only their illness but their life as well. He has a particular interest in Psychiatry and was able to anticipate how their psychosocial situation had and may influence their medical conditions. Mr. Creevey is a proactive learner. He routinely chose patients to follow and always took the lead on presenting the patient on rounds without being prompted. Mr. Creevey's level of enthusiasm, thoroughness and synthesis of a patient's medical information surpassed some of the interns on our team. 
Very bright, jumped right into role of presenting ICU patients on rounds. Was prepared to share data and problems and impressively ideas. 
Very impressed with Colins week on Critical care. Very good medical knowledge base reads and reviews appropriate literature. Very impressed with case presentations, very succinct, summarizes information well. 
Advocates for his patients -Develops broad differentials and ranks likely-diagnoses appropriate to each patient case. During 2 different patient care scenarios, he was able to think of diagnoses house staff had not initially considered and helped rule these diagnoses in or out. -Has an enthusiasm for learning and an upbeat attitude. 
This is the 3rd time I have worked directly with Mr. Creevey on the Wards. He has continued to be an excellent medical student. His clinical knowledge is ahead of where I would expect him to be. His write-ups are timely, demonstrate a thorough evaluation process and he lists appropriate differential diagnosis and commits to the most relevant. He is incredibly personable, kind and always actively participated in teaching rounds. He was trusted with a newly diagnosed HIV patient and many of the communications regarding her test results. He did this with compassion and sensitivity as she also had a dual Psychiatric Disorder. Most of all he is a hard worker. He always picks up additional patients without being asked. He finishes his work even when he has other commitments that take him away from the floors. I never have to remind him to follow up on test results. This comes from an innate sense of intellectual curiosity, which Mr. Creevey certainly exhibits.
Colin takes a thorough history and has a methodical physical exam skill, especially his neurological examination. Has a decent fund of knowledge for his level of training. He is a responsible medical student, who does not need prompting and follows-up on his patients in a timely fashion.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Fleur stood out during this rotation - she was very engaged and proactive, and started the week with clear learning objectives. It was clear from her questions and responses that she has a strong fund of knowledge to draw from and to build on, and she was a great team contributor. Her compassion for patients was apparent with a challenging case we had with a patient who had unexpected complications during a surgery, resulting in prolonged intubation. Her demeanor with the family was very kind and professional, and she contributed to the team's knowledge of the patient with an excellent patient presentation during rounds. She also researched and presented the risks and benefits of the targeted cooling therapy in anoxic brain injury, which was helpful for the team in managing the patient as well. 
Immense wisdom beyond her years Compassionate Patient thinks outside the box. 
Very good knowledge, enthusiastic, hardworking. 
Gave a very good presentation on antibiotics which was a big topic but she was able to summarize well. Her presentation skill was excellent. She was very interested to know about treatment plans and asked pertinent questions. 
Fleur worked hard in pulmonary clinic. She demonstrated a good fund of knowledge and ability to increase her knowledge. She was confident and willing to gain by discussion for advanced pulmonary issues beyond the scope of a Medical Student. Her willingness to push her learning to a higher level is a very important; one might say a superior trait of an accomplished Physician. Fleur was willing to rethink previously dismissed ideas, from a fresh perspective. Another sign of a good learner. 
It is always a pleasure mentoring Fleur. Broad and deep fund of medical knowledge. Presentations are polished and neat. Always comes up with very broad differential. Write-ups are insightful, easy to understand and succinct. Very empathetic to patients and their families, which is clearly seen in her presentations as well. Works very well as part of a team. Hardworking, always willing to stay with team and help them. I have personally appreciated her dedication many times for staying late and trying to help patients and their families understand about the complex situations. Oral presentations are extraordinary, she is a great teacher. Overall Fleur has shown exceptional dedication in her work, compassion towards patients, enthusiasm for learning and exceptionally thoughtful in understanding the needs of her fellow teammates.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF



Cedric was perhaps the most compassionate, thoughtful, and thorough medical student with whom I have worked. He is incredibly motivated to take the best care of patients he can, and went above and beyond on many occasions. The rapport that Cedric was able to build with his patients is beyond what many residents and even attendings are capable of. The way he connects with people is a skill that for some takes many years to develop. For Cedric, such an ability is inherent. One three unique instances, members of the care coordination team approached me to ask for Cedric's full name so he could potentially be formally recognized for his excellence in patient care. In addition to Cedric's interpersonal skills, his fund of knowledge is above that of many at his level. He remains curious and engaged, often looking up literature to support group discussions and contribute to the team's learning. I only have the highest of compliments for Cedric. He is intelligent, kind, and humble. I would be thrilled to have the opportunity to work with him again, and am certain he will succeed in whatever he chooses.
Cedric is an excellent student who is very enthusiastic and hard-working. He was really outstanding among his peers in maturity and compassion for his patients. We had a very challenging list and Cedric was at the forefront of taking care of our most difficult patients. He went above and beyond to spend time with one particular patient who was dealing with addiction and non-complaint with medical care. Because of Cedric' efforts and therapeutic relationship with this patient, we were able to advance his care and keep him the hospital. Cedric also participated in a family meeting involving the Ethics committee regarding this patient and made valuable contributions with a level of understanding and maturity that I have not seen in other medical students. Another example - Cedric was very compassionate towards a homeless patient with schizophrenia; he treated this marginalized, disenfranchised man with respect and dignity. Discharge planning for this patient was very complicated and Cedric was a tremendous help to me in this process - again, a responsibility that I have not seen any other medical student take on, and embrace, in the way Cedric did.  Cedric possesses a wonderful sense of curiosity and a genuine thirst for knowledge. He was always well-prepared for rounds and carried 2-3 patients, which is more than expected. He had reviewed all the data and already synthesized it prior to presenting on rounds. He had the ability to see what I would call the big picture for each of his patients, without getting bogged down by irrelevant data. He has an excellent understanding of pathophysiology and is able to formulate management plans for his patients. He asked questions on rounds, was not afraid to speak up. And he was very patient with an attending who often asked him to repeat information several times. He was responsive to feedback and incorporated any suggestions we gave him.

Definitely the best medical student I have worked with so far! He will be an amazing clinician and I hope I have the chance to work with him again!
 

Patient care skills: this is one of Cedric' strongest areas.  He demonstrated consistent and exceptional empathy when interacting with patients, and would draw the team's attention to the psychosocial wellbeing of our patients, even those whom he was not specifically following.  He had good rapport with all of his patients, and was immediately comfortable in all of his interactions, even when being scrutinized by the team.
Presentations: Cedric' presentations were thorough, well-articulated, and thoughtful.  He developed full differentials, and was able to reason his way through even difficult cases clearly.  
Communication skills: Cedric is exceptionally well-spoken, and has the poise and assurance of a much more mature trainee.  He was never afraid to offer opinions on patients during rounds, but also managed to deliver his comments in a way that was respectful and appropriate.
Professionalism : Cedric was always professional and respectful in his interactions with patients and team members.  He is a true gentleman.  He will make an excellent house officer in his chosen field.
Team work: Cedric was always more than happy to contribute to the team, and actively offered to perform tasks even for patients he was not actively following.  
Teaching: Cedric did an excellent job sharing pearls and articles he had found while reading about his patients.  He is a strong teacher, and clearly enjoys taking on the role of teacher. 

Cedric was in my sister team "Ó I did not work closely one-on-one with him. 
Fund of knowledge: Cedric had a broad base of clinical and basic science knowledge and seemed to read on topics relevant to his patients.
Patient care skills: Strong patient advocate, consistently challenged primary team to consider how best to connect with an individual patient.
Presentations: Cedric gave a clear, well-organized admission presentation on morning rounds, with mastery of all relevant history, physical exam findings, and interpretation of imaging. He required little if any cueing.
Communication skills: Cannot assess. 
Professionalism Appeared professional in our interactions. 
Team work: Cannot assess. 
Teaching: Gave succinct explanations of medical concepts and several trials on rounds. 

ATTENDINGS

Mr. Diggory was a pleasure to work with during the rotation. He showed superb initiative in learning, both by asking thoughtful questions and doing outside readings on relevant topics. He demonstrated a good fund of knowledge during his patient presentations. Mr. Diggory was professional and he worked well with the team. He displayed excellent insight in the care of management of complex patients, taking into account the interaction between a variety of medical and non-medical components of patient care.  


Cedric was quiet on rounds. When he did contribute he showed a solid understanding of the relevant pathophysiology commensurate with his level of education. 
Based on his initial and follow-up patient presentations Cedric was a bit diffuse and scattered. He did not show that he understood the important pieces of the history, physical exam, and laboratory data to convey to us- especially for his follow-ups. I had mentioned to him that all we need is a thumb nail sketch to remind us about the patient and then in sentence or two new info since previous day but that didn't seem to happen.  Several of his patients had complicated and severe diseases in the setting of drug abuse and addiction.  He could be overly focused on the drugs and lose track of the underlying disease progression- which I would assume is what is the important learning experience for this rotation.  I thought maybe he wants to go into psychiatry but he said no.
See above.  Felt like Cedric was taking us on an interesting journey to an unknown location.
Cedric is quiet and low key but is kind, understanding, and genuine.  
Cedric showed a high level of professionalism.
The residents tell me that Cedric was a good team player.
Cedric did an excellent job with brief presentations on assigned topics including getting a few references for myself and the group on one of our patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Cedric was the student on my team. In the month that he was with us he made only one or possibly two presentations so there was not much for me to go with to assess his performance. He did not present from memory.  He did, however, follow several patients and he was able to present their progress reports adequately. His interaction with patients was quite good and he was sensitive while asking appropriate and insightful questions. He often offered comments that were appropriate and helpful. His knowledge base was as expected. He was professional in his demeanor. All told I would say his performance was a solid average for a P&S student. 

Cedric did a good job with his presentations and was professional.  He asked good/relevant questions about patient care.

answer_text: 56yo female RLE ulcerative lesion with possibly surrounding cellulitis in setting of UC - likely pyoderma gangrenous.  He quickly & easily engaged the patient with his very pleasant, calm and relaxed style.  Meticulous acquisition of hx and very streamlined efficiently performed PE.  Outstanding oral presentation following the bedside exercise.  During chest exam, would suggest percussion prior to auscultation.  All in all a truly masterful performance.
