question: Comments on the Observed H and P
answer_text:
Pt with severe lumbar pain in setting of spondylodiscitis.   He very patiently and carefully obtained detailed hx from patient with complex medical hx current and past.  Skillfully performed exam despite limitations imposed by pts. Patient.  Generally excellent performance.  
I did observe Harry performing parts of the exam including pulmonary exam, cardiac exam and neuro exam on some patients. He is able to independently perform these exams at this point. He performed an abbreviated neuro exam focusing on key elements superbly on one of our patients that needed a f/u exam. I also observed him obtaining parts of the history or clarifying the hx when presenting at the bedside. He asked opened questions and was able to narrow the questioning appropriately in an engaging, empathetic manner that encouraged sharing of information. I felt very comfortable having him lead the interview.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text:
He was able to obtain data effectively but as is the case for many 3rd year students, still struggled at times to fully interpret data and form an accurate assessment and plan. He was at or slightly above the level, I would expect for a 3rd year medical student. 
Harry's H&Ps and notes were well organized and continue to improve. I did give feedback to include more pertinent positive and negatives in the HPI and to expand his PE findings in his H&P's. He collects all the pertinent hx but doesn't always document it. This improved over the week. I also recommended that he not template his exam findings in his daily SOAP notes since it leads to excessive exam findings not relevant to f/u. 
He needs to start making plan for patients, and "manage" them, rather than only "observing" them. However, I have observed him only in cancer center, and thus he is not expected to manage cancer patients. In general, he should continue do do so in primary care medicine/surgical clinics. 
Continue to work on structured differential diagnosis to assist in developing effective assessment and plan.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Harry continues to be very proactive at looking up topics and summarizing the literature for the team. He gave an excellent presentation on Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia and discussed the advantages/disadvantages of different types of maintenance fluids. His ability to interpret the medical literature is clearly above average. He is doing very well at reading EKGs and interpreting acid base balance and has demonstrated his ability to take what he learned during our last rotation and apply to patients this time. He learned about a few new topics this time including UGI bleed, tachycardias, and complications of ETOH abuse. His oral presentations continue to improve. His HPI's are more organized and inclusive and presented with less use of his notes this time. His communications skills with patients, families and staff is superb. He is able to obtain key historical information in a natural flowing, empathetic manner. Clearly above average. He integrated and worked within the team very well sharing information in a positive fashion. Harry seems to be developing right on track and look forward to spending more time with him on inpatient service. 
Enthusiastic and bright, eagerly took on patients and quickly adopted systems based presentation method. Developed problem-identifying skills and showed ability to develop care plan. 
Harry is a team player who continually expresses interest in his patients' well-being. He was a delight to have on the ICU team. Patients and staff very much liked having Harry around. 
By the end of the rotation, he had a very good epistemological approach to nephrological disorders. 
Harry is an exceptional person. Great to talk to. He integrated fabulously into the team. Great interpersonal skills. Good knowledge for his level and is always curious to learn more. Looks for data to inform decisions. His presentation on Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia was well researched, prepared and delivered. 
Harry's case presentations were excellent flowing in an organized manner from HPI, PMH, Meds to PE and labs. His presentations were hypothesis driven with more focused data being provided than during his first week. He has grown tremendously in being proactive at providing the patient's relevant problem list as well as a preliminary differential diagnosis and management plan. Furthermore, with minimal prompting and time to think he was able to come up with less common potential causes of a patient's medical problem and more in depth management options. This was evident when we had a patient with hyperkalemia where he shared very accurately the management options. Harry presented on several topics including dorsal midbrain syndrome, thyroid function in pregnancy and how to predict severity of pancreatitis. He gave superb, short presentations that demonstrated his ability to efficiently summarize the key relevant clinical information for the team. He is incredibly logical in his thought process and I am certain will develop into a superb diagnostician. Harry continues to be a superb communicator with patients, including an incredibly warm, empathetic demeanor. Harry's bedside verbal presentations have developed tremendously into organized, easy flowing presentations. 
Harry is very pleasant medical student, very astute and aware of his surroundings. His medical knowledge is average. He has fantastic bedside manners, and communicates well with staff/patients. 
Harry was a pleasure to work with. He was was an eager learner, asking many questions and looking up topics on his own at times as well.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
It was a pleasure working with Ron. He showed great enthusiasm and interest on the inpatient rotation. He has deep fund of medical knowledge-both basic sciences and clinical. He is a wonderful person and will be a great physician-seen in his compassion and hardworking skills. Made himself thoroughly involved in teamwork, case presentations, topic presentations and discussions. Case presentations are succinct, well organized and detailed. 
He did literature reading on two topics; anorectal abscess in neutropenia and autonomic dysfunction, and shared with the team. 
We had a productive and enjoyable rotation together. He is ready for internship quite early in his medical school training. He has done an impressive job learning the physical exam, particularly the neurologic exam. He performs this skill at the resident level. 
His presentations were comprehensive and clear, and contributed immediately to patient care. He is working above the level that one might expect for his level of training and experience. 
Ron is an exemplary medical student. He has a thoughtful, calm demeanor. His presentations were concise and well organized, and he demonstrated a superior knowledge of pathophysiology. A return patient complimented his bedside skills and noted that he wished all of his doctors were as kind and empathetic as Ron. 
Pleasure working with Ron. Broad fund of medical knowledge. Presentations are neat and thorough. Enthusiastic and very much involved in patient care and teamwork. Excellent communication and interpersonal skills. I am impressed by his history taking, physical exam and presenting skills. Write-ups are detailed and insightful. Overall a very dedicated, hardworking and exceptional medical student. 
First time working with Ron. Very fast and efficient while still taking a thorough history. Has a good knowledge base and came up with a broad differential. Great bedside demeanor, empathy towards patients is on point. Assessments and plans were succinct on his daily progress notes. He did a brief power point presentation on sensory and motor deficits, dermatome distribution. He looked up and then summarized role of novel anticoagulants in submissive PE/PE with large clot burden. Presentations were very concise, and knew how to summarize all the pertinent information. 
Excellent knowledge base, clinical skills, communication, professionalism, bedside manner. I saw him take the HPI for new pts and perform bedside presentation to me. His presentation skills really stood out. He is a very strong, organized, comprehensive presenter. One of the best presenters that I have seen in students so far. Also gave multiple excellent presentations during the week on pertinent topics, showing excellent EBM skills. Overall strong student, no concerns.
He made an impressive and succinct presentation on cardiogenic shock during this rotation. 
Ron showed he could learn actively and independently while on the medicine service. He worked on understanding difficult patient cases and came up with excellent differentials on his own
It is such a pleasure working with Ron. I am extremely honored to be his mentor. Exceptional dedication and enthusiasm for learning. He has always been a role model for our team members. Medical knowledge is superior and has deep fund of medical knowledge in both basic sciences and clinical. His presentations are extraordinary and superior. Write-ups are detailed, sophisticated, yet easy to understand. Oral case presentations and topic reviews are effective and insightful. He is an excellent teacher. Very empathetic towards patients, patient's families and all the medical team members. Always a helping hand. I am amazed by the dedication, hard work and compassion put in to patient care and learning. No doubt, that he will excel in whatever medical field he will opt for.

question: Teamwork and Professionalism
label: 4

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Lavender was a wonderful medical student, demonstrating enthusiasm, intellectual rigor and an impressive work ethic. Her fund of knowledge was notable; she was well prepared and knowledgeable regarding the clinical and pathophysiological aspects of her cases. Throughout the clerkship, Lavender demonstrated an impressive ability to critically review the literature and effectively apply it to her patient care. Her critical thinking improved steadily and significantly over the course of our 6 weeks together and was quite sophisticated at the conclusion of the clerkship. 
Lavender was very thoughtful and articulate; she always contributed to the group discussions and was very enthusiastic about sharing the knowledge that she gained with our group. Throughout the clerkship, Lavender was an effective teacher for the other students. Her formal topic presentation on opportunistic infections in HIV was very thorough and extremely well-researched. 
Lavender's write-ups were exemplary, with the Formulation and Discussion sections being particularly noteworthy for the way in which she seamlessly wove patient-specific points with information from standard medical texts and the medical literature that were pertinent to diagnosis and management. The discussions were excellent and a pleasure to read; thorough with thoughtful, broad differentials, pulling together complex histories into cohesive patient-centered stories, incorporating pathophysiology and current research.
Lavender consistently paid careful attention to the psychosocial aspects of her cases. She always included a thoughtful assessment of the patient's home support and the barriers to optimal medical care and made suggestions for how these could be addressed. More than once, I personally observed how her bedside manner demonstrated maturity and compassion. 
In terms of professionalism and attitude, Lavender was also exemplary. She was always polite, mature and respectful. Her write-ups were always punctual. Importantly, Lavender responded well to constructive criticism and made a concerted effort to improve in suggested areas.  It is clear that she wants to develop and excel. I was impressed in general with her interpersonal and leadership skills.

answer_text: Areas for Lavender to improve include practicing presenting from memory and gaining more confidence in her public speaking.

question: Comments on the Observed H and P
answer_text: Lavender's patient care skills were outstanding; she consistently obtained accurate and complete histories and performed detailed and thorough physical examinations. For her Observed H&P, she asked open-ended questions and allowed the patient to answer in his own words, yet at the same time guided the interview in a way that made sense and hit all of the relevant points. She also performed an extensive and appropriate physical and was able to anticipate and detect abnormal findings in a highly competent manner.

question: Professionalism

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Patil is a fantastic med student!  She is clearly eager to learn, constantly offers to help the team in whatever way possible, takes initiative, and isn't afraid to state her opinion with what she thinks is going on with a patient (with evidence) and what should be done about it.  Presentations are clear and thorough.  She is passionate about her patients and will no doubt do great in her medical career. 

Fund of knowledge: excellent for the stage that she is in med school, and she was enthusiastic about reading up on topics and learning more.
Presentations: concise, clear, confident in presenting, able to synthesize assessment and come up with a plan on her own seemingly
Communication skills: was a pleasure to work with and integrated into the team seamlessly; was not directly part of my resident/intern team so cannot comment more on communication skills.
Professionalism: enthusiastic and positive, a pleasure to be around.
Team work: wanted to integrate into the team as much as possible and did so well.
Teaching: did a presentation on CIWA protocol vs. symptom triggered alcohol withdrawal treatment in light of a few patients we had. 

Patil is a fantastic medical student -- super helpful and a great privilege to have on the team. Always willing and eager to help, genuinely cared about her patients, often going above and beyond (e.g. making sure to see a patient with active medical issue even though he was off the floor, taking the initiative to schedule outpatient follow-up, serving as a participant in family meetings, etc.). Presents well, organized, great fund of knowledge (definitely above average for her level of training), and always paid close attention to physical exam findings. Always willing to learn more about cardiology, asked very thoughtful questions. She's going to go on to be a great resident in whatever field she chooses! 

Patil is one of the best medical students I've worked with. She was extremely helpful, always making sure she did everything to help the team. She knew her patients very very well, and really immersed herself in the care of the patients. She was a valuable member of the team, and very reliable and trustworthy to carry out the team's tasks. She was very intelligent, and came every day very well read and asked multiple inquisitive questions.  Her presentations were excellent. I really enjoyed working with Patil! 

Fund of knowledge: excellent. She asked excellent questions and demonstrated solid understanding of pathophysiology 
Patient care skills: Interacted well with patients and was very thorough in exams
Presentations: Excellent presentations, able to synthesize information very well 
Communication skills: Outstanding- worked well with all on the team
Professionalism Excellent- tried to find ways to help when we were busy
Teaching: Excellent effort in bringing in articles to teach about on rounds. To get to the next level- try to describe how the articles you're reading are relevant to the patient. 

I worked together with Patil for several weeks on the cardiology service. I was very impressed with her knowledge, her curiosity to learn, and her warmhearted display of kindness to many of our sickest and dying patients. She would often stay late speaking with family members, comforting patients in the evenings, and reassuring them when they became frustrated with the unfortunate consequences of their illness. She was also excellent at having GOC discussions and helped not only translate, but lead the discussions in very difficult cases of patients dying and terminally ill from heart failure. I was particularly impressed with her ability to relay very difficult topics of conversations to the family as a 3rd year medical student- this is something myself, and other residents often have difficulty with well into their residency training. 
Of particular note, there was a very special patient who I had been regularly seeing in clinic, but was admitted to Gen Med 2 with cirrhosis while Patil was on service. She continued to follow the patient while she was on cardiology, coming with me to clinic to see her, and joining me in multiple GOC conversations with the family when she was readmitted to the Gen Med 2 service later on that month. 
All the patients she had been following loved her and really appreciated her thoughtfulness and the attention she provided them. They all trusted her and made the entire team's care for these patients much easier!
She also gave 2 very impressive discussions on non-compaction cardiomyopathy and the utility of amiodarone in patients with NSVT, as well as an introduction on pulmonary angioplasty in patients with CTEPH. These were all fascinating discussions intertwined into admission presentations of patients that she was following.

Patil worked on the sister team, and my interactions with her were brief. What I can speak to is her ability to incorporate evidence-based medicine into her presentations. For each of her HPIs, Patil references multiple studies that supported her assessment and plan for her patients. 


ATTENDINGS

She gave excellent, to-the-point presentations, and participated actively in the discussions. Patil asked questions and demonstrated an excellent fund of knowledge. No problems whatsoever. 

Patil:  highly involved and interested in clinical endeavors.  Very intelligent"Óappropriate fund of knowledge"Ócurious and asks good questions.  Presentations a little bit tentative but still quite good, but most importantly her case formulations were excellent.  Highly professional and outstanding interaction with patients.


very good fund of knowledge
attentive and participatory during rounds
Very close follow-up on her assigned patients
Read up on all the relevant medical issues
Did medical review on the relevant topics and questions we had on her patients
worked well with in intern and resident team
overall, just excellent 

Patil did an excellent job. She was an active member of the team and very engaged in rounds. She delivered a presentation on CIWA protocol to help us better understand how we could apply it. She was able to pick up cases and present them in a comprehensive and logical way later on the same day, which I found very impressive. Overall her patient presentations were very well structured and well delivered. Her patients felt well connected to her and that she was the face of our team. She was a hard worker and contributed a great deal to our team. She was a pleasure to work with on rounds. 

Feedback was given to improve communications with others as during her presentations she often lacked clarity and confidence despite her knowing the intricacies of her patient. She had a good attitude and was a hard worker. 
Her quiet demeanor unfortunately made it easy for her to be lost in the crowd. 

excellent student!
Excellent fund of knowledge.
Very good presentations
Very good clinical skills for their level 
Excellent professionalism and team work

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Professionalism
label: 4

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Fund of Knowledge: Appropriate to his level of training.
Patient Care Skills: Excellent - I think its fair to assume that most if not all medical students care about their patients, but with Vincent there was never any doubt. he would always spend extra time explaining medications or procedures to the patients and I noticed his ability to deploy therapeutic touch with great effect.
Presentations: Excellent, Vincent had a knack for delivering the most relevant information, the signal, and filtering out a lot of the noise which is beyond his level of training. 
Communication Skills: One memory sticks out to me - Vincent and I were down in the emergency department with a patient with Afib w/ RVR who was agitated trying to leave AMA. While I was trying to get the patient to stay, Vincent very subtly collected a concise history and physical on the patient. I thought that situation awareness and calm under pressure stood out to be as excellent.
Professionalism: Never an issue.
Teamwork: Vincent was always willing to give me or our attending a hand with his excellent control of Spanish which I certainly appreciated.
Teaching: Vincent was always eager to share any knowledge that he had 

I worked with Vincent Crabbe. Vincent was an excellent student to have on the service. His presentations were always thorough and accurate. He had a good relationship with his patients and their families. Most of his patients thought of him as their primary medical provider during their hospitalization. He was always enthusiastic about helping out. He asks good questions and has an excellent fund of knowledge. 

Fund of knowledge Vincent carried appropriate knowledge for his level of training, and was very curious and motivated to improve this fund. Very self-directed, reading independently and asking insightful questions. 
Patient care skills: Vincent did well with his thorough histories and physicals. He approached the expert level of collecting and reporting his findings on exam and laboratory values. More than that, he was eager to provide patient care at the bedside with impressive enthusiasm and rigor. 
Presentations: Through the rotation, he progressed nicely from leaning on his notes early to presenting a clinical course and story from memory. Very well done.  
Communication skills: Vincent was very focused on communication, always asking for clarification when confused, speaking to team members with respect, and employing empathy and sympathy consistently. 
Professionalism Always demonstrated professionalism, worked hard to improve himself by asking for and implementing feedback. He did not struggle to move his clinical skills forward by working and reading on his own. 
Teaching: Often shared his readings and findings from patient-level research with the whole team. 

I did not work directly with Vincent and so cannot give very specific feedback on him. I can say, however, that he always gave very clear, concise patient presentations and spoke confidently and knowledgeably about the care plan. Friendly and professional. 

Vincent was a huge asset to our team. He proactively contacted patients' outpatient doctors and pharmacy for collateral. He was always eager to learn and asked questions on his patients as well as on other teams' patients. He developed great repertoire with the patients and their families. Even after I left the service, I could trust Vincent to help with a discharge of one of my patients. 

Vincent deserves a great deal of praise for the maturity and initiative that he brings to the hospital each and every day. When interviewing his patients, Vincent is thorough - asking all the pertinent questions related to the patient's presentation as well as obtaining the background information about the patient's social and family history. More impressively, he manages to gather the necessary information in a time-efficient manner while also developing patient rapport. His questions about the patient's medical condition are often interspersed with comments about Vincent and the patient's shared interests or experiences, and this skill helps the patients to open up to him and trust him. When on rounds, Vincent shows an interest in learning about the medical decisions for all of the patients on the lists. His questions demonstrate that he has a grasp of basic cardiology knowledge and is thinking one step further, synthesizing what he already knows and asking questions beyond the scope of a medical student. In paying close attention to all of the patients on rounds, Vincent - without being prompted - will make his own to-do list that he accomplishes during the day. I have often been astounded when Vincent approaches the team and provides a detailed list of the appointments he has scheduled, the medical records he has obtained from outside hospitals, and the PCPs and pharmacies that he has contacted. He does all of this without being asked and for patients that he is not even responsible for! Because of Vincent, the intern had less tasks, the outlook of the team was more optimistic, and our days were pleasant. He will be an excellent physician in whatever field he chooses to pursue. 

ATTENDINGS

Vincent was good. I think I heard him present one case. He was always there and followed his patients closely. Fund of knowledge was appropriate for his level. His chart notes were good. 

I never heard Vincent present an initial case and only heard 1 or 2 followup presentations, so my observation was too limited to really comment. He did seem very professional and the very brief interactions revealed a student with strong medical knowledge. He seemed quite interested in the cases. 

Fund of knowledge Vincent's fund of knowledge was at a level expected of his level of training. During team teaching rounds, he would always ask questions about things he didn't know as well as attempt to understand them. In addition, after his time on service was up and he left for another service, when given opportunity to learn and see an autopsy of a patient he was taking care he did not hesitate to go to the autopsy and partake of the learning experience.
Patient care skills: Vincent's patient care skills were outstanding. He would take ownership of the patient's and be involved with the discussion making. He would be willing to make recommendation on how we should proceed with the patient's care. You could tell from his interactions with the patients that they trust him.
Presentations: Vincents presentations were as expected from someone with his level of training. He has very detailed H and P's. He would attempt present from memory and minimally refer to the admission note.  
Communication skills: Vincent communication skills were outstanding between himself and the team as well as the patients.
Professionalism Vincent was never late to rounds and was always willing to stay late if it was necessary. He treated every patient with respect and kindness and they all trusted him.
Team work: Vincent was an invaluable member of the team. He would be willing to get blood to the lab in cases of emergencies and to help with patient admissions and gathering a complete history. Furthermore, his proficiency in Spanish was an assets when communicating with some patients.
Teaching: In my feedback session with Vincent I told him that going forward he should perform more presentations to the team about topics that interest him regarding his patients. This will maximize his learning. 

Feedback was given. He was an advocate for his patients and team remarked how he was eager to help the team irregardless of whether it was for his own patients. He wanted to help his team get things done. He was inquisitive and went above and beyond for his patients. He gave a presentation on renal artery stenosis. 
Area of improvement was to incorporate more evidence based medicine into his presentations. 

excellent student!
Excellent fund of knowledge.
Very good presentations
Very good clinical skills for their level 
Excellent professionalism and team work

question: Presentation skills: new patient and follow up
label: 3

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Professionalism
label: 4

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

I worked with Lavender Brown on GM1. I thought she had an exceptionally professional demeanor beyond that of many medical students at her level of training; she was self-motivated, interested, engaged, sought feedback and was very invested in the care of her patients. She formed wonderful therapeutic alliances with her patients & their families and was enthusiastic about any tasks related to patient care which consistently helped out the team. Her presentations were well organized, detailed and appropriate for her level of training and I would encourage her to continue seeking out feedback as she has been doing to allow them to continue to improve. She was extremely pleasant to work with, an important member of our team and will be a wonderful asset to whichever speciality she chooses to go into. 

Overall, Lavender was an awesome medical student! Her greatest attribute was her poise during presentations. She was able to take complex patient's and present them in an organized and succinct manner. When it came to the assessment, she was able to prioritize patient's by their most active and important problems, and present a logical and practical plan. She was an asset to the team off of rounds as well. She was quite reliable in retrieving distant past medical history that was pertinent to patients presenting illness. Moreover, she maintained a great attitude throughout the rotation. Lavender was a pleasure to work with. 

Lavender Brown- was part of my ID team for a few days. She was very personable, kind, thoughtful. She had a strong command of clinical medicine; her knowledge base was above average for her training level. She gave an excellent presentation of a fairly complex patient. She knew the patient very well and knew relevant medicine to discuss a broad differential and plan of action for the patient. She was professional and worked very well within our team. Solid work.  

Lavender is a bright, hard-working medical student. She was always looking up information and studies on her own, was thoughtful in her approach to working up new patients, and clearly knew every important part of their history and clinical information. She was a great team-player. 


ATTENDINGS

Lavender was with us for about 10 days.  She did a fine job on GM-1.  She seemed knowledgable and well organized, presented well (trying not to read verbatim from her notes), and when questioned at the bedside about her cases and others was able to respond with knowledge and good sense.  She seemed to be enjoying herself, and I think will blossom during the rest of her stay on Medicine. 

Lavender was on our service for two weeks. She made two presentations, both of which were well prepared, organized, and clear.  The presentations were not from memory. She contributed on rounds, knew her patients well, provided succinct updates, and demonstrated maturity, professionalism, and motivation in her interactions with patients and other members of the care team. Her fund of knowledge was appropriate for an MCY student. When asked to look into specific topics, she responded the next day with a clear and well organized update. She was enthusiastic, positive, and engaged. It was a pleasure to have her on the service. 

I only worked with Lavender for about a week or so. During this time she presented twice. Her presentations were good but she seemed somewhat hesitant in her presentation, but she was aware of the issues the patients had. I also saw that she was active on the service and during the general "roll call" of all the patients she seemed to know what was going on and for her patients she was pretty much on top of things. I could not tell the level of her fund of knowledge due to the limited time we spent together. 

Lavender presented mainly from memory with only some assistance from her notes. Overall was confident during her HPI, but needs to work on broadening her differential diagnoses. Her medical knowledge is at what I would expect for her level and she occasionally answered questions during rounds. She did a good job with her follow-up presentations, they were concise and relevant. Many times our teams split for follow-ups, so I didn't see her present that often. 

Fund of knowledge Very good fund of knowledge and was clearly interested in learning and integrating new information.
Patient care skills: Histories were always thorough and trustworthy. Never missed any relevant physical exam findings.
Presentations: Lavender really excelled at patient presentations. She was thorough without going into excessive detail. The assessments and plans were on the level of what we often see from interns. Really outstanding.
Communication skills: She communicated very effectively with staff and with patients. She has a quiet calm about her that I think the patients appreciate and find comforting. This forms the basis of a really outstanding bedside manner.
Professionalism Clearly extremely mature and professional. She worked well within the team structure. Clearly understood her role in patient care as a learner and member of the team.
Team work: Again, she is a consummate team player and worked well with everyone. In terms of maturity/professionalism, etc. she is one of the best students that I have ever worked with.
Teaching: As above, she didn't speak much on rounds at first, but as she got more comfortable with the flow of the service, was highly effective at teaching what she knew. 
I know that she is deciding between surgery and medicine. I think she has all of the tools to be highly successful at either and she is the type of person we should recruit to stay here for residency.  

Fund of knowledge: Outstanding fund of knowledge and a well-developed ability to apply it to complex clinical presentations.  
Patient care skills: A thoughtful, disciplined provider who in a quiet way was quite impressive with regard to the outstanding overall care she provided. Kind to patients, appropriately forceful when advocating on their behalf, careful to leave no issue unresolved in her effort to advance patient care.
Presentations: Always well-constructed, thorough, and delivered in an efficient and clear fLavenderion. 
Communication skills: Excellent. Able to listen as well as convey ideas/concerns with a minimum of extraneous flourishes. I enjoyed listening to her express her ideas with an efficiency that was appreciated, especially on particularly busy days.
Professionalism: Top-notch. Lavender clearly approaches both her education and clinical duties with a profound respect for patients, peers, and overall clinical process. 
Team work: Superb. A highly valued member of the team who made significant contributions in both direct clinical care and during rounds.
Teaching: A thoughtful contributor on rounds who I suspect was capable of adding additional insights but was finding her feet with regard to when she thought her contributions might be valuable. I would encourage her to trust her instincts and contribute more often as I often found her insights to be particularly valuable.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Fund of knowledge: Oliver had a very impressive fund of knowledge and demonstrated this through his presentations, notes, and thorough understanding of his patients and pathophysiology pertinent to their disease processes. He had great curiosity and continued to build on his knowledgebase by continuing to read broadly and refer to pertinent literature. 
Patient care skills: Oliver was well liked by his patients and demonstrated excellent empathy and care for them. He was viewed by many as one of the primary caregivers, and his patients appeared to greatly trust his ability to help and care for them. His ability to collect and analyze information was superb, and he continued to strengthen his skills in physical diagnosis and examination. 
Presentations: Presentations on rounds continued to improve throughout the course of the rotation. By the end of the rotation, Oliver presented largely from memory. 
Communication skills: His communication skills were excellent, whether with primary team, consultants, or multidisciplinary staff. 
Professionalism: Oliver demonstrated great professionalism throughout the rotation. 
Team work: Oliver was a superb team player and was always willing to help. He grew to be an integral part of the group, and helped the team manage a busy workload.  
Teaching: He readily brought literature to the team's attention, and was eager to research and teach regarding the pathophysiology behind processes pertinent to his patients.  

I had the pleasure of working with Oliver Wood on the Gen Med 1 service. I think he was one of the strongest students that I have worked with this year and I want to give him a superior endorsement. His fund of knowledge was superior. Oliver proved early on that his understanding of pathophysiology was more on par with that of an early intern than of his peer medical students. His differential diagnoses were broad but also reasonable. In his workup of patients, I was particularly impressed by his thoroughness. When his patient had 10 different problems to address, he did not push aside the 1-2 problems he did not understand. Instead, he brought them to the attention of the team and tried to explain them using research and reading he had done on his own time. I was particularly impressed by his exploration of macrocytic anemia which he presented on rounds without having to be asking to present. It was a thorough and thoughtful presentation which did actually contribute to the care of his patient who had an unexplained macrocytosis. Olivers' strong fund of knowledge also meant that he was able to carry more patients than his peers. There was a day where I as the intern had to leave town and a different intern was covering for me, and Oliver used this as an opportunity to show that he could cover more than half of our service that morning on rounds. The covering intern told me after the fact that she was very impressed and found his contributions helpful. Oliver was a strong team player and enthusiastic contributor to patient care. His patients often said they felt most comfortable with him and he went out of his way to spend more time with them. At the start of the rotation, Oliver's presentations were strong but required more precision. He was given feedback about how to be less verbose and more direct with his speaking and he incorporated this feedback with enthusiasm, improving his presentation skills immensely by the end of the rotation. He also asked for feedback on multiple occasions and was always receptive and responsive to thoughts for improvement (although they were very few!). He will make an exceptionally compassionate and intelligent doctor, and I hope he considers internal medicine because I know he would thrive. 

Oliver presented very well and knew his patients inside and out. Even when he was following about half the team's list by the end of the rotation, his knowledge of each patient was very thorough. He was definitely operating at a sub-I level. 

Oliver was an excellent student who was easy to work with and clearly has a superior fund of knowledge. He was good at anticipating what work he could help with and going the extra mile when needed, for example to type up records so that they would be permanent in the chart after obtaining the paperwork himself. His presentations were from memory and thorough. He was however a bit too focused on learning how to be an intern and still has a long way to go in terms of learning to pick out important details and evaluate the big picture. He also did not seem to like being corrected or being taught something new (whether it was a concept, skill or about medication) particularly from the residents, insisting that he already knew the answers. I think this could be corrected with a bit more humility and communication with his team members about the patients before rounds. I did not see him teach directly but saw his handout which was excellent. Overall, a very advanced student. 

Oliver is definitely knowledgeable beyond his years as a medical student. He has a great understanding of his patients and their active issues. Oliver is incredibly inquisitive, while I feel that this is an excellent quality to have as a medical student, I caution him that his questions can at times feel challenging. It is important to understand his place as the medical student on the team, and while he should always ask questions, be curious and thoughtful (and he was), I want to make him aware of this for the future. He delivered two excellent presentations throughout my time with him, followed very complex patients, and helped lighten my work as a resident. He was great to work with.  


ATTENDINGS

Oliver was punctual, pleasant, excellent team mate and very professional.
He has a very good fund of knowledge and demonstrated intellectual curiosity.
He has good patient care skills, knew his patients well, and connected well with them too.
His presentations were clear, accurate, succinct, with an effort to do them from memory.  
His communication skills with the patient and the team were outstanding. I was not able to appreciate his communications with other providers (consultants or PCP).
Oliver did one presentation on macrocytic anemia to the entire team. He had done his homework and felt confident.  

Oliver was excellent. He had a strong voice on rounds and practically ran his whole service. He presented new and follow up patients extremely well. He responded well to feedback. I was impressed with the relationships it seemed he was able to easily form with his patients. He was instrumental in helping to advance care for one difficult/delirious patient in particular-- speaking with Oliver seemed to put the patient at ease which allowed us to perform necessary diagnostics and therapies which were necessary to stabilize the patient. He was energetic and enthusiastic on rounds and helped educate our team by delivering various short topic presentations. He was a pleasure to work with. 

Fund of knowledge - Oliver is well equipped with medical knowledge, and was able to apply it to the management. 
Patient care skills - Excellent care. Liked by his patients. 
Presentations - Improved rapidly and steadily throughout the rotation. Presented now with confidence and logic. 
Communication skills - Good listener and speaks clearly and well. 
Professionalism - Showed a high level of motivation in learning. Reliable in his work. 
Team work - Excellent team player. 
Teaching - Gave two updated and very informative mini-lectures.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Gregory was described by members of the house staff as "one of the best medical students I have ever worked with" and as "one of the top 5% of medical students". Similarly, he was an absolute pleasure to have in my preceptorship group. Gregory is a kind and conscientious medical student who is committed to self-improvement and to patient care.  He regularly requests feedback and is dedicated in his efforts to incorporate it into all that he does in real time. His fund of knowledge is excellent.  He is proactive in his learning and was commended for actively sharing his knowledge with his team in the form of summaries of clinically relevant studies or short presentations on pertinent topics. While Gregory is very knowledgeable he sometimes holds back. When I asked why he doesn't always speak up he stated he wanted to give everyone an opportunity to answer questions. His response speaks to his thoughtfulness, which is visible both in how he relates to his classmates and team members and in how he related to his patients and their families. His considerate disposition, enthusiasm, and willingness to help forward patient care made him a  strong asset to the medical team and a pleasure to work with.  Gregory took ownership of his patients and took the time to cultivate relationships with each of them. He was routinely regarded as their primary contact person on the team. One of his attendings noted that she "was quite impressed in frequently and regularly seeing him sitting at the bedside of his patients at various times of the day rather than glued to a hospital computer. He visited patients and family even when not necessary and spent time getting to know them, helping them understand their hospital course and offering comfort in difficult situations. This level caring and compassion set him apart not only from other students but from the residents as well."  His commitment to his patients was also illustrated by his profound attention to detail. His histories were unbelievably comprehensive giving one the sense that there was not a single detail about the patients medical history that Gregory did not know. Additionally, Gregory was a clear advocate of this patients and always put their needs first. One of his residents noted that Gregory was attempting to make a follow up appointment for a patient, but was unable to get through to the physician's office. Instead of giving up, Gregory went to the physician's office himself and spoke directly with the secretary to schedule the appointment. Gregorys physical exam skill were also quite good and appropriately comprehensive. His write-up were always thorough, albeit occasionally too detailed. However, he was diligent in his efforts to be more concise and demonstrated steady improvement in this area. His assessment demonstrated strong clinical reasoning skills and the effective use of the literature and his plans were comprehensive, reflecting an understanding of the details of clinical management that exceeded his level of training. His presentations were effectively communicated and easy to follow and as his confidence grows that will undoubtedly continue to improve.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

I am writing to evaluate Gregory Goyle on the Oncology service. Pat was one of the best medical students I have had the pleasure of working with. In every facet, Pat was excellent. Starting with his fund of knowledge, Pat was totally on top of his game. In one instance, a patient had new AFib right prior to his AM presentation. He took this new information in stride and quickly formulated an accurate and efficient plan for his patient. He showed great ownership of his patients. He knew the most information about his patients, had this information ready at a moment's notice. I had the opportunity to see him speak and interact with several patients. He demonstrated excellent bed side manner, and was always putting his patient's needs first. His presentations were excellent as well. We worked on building his confidence with his presentations and cutting out the extraneous information, and he responded to feedback excellently. He was always putting the team's needs first. In one instance, he was attempting to make a follow up appointment for a patient, but was unable to get through to the physician's office. Instead of giving up, Pat went to the physician's office himself and spoke directly with the secretary to schedule the appointment. He was constantly showing this ability to go above and beyond. Finally, Pat was frequently participating in learning and would use this information to teach the team about subjects related to his patients. Pat was in the top 5% of medical students I have worked with and has a bright future in whatever field he chooses. 

Gregory is one of the best medical students I have ever worked with. Gregory is extremely intelligent and curious and has an excellent hold on the pathophysiology behind the medical problems his patients had. On his own accord, Gregory would bring in articles to share with the team, which proved to be highly informative and relevant, and even further demonstrated his intellectual curiosity and dedication towards learning. He is very proactive and reliable. His presentations were excellent. He was always clear, accurate and succinct and I enjoyed hearing him present each morning.  Not only is Gregory strong in his knowledge and presentations, but he also is highly dedicated to his patients and established amazing rapport with them. In particular, he formed a bond with a patient that could only be formed by someone who truly is dedicated to their patients, and I could tell the patient was more at ease when Gregory was around. Overall, Gregory performed at the level even greater than a subI, and he will be successful in any speciality he chooses and his colleagues will be lucky to have him as part of their team. 

Fund of knowledge:
I was impressed by Gregory's strong fund of knowledge as well as his curiosity. When new questions came up, Gregory with frequently seek out the answers in the literature and other resources to share with the team. 
Patient care skills / Presentations / Communication skills: 
I could rely on Gregory to accurately and insightfully report on his patients' conditions and concerns throughout the day, and it was clear that they relied on him as their main point person on the team. Gregory's presentations on were frequently from memory and polished. His notes, in particular his admission notes, were thorough, detailed, and insightful. He was able to focus on the active problems at hand while discussing a broad and thoughtful differential when asked further. Further, Gregory effectively communicated disposition plans for his patients on multi-disciplinary rounds and the plan with nurses/therapists/team members during the day.
Professionalism:
Gregory was proactive and asked for feedback several times through his rotation. He quickly adapted and integrated the feedback in real time.  
Team work: 
Gregory was a strong asset to our medical team. Even as a med student early in his third year, he demonstrated a keen understanding of the structure of the team and the flow of the day, and he was very willing to contribute in whatever way would move forward patient care, from obtaining outside collateral to reviewing discharge instructions with a patient. Lastly, he maintained a genuine and cheerful attitude that made him a joy to teach and work with.
Teaching: 
Gregory led several very helpful teaching sessions, including a helpful overview of pulmonary hypertension. 
Overall, it was a pleasure to have Gregory on our team, and I hope he chooses internal medicine for residency! 


Gregory was a kind, thoughtful medical student on my sister team, who was clearly very dedicated and helpful.

ATTENDINGS

Gregory is extremely kind, sincere, and thoughtful.  He carried several patients with complex physiology and demonstrated an excellent understanding of their key issues.  Gregory is on top of all details, and communicates very clearly.  His case presentations were informative and demonstrated comprehensiveness and thoughtfulness. He worked well and easily integrated into the team. He was curious about learning and asked good questions. He was asked to research a couple of topics, and his presentations were tailored to our questions and needs.  He is professional and worked well with our entire multiD team. 
My feedback to Gregory is to keep working on making his day to day presentation more concise. Gregory is self aware and already knew this is an area to keep working on. 

I worked most closely with Gregory Goyle. He was an outstanding student and worked hard to continually improve during the rotation. He asked for feedback, made himself an integral part of the team and helped the team function smoothly. Several times each week he would share a relevant study or discuss disease pathogenesis and management pertinent to his patients. Patient presentations were thorough, all pertinent information was given and assessment and plan were well thought out and organized. There could be a tiny bit of room for improvement in making his presentations more fluent and polished but I am certain that this will come together as he matures. I was quite impressed in frequently and regularly seeing him sitting at the bedside of his patients at various times of the day rather than glued to a hospital computer. He visited patients and family even when not necessary and spent time getting to know them, helping them understand their hospital course and offering comfort in difficult situations. This level caring and compassion set him apart not only from other students but from the residents as well. 

Gregory: During my 2 weeks on-service, Pat presented 3-4 new admissions and consistently presented 2-3 follow-ups per day. His presentations were clear and concise with an appropriate amount of detail. He has an excellent fund of knowledge. Very professional and a good team player. He would frequently present articles relevant to his cases.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Viktor is one of the most outstanding medical students I've had the privilege to work with. He is first and foremost a kind-souled person who genuinely cared about the physical and emotional well-being of patients. He always spent extra time talking with his patients to make sure that their questions were addressed and they were kept in the loop about their treatment course. When interviewing patients he was thorough, systematic and efficient. He took the time to uncover relevant information that otherwise can get missed in the daily hustle and bustle of the residents. I was especially impressed that he took the initiative to check in on patients after they were discharged to make sure they were doing ok and had good transitions to care outside the hospital. Viktor is very polite and modest, yet he has an excellent fund of knowledge. He works beautifully with his peers, the other residents and other members of the care team. He also sought out feedback and was able to improve a lot (though he's already great to start with). 

Viktor was on the other team, so I didn't work as closely with him. However I found his presentations very clear and thoughtful, and he worked well with his team. 

Viktor: Dedicated, thoughtful, very attentive to details.  He was friendly, easy to get along with, and enjoyed learning.  He contributed during rounds in a meaningful way, and was always ready to help out with floor tasks.  He took great care of his patients and didn't miss any details.  Almost better than the intern!  He'll do well in whatever field he chooses, and I'm confident he will grow into a fine physician.  

I had limited interaction with Viktor since he was on the sister team, but his presentations were clear and concise and seems to know his patients very well. 

-Did multiple (at least 3 that I can recall) brief presentations on rounds, showing initiative each time in coming up with topics pertinent to our patients. Appreciated that, rather than choosing broad, generic topics, he focused on specific questions important to our patients' care - for example, we were struggling with the question of how long to anticoagulate a patient with Impella-induced clot - he did a thorough search of relevant literature and case reports.
-Demonstrated outstanding curiosity and was a highly motivated, enthusiastic team player
-Worked very hard on his presentations and it showed; did a great job incorporating resident feedback to give well-organized, thorough admission presentations on rounds. Our attending commented after one of his presentations "it makes my job easy when the presentations are like that...it would be great if all the resident presentations were done the same" - speaking specifically to his polished , organized, efficient presentation style
-Took initiative to  help the team get the work done - called patients/family/outside hospital often before being asked to do so; did a great job communicating with nurses/staff/consultants
-In terms of history taking and physical, in the top quarter of his peers; great job, went the "extra mile" (e.g. getting detailed social hx, doing MMSE, orthostatics) 
-Great patient rapport - knew his patients very well and demonstrated compassion - well liked by team members, patients and staff. 

Viktor was on the sister team. 
He gave well organized and thoughtful presentations that were at the level of an intern. 

Having Viktor as a medical student on cardiology was one of the greatest gifts I could have imagined in my first two weeks of residency. He truly was a team member who contributed to excellent patient care, improved length of patient stay outcomes by facilitating discharges with us, and was an outstanding advocate for his patients. In what could have been a very tenuous time for patient care given transitions of roles at this time of year, he was of invaluable assistance in keeping the team moving forward.
In terms of fund of knowledge and curiosity, Viktor was diligent in reading about his patients, keeping abreast of current clinical knowledge and also, especially towards the end of his weeks with us, offering suggestions for management. He was constantly asking questions, taking initiative to really understand underlying pathophysiology, and often enlightening the team in cases of more esoteric medical presentations. He stood up well to rigorous questioning from none other than the director of the Internal Medicine program.
In terms of patient care skills, this was one of the areas where I watched Viktor improve over time. As his intern, I watched him pre round with me every day, and saw him begin to be able to synthesize information and exam findings into a clinical picture (I.e. Assessing volume status and using that to create a plan). And most of all, I watched him create outstanding patient relationships and blossom in confidence and competence in them, most notably with a pregnant patient who above all, needed an advocate; and again with a young man with new onset heart failure. In the second case, he was the one who began the motivational interviewing process to understand the management of his new chronic disease as well as the one to break bad news to him. 
Viktor's presentations, as the block went on, became increasingly confident and relevant, especially in the extremely difficult setting of advanced heart failure rounds. By the end, he was appropriately reporting his HPI and Assessment/Plans from memory. 
Viktor was an outstanding and trusted communicator- myself and the senior resident often trusted him to return pages, communicate with consults, and lead patient discharge discussions, for example. I can say with full confidence that I would not trust many students to do this. 
Overall, working with Viktor was a joy. He was consistently present, excited to learn, involved with his patient's care, a trusted member of the team, and came in every day with a positive attitude. He made what could have been an extremely stressful first two weeks of intern year much less stressful. I'm excited to see him grow, gain confidence, and hopefully join us here as a medicine resident one day soon.  

Viktor is an extraordinary student and future physician. Several days after he has been off service, his patients are still asking about him and his team is still talking about what an outstanding job he did during his medicine rotation. Viktor takes ownership of his patients and his patients see him as their care provider. He worked tirelessly throughout the month to know everything about his patients and contribute meaningful to their care. He thought critically about their medical problems and took every opportunity to learn. He was such a joy to work with as a team member everyday: he was always prepared, conscientious, and upbeat. He not only helped take care of the patients he was following but was actively involved with all of the patients and eager to help in any way he could. He often did things we out even being asked and anticipated next steps in patient care. His presentations were excellent and demonstrated his understanding about all of the active issues for his patients. Viktor will thrive in whatever field he chooses to pursue and I hope he goes into medicine.  

ATTENDINGS

Viktor was truly an outstanding medical student, among one of the best medical students I have worked with up to this time as an attending. In each presentation he gave, he never missed any pertinent detail and yet remained concise and could summarize complicated data with ease. That ability to be very thorough and yet always grasp big picture is a skill I ask even our interns or residents to grasp and he seemed to have it so early in his training. His topic presentations demonstrated his innate skills as an educator- being sure to connect teaching to patient cases and illustrating how to incorporate evidence into next steps in management. 
 
Viktor's strengths included his level of professionalism, his ability to synthesize complicated information succinctly and his ability to work well with the team. He received numerous compliments from patients and families about his empathy and professional manner. He has a strong fund of knowledge. I was particularly impressed with his curiosity and growth over the few weeks I worked with him. 

Krum:   Mature, solid fund of knowledge, eager to research topics and present appropriately, excellent patient rapport.  Worked productively with his team. Took feedback well.  Mr. Krum exceeded standards of medical knowledge, patient care, teamwork, communication on this portion of his rotation. 

Viktor Krum is the medical student who was specifically assigned to my resident team and he is truly one of the best students I have ever had the privilege of working with.  I cannot say enough good things about him, he functioned at the level of a highly functional intern. Viktor is kind, conscientious, intelligent, thoughtful, knowledgeable and a fantastic team player. He established amazing therapeutic relationships with his patients and was instrumental in providing care to them. His thirst for knowledge is admirable and he truly represents the ideal medical student.  Giving him honors really doesn't do justice to his level of competence. If there is some award at graduation for the best student on the medical service he should receive it. Hopefully we can convince him to pursue internal medicine and stay here at CUMC.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Dean: Dean is a very good MCY student. He is at an appropriate stage of learning for the year. He is eager to be helpful and be part of the team. He develops good relationships with his patients. He is improving daily and very focused contributing to patient care. He is very receptive to feedback and should continue to keep up his very good attitude. 

Dean Dean: 
Fund of knowledge: 
 - excellent knowledge base. demonstrated intellectual curiosity, would often look up literature to improve knowledge
Patient care skills:
- excellent job with history taking, able to organize information in a manner that supports assessment and plan. 
Presentations: clear, accurate, succinct, from memory  
- outstanding presentation skills. very thorough and systemic. 
Communication skills:
- excellent communication with patients. well liked by patients. 
Professionalism and attitude 
- self directed. able to organize his work day without much re-direction or reminders. 
Team work: 
- always willing to help team
Teaching:
- eager to share knowledge with the team  




ATTENDINGS

Dean Dean: 
Fund of knowledge: Dean demonstrated a very strong fund of knowledge, especially as he is still early in his clinical clerkships. He is able to apply this knowledge towards formulating a thorough assessment and plan for each relevant medical issue. 
Patient care skills: Dean performed thorough histories and physicals on new admissions and focused examinations on follow ups. He is open to feedback on his physical examination skills. He is eager to be involved in patient care and willing to help the team in any way he can. 
Presentations: Presentations were succinct and focused on rounds, and he required minimal referral to his notes. He presented in a clear and confident manner, and overall his presentations were well above average for a third year student.  
Communication skills: Superb communication skills with patients that helped him develop strong rapport. Also did an excellent job communicating with the health care team. He was definitely 'value-added' on the team. 
Professionalism: Always on time, enthusiastic to help out, actively solicited feedback from the residents. Was inquisitive during rounds but was respectful of / did not interrupt his fellow students' presentations. 
Team work: Communicated really well with the team including nurses on the floor and made every effort to be helpful to the residents without obstructing the work flow. He got along well with the other students on the team. 
Teaching: Made a fantastic oral presentation on cholangiocarcinoma, including the epidemiology, risk factors, diagnosis, and management of the disease. In addition to providing a great overview of the disease, he also summarized a couple of important publications.  

Dean Dean: Dean was actively engaged on rounds demonstrating curiosity and asking appropriate questions for all patients discussed on rounds. He also demonstrated a very good and appropriate fund of knowledge. He was extremely courteous and professional at all times. Presentations were exceptionally thorough, accurate, and detail oriented. He communicated clearly and articulated an organized H&P. However, presentations were very long and could be more concise--I could tell that Dean was working on this even without feedback as I noted he would set his watch in from to him to time himself. Additionally, presentations somewhat relied on reading notes, print outs. I did not directly observe physical exam skills. He was a positive and engaged team member. Overall, I think Dean did a great job! 

Fund of knowledge very good
Patient care skills: very good
Presentations: very good; could have been more proactive when interacting with patients during rounds - tended to defer to the residents rather than lead the interaction
Communication skills: excellent; I particularly liked that at the end of my rotation, Dean asked for us to meet to discuss any specific feedback/criticisms I had 
Professionalism excellent
Team work: not sufficient contact to assess 
Teaching: not sufficient contact to assess 

Fund of knowledge. Good fund of knowledge for his level was comfortable with our topics of discussion. 
Patient care skills: Dean actively followed a number of patients during his tenure on GenMed2, and his presentations reflected a thoughtful, careful approach to history and examination. His differentials were clear and mostly correct. His interpretation of the data reflect a strong fund of book knowledge. 
Presentations: Presentations left me in little doubt what was going on with the patient, and we as a team were confident with his care of the patient. 
Communication skills: Clear, concise, engaging with the team. 
Professionalism Very professional, no complaints from the patients. 
Team work: Worked well as a part of the team 
Teaching: Presented a topic for the group on his last day - it was well researched, thoughtfully compiled, and eloquently expressed. Well done.
