eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Luna is an excellent medical student.  She was an active participant in preceptor sessions who regularly presented cases in a skillful, engaging, and interactive format.  Her presentations reflected comprehensive knowledge about her patients and thorough understanding of the pathophysiology, differential diagnosis, and treatment of their diseases.  She also gave engaging and informative talks to the group related to her patients' illnesses.  Her write-ups progressed to outstanding with well-written, thorough histories of present illness, very good descriptions of physical examinations, and excellent formulations and differential diagnoses, reflecting careful literature review and excellent understanding of her patients' illnesses and proposed treatment plans.  Her observed history and physical examination was performed very well.  Her interviewing was careful and thorough.  She treated the patient with respect and developed excellent rapport during the interview.  Her physical examination skills were performed very well.  She was a pleasure to teach.  She was always enthusiastic and engaged in the clerkship.  She was always willing to be first for presentations and for the observed history and physical.  She will become an excellent physician, and she will be an asset to any residency program.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: When interviewing a patient for medical history, remember to elicit pertinent details of all major medical issues mentioned by the patient.  Try to avoid using medical jargon when speaking to patients.  Try to resist offering answers to your questions if the patient hesitates to answer.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Luna is a wonderful medical student. I was very impressed with her fund of knowledge and level of investment in her patients' care. She presented clearly and concisely, and was able to summarize and synthesize very complex information (including several particularly complicated ICU transfers with multiple medical and surgical comorbidities). She displayed excellent clinical reasoning skills, and was tremendously helpful to me on the floors, taking the initiative time and again to follow-through with nurses to make sure things got done, to get on the phone with consultants directly, and even to challenge the team's thinking and ask for rationalization for a given management decision, which is really above and beyond what is expected of a medical student!  

Luna (Luna) exhibited a vast fund of knowledge that she applied very meticulously during her clinical encounters on the infectious disease service. She was motivated to see patients on her own and was always willing to go beyond to help the team. She actively sought feedback. Her presentations were clear, accurate and concise while her notes were also very thorough.  

I had the pleasure of having Luna  on my team during her Medicine rotation. I would consider Luna to be one of the best medical students I have worked with. Luna has both a strong fund of clinical knowledge as well as a high level of intellectual curiosity which kept her engaged during our Medicine rounds. Besides carrying her own 3 patients, Luna followed along with the courses of all the other patients on the team and was eager to engage in PM bedside rounds on the other patients. As a medical student, Luna exceeded the responsibilities that were required of her. Early on, she assumed full ownership of all of her patients and began placing lab/imaging orders, repleting patients' electrolytes, calling consults, making appointments, and writing discharge summaries. In terms of her notes and presentations, her HPIs were very organized and succinct, her physical exams were detailed but focused, and her assessments and plans were well thought out. She gave two excellent presentations during her rotation (one on pancreatitis and the other on cholangitis/choledocholithiasis) which both provided the residents an appropriate level of learning. Lastly, Luna is very easy to get along with and a team player. She worked well with the housestaff and did an excellent job of communicating with the nurses to ensure that her patients would be taken care of. We came to think of her as an integral part of our team. Additionally, patients often commented that she was nice/sweet/pleasant and that she was able to clearly explain to them their medical conditions and plans of care. Luna will do well in any specialty she chooses, and any specialty would be lucky to have her.

Presentations: Luna gave very comprehensive and accurate presentations, clearly demonstrating she had spent significant time learning about her patients and performing comprehensive histories and physicals. She can still work on making her presentations a little more concise and organized, highlighting some of the more relevant elements and leaving out those elements that are somewhat superfluous.
Professionalism: Luna was positive and really a pleasure to work with.
Team work: Luna was a great team member, and was very helpful with her own patients as well as those she wasn't even following directly.
Teaching: Luna gave us a great presentation on pancreatitis, that nicely summarized her own patient's presentation while also giving a really great outline of the differential diagnosis and basic management principles of pancreatitis. 

Luna:
Fund of knowledge  excellent
Patient care skills:  very good, great rapport with patients
Presentations: clear, accurate, succinct, from memory  
Communication skills: excellent
Professionalism and attitude excellent
Team work: great team player
Teaching: great skills in sharing knowledge with the team and fellow students 

Luna was a pleasure to work with and a very strong, dedicated medical student. She demonstrated a strong grasp of medical knowledge and curiosity to learn about her patients' medical conditions, including preparing and leading short presentations for the team. She was very hardworking and took the initiative to complete workday tasks and participate in the medical care of her patients. Her presentations were notably concise, well-organized, and well prepared. She also demonstrated an impressive level of empathy and maturity when dealing with her patients. Overall, she operated at intern-level and was a very integral member of our team. It would be my pleasure to work with her again. 

ATTENDINGS

Luna did an excellent job on her rotation with the ID service. I was impressed with Luna's ability to get "the big picture" when presenting her patients from memory while still having command of details when asked. She was quite efficient in her presentations and contributed greatly to rounds. 

Fund of knowledge: Very strong. Luna demonstrated good basic skills in general medicine and a strong motivation to expand her knowledge of infectious diseases.
Patient care skills: Luna excelled in this area. In addition to meticulous history and exam-taking, she took the time to collect history from a broad range of sources, including the PMD, family, and outside hospital records, which she succinctly summarized and integrated into her presentations.
Presentations: Presentations were great and her assessments demonstrated a clear thought process. Would encourage her to work on making her presentations more concise as she is doing.  
Communication skills: Luna connected very well with her patients and communicated well with the team. She has a rather quiet demeanor but asserted herself effectively particularly as she became more comfortable during the rotation; I would encourage her to continue to do this!
Professionalism: Luna was a pleasure to work with and demonstrated a strong sense of professionalism and humility. She was highly respectful of patients and staff and had a great disposition on rounds.
Team work: Great team player. She did tons of leg work to help advance the care of her patients.
Teaching: Also showed evidence of researching relevant topics for her case presentations. I would encourage her to continue to expand her knowledge base and share what she has learned with the team. 

Luna stands out in terms of her ability to succinctly and accurately evaluate and formulate cases.  She has an excellent fund of knowledge and a terrific ability to present the key features of in a most careful and succinct manner without sacrificing the most important and relevant case features.  She consistently identified history and physical findings that others on the team may have overlooked, and showed an advanced understanding of their relevance. Such skills are certainly beyond her current level of training.  She demonstrated terrific team collaboration.  Luna seems tireless in her pursuit of excellence and based on my experience, will make an outstanding resident and attending physician. 

Fund of knowledge Good fund of knowledge for her level of training. 
Patient care skills: Provided very good follow up for her patients. 
Presentations: As above, the one presentation I did hear her give was excellent, the case was very complex and she managed to summarize the details and the overview very well. 
Professionalism and attitude: She is poised and confident. She has a somewhat informal manner 
Team work She was very eager to help the team, made every effort to make sure results were followed up. On one occasion a patient's clinical care was dependent on pathology results, she spoke daily with the pathologist and made it such that a clinical decision was arrived at in a timely fashion. 
Teaching: She gave a presentation on the various causes of hypothermia that was somewhat disorganized but ultimately helpful to the care of the patient. It was overall a good attempt given the time constraints. 

Luna was a pleasure to have on our team.  She was enthusiastic, detail-oriented, and professional.  Her daily presentations were excellent and she was very diligent in the care and follow-up of some complex patients.  She developed wonderful relationships with her patients and served as a key member of the care team.  She gave us a nice, concise presentation on a topic that was applicable to many of our patients.

question: Professionalism

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Seamus was engaged, took responsibility for our whole patient list and was a pleasure to work with. In addition to excellent presentations on the pathophysiology of pulmonary hypertension and an overview of digoxin and digoxin toxicity, Seamus was clearly invested in his patients. He spent an hour explaining the intricacies of pacemaker placement to a critically ill patient, exhibiting a kind bedside manner with an impressive ability to make complicated medical problems understandable. He will be an excellent doctor in any field but his passion of detail and physiology would make him a wonderful internal medicine physician. 

Fund of knowledge: Seamus always demonstrated a great depth of
knowledge. He had great differential diagnoses on his own patients and added to the differentials of patients that were not his own. He was able to interpret imaging and laboratory testing at a level of an intern. 
Patient care skills: Seamus expressed a desire to continuously improve his physical exam skills and was able to recognize findings quite well. He picked up subtle changes in his patients' volume status that subsequently influenced treatment plans and also picked up findings that aided in the differential diagnosis. In particular one of his patients with pulmonary hypertension that had acutely worsened, Seamus recognized the signs of right sided heart failure readily, and attempted to identify more advanced signs. 
Presenting: Seamus showed great improvement during his rotation on his presentations. They were succinct yet mentioned the most critical information when reporting progress. His admission presentations were thorough and necessarily detailed. 
Communication skills: I will not forget a particular instance when Seamus dealt with a difficult patient who was certainly in need of a pacemaker. Seamus appreciated the urgency of this therapy and was able to communicate this effectively to the patient. He went above and beyond spending over one hour with this patient, retrieving critical information about why the patient was hesitant and showed his mastery of the cultural competency required to practice medicine in New York City.
Professionalism: Seamus demonstrated superb professionalism during his rotation. He exemplified the nurturing yet objective role of the physician. He was polished in front of his patients and respectful when dealing with nursing and social work. 
Teamwork: Seamus was an advocate for his patient and functioned as an intern during interdisciplinary rounds. He provided critical information that helped his patients have a safe discharge and even interacted with insurance companies to ensure that his patient would receive the necessary medications. Truly stellar in this regard. 
Teaching: excellent, residency level teaching. Our whole team learned from
his discussions on findings on physical exam pertaining to a critically ill patient on our service. He was also an excellent teacher for the patients, taking his time to explain risks and benefits of treatment and invasive procedures.  


ATTENDINGS

Mr. Finnigan's case presentations were clear and succinct without missing relevant data. He also showed outstanding fund of knowledge. 

I primarily worked with Seamus Finnigan on the Cardiology B Service.  Seamus's fund of knowledge is excellent, and he was eager to learn more on the rotation each day.  Seamus has tremendous enthusiasm for cardiology, and he took advantage of all opportunities to learn about different areas of subspecialty, as he followed his patients to EP, cardiac cath, echo, etc.  He knew his patients very well and used pathophysiological concepts to describe the clinical manifestations of disease processes.  For example, he clearly explained the difference in WHO classification for patients with pulmonary hypertension related to systemic v. limited scleroderma.  Seamus gave an outstanding presentation on Digoxin.  His professionalism is commendable.  He earned the respect of his house staff colleagues, and he was given significant responsibility as a reliable team player.  As a team, we were very impressed by Seamus's determination and focus to achieve his career goals.  Seamus's dedication to medicine and his passion for cardiology inspired the entire team and set the tone for a fantastic month.  He was a pleasure to have on the Cardiology Service. 

Seamus did an excellent job on the General Medicine 1 rotation. I served as the attending for the "sister" team - and so did not have as much of an opportunity to observe Seamus in day to day interactions as the other attending on service and so would defer to him for a more complete evaluation-but I had the opportunity to observe and work with Seamus on rounds and during teaching sessions. He demonstrated exceptional curiosity and an eagerness to learn, and did an excellent job with 2 10 minute presentations during rounds, displaying great ability to compile and interpret relevant literature. He was very self-directed and took "ownership" over the patients that he followed, serving often as the point person in discussions with the family and with nursing staff. In patient interactions, he was tactful, thorough, and sensitive; his presentations on rounds improved thanks to his hard work and by the end of the rotation he was presenting at the sub-I level. Overall, he was a pleasure to work with and the team benefitted greatly from his enthusiasm and hard work.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments on the Observed H and P
answer_text: Seamus was very empathic, and at ease with the patient interaction. He obtained a very through social history. He noticed subtle findings on exam that helped clarify/gain additional information about the patient's PMH. His ROS and PE were very thorough, and focused on what was appropriately needed for his differential. His differential was excellent, yet through; I appreciated that he thought about other important considerations rather than just focusing on the one seemingly obvious reason for the patient's admission. We discussed summarizing more with the patient, avoiding jargon (which he mostly did), and smoking cessation counseling.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Discussed getting into deeper levels of the assessment/plan, especially other nonmedical/social factors that are affecting patient care. Also encouraged more confidence in narrowing the differential (while still including a discussion that considers other possible but less likely possibilities).

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Early on, Seamus initiated a discussion to clarify feedback regarding one of his write ups - after that his write ups improved significantly after he processed the feedback. His HPIs and discussions were more clear and organized. I appreciated his initiative and eagerness to improve. He gave didactic/teaching presentations on DKA and pulmonary hypertension which were excellent - he had a very strong grasp of the pathophysiology. He was able to explain and draw pictures on the board, with minimal notes! His love for understanding the pathophysiology as a way to figure out a patient's diagnosis is evident. Seamus is very eager and excited to learn, and is always looking to improve to be the best he can be. It is clear he is passionate about medicine and patient care. He was a pleasure to work with!

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF


Draco was an amazing medical student.   
His fund of knowledge was deep and expansive.  He regularly impressed me and my attending with his knowledge of topics and pathophys.  I began to expect him to have the answer more often than my interns.  His patient care skills were good.  He took detailed histories and physicals and took ownership over the care of his patients.  His presentation skills are truly impressive.  He is able to clearly and succinctly deliver information.  He is both complete and concise.  He contributes to getting tasks done for his patients.  He is also a good teacher giving great presentations to the team.   

Draco had a phenomenal fund of knowledge.  He was able to dissect very complex patient presentations and present them to the attending in a coherent and complete manner.   He has undoubtedly a very bright future in whichever specialty he chooses to pursue. 

While I did not work with Draco directly (he was the med student for my sister team), I was consistently impressed with his patient presentations. They were always terrifically organized, thoughtful, and confidently delivered, with appropriate and accurate interpretations of data. He is clearly a very bright, enthusiastic person with a gift for sharing information. 



ATTENDINGS


He learned a lot during the rotation. His presentations became more concise and focused on the problem at hand.  His physical exam skills also improved. He looked up pertinent information from the literature on his patients and presented it at rounds. He was very courteous and fit well into the team dynamic.  
Though I didn't work directly with Draco, he had standout presentations and was a pleasure to work with.  He had great communication skills and was very professional. 

Draco was a valuable member of the team.  He had a very strong fund of knowledge for his level of training. He was very likable and always had a great rapport with patients.  His presentations were well formulated and thorough.  As he continues to develop, he will be able to make his presentations more concise as he is able to improve his ability to identify pertinent clinical information.  Overall, he was a pleasure to have on the team.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Professionalism
label: 4

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments on the Observed H and P
answer_text: Draco performed an observed history and physical examination during our session. He was confident, professional, respectful, showed empathy, used appropriate language and was able to put his patient at ease. He achieved an important balance: truly listening to his patient and expressing his compassion, while, at the same time, very effectively directing the interview to obtain a great deal of information quite efficiently.  He was able to move from more open-ended to more specific questions and the physical examination performed was logical and organized.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Draco submitted 6 write-ups during the rotation, gave patient presentations to the preceptorial group, and presented an excellent topic summary focusing on physiology of septic shock.
Draco's written case presentations have been thoughtful and organized. He has been able to get to know each of his patients and tell their story while maintaining the structure required for a medical write-up. The sections on the History of Present Illness and Past Medical History grew in their level of organization and detail throughout the course, and the final write-ups provided comprehensive assessments in these areas.  Additionally, Draco worked hard on the format and completeness of the physical examination section, so that this section progressed to become a thorough and excellent aspect of his presentations. From the beginning of the course, Draco has had an impressive grasp of the overall picture relating to each patient's presentation. Draco developed assessment/differential diagnosis sections that were thorough and structured and detailed systematic plan sections that addressed the patients' many issues and addressed diagnosis, treatment and monitoring goals. Draco was also able to effectively utilize and interpret medical literature to delve deeper into clinical management issues.
Draco performed an observed history and physical examination during our session. He was confident, professional, respectful, showed empathy, used appropriate language and was able to put his patient at ease. He achieved an important balance: truly listening to his patient and expressing his compassion, while, at the same time, very effectively directing the interview to obtain a great deal of information quite efficiently.  He was able to move from more open-ended to more specific questions and the physical examination performed was logical and organized.
Draco's presentations in our sessions were professional, well-prepared, relevant and focused. He was able to effectively and enthusiastically convey his knowledge to teach his peers. He worked well within our group and actively contributed to group discussions.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Cedric is a very bright, highly compassionate, dedicated and hard working student whose performance was excellent in all aspects of the clerkship.  He was keenly interested in helping his patients and learning and enthusiastically investigated their diagnoses. His fund of knowledge was excellent and he worked diligently to improve this over the course of the rotation. His oral case presentations in preceptor session improved significantly over the course of the clerkship to where he could provide most of the presentation for memory. His formulations also significantly improved and were excellent by the end of the rotation. He effectively incorporated feedback and was able to make his write-up HPIs and discussions better organized and effective. On the wards he was described as incredibly motivated to take the best possible care of patients and went above and beyond on many occasions. He was highly skilled at connecting with patients and was often at the forefront of taking care of the most difficult patients. He demonstrated a maturity and outstanding understanding of patient care that was significantly above that expected of a medical student. Cedric was highly curious and engaged on rounds, bringing literature to support discussions and to contribute to the team's learning. He demonstrated an excellent understanding of pathophysiology and was able to formulate management plans for his patients. In his observed history and physical he demonstrated an expected facility with obtaining the history and performing the physical. He demonstrated excellent rapport and empathy toward the patient. He demonstrated a very professional manner and was very receptive to feedback.  It was a pleasure having Cedric in the preceptor group.

His write ups improved and were excellent in quality, reflecting clear understanding of complex history and mastery of his patients problems. I can only surmise that this reflects the fact that it is taking him time to synthesize and produce this high quality of work, and he is having some difficulty executing this in real time.  That said, he is professional and very capable and has great potential.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Katie was a wonderful med student. Very well prepared, eager to learn, gave excellent presentations (especially given time of year), and easy to get along with. We enjoyed having her on our service. 

Katie is a kind, thoughtful medical student who was a wonderful addition to our team. Her fund of knowledge is impressive, and she supplemented what she did not know immediately by doing thorough research, presenting her admissions with comprehensive differential diagnoses and convincing supporting arguments for and against each diagnosis. Her topic presentations were well-researched and included the latest literature. She was incredibly helpful to the medical team. Katie should continue to read about her patients, and can strive to take more initiative in proactively working on tasks to help the team. Overall a great job on this rotation. 

Katie (Sister Team)
Fund of knowledge Good with regards to where she is in her clinical training, definitively motivated to learn and improve his basic understanding of clinical medicine. 
Presentations: Very clear, always accurate and would preform SOAP notes from memory.  
Communication skills: Always appeared calm and cooperative when talking with patients, family members and staff.  
Professionalism Always felt she was professional and respected the health care system. 
Team work: Always a willing teammate. 
Teaching: Presentations were accurate, succinct and emphasized clinical importance 

She did a fantastic job on the ID service.  For being so early in her training, she has already accumulated an impressive amount of medical knowledge and sometimes knew more than I did on certain topics.  She was a great team player and would always do things that were needed even if it did not pertain to her specific patients.  She had an excellent bedside manner and actually helped us out dealing with some of our more difficult patients.  She will make an excellent physician.  

Katie demonstrated a high level of understanding of her patients' complex medical problems. Her presentations were well-thought out and show thoughtful history taking and physical examination skills. She was always professional and demonstrated excellent communication skills with other staff members including nurses and social workers.  

Katie was a wonderful med student. Very well prepared, eager to learn, gave excellent presentations (especially given time of year), and easy to get along with. We enjoyed having her on our service. 

Katie - Katie is a superstar. She is already functioning at the level of a Sub-I and this was her second clinical rotation. She was carrying complex patients with ease, actively taking ownership and getting tasks done to further patient care without even needing to be asked. She will make a phenomenal physician in whatever field she chooses, but I hope she considers internal medicine! 

Great presentations and great working with the team. 

ATTENDINGS

For Katie bell:
Fund of knowledge : her fund of knowledge appeared to be good.  She has very good clinical instincts.  She is very curious and diligent about doing outside reading.  
Patient care skills: As per the residents on the team, she was very involved in all aspects of the care of her patients.
Presentations: Outstanding.  she is far ahead of what would be expected for her level.  She organizes information beautifully, includes just the right amount of detail, and makes frequent eye contact with her audience rather than just reading from a paper. She includes an excellent differential diagnosis and discusses the underlying pathophysiology.  Is able to "rank" diagnoses on a scale of most to least likely and discuss why.  
Communication skills: again, outstanding.  
Professionalism: excellent, with a great attitude.
Team work: works very well with others.  
Teaching: gave 2 excellent presentations with well-referenced handouts that were very instructive to the entire team. 

Fund of knowledge: Katie had a great fund of knowledge for her level of training. She was intellectually curious, spent time synthesizing information that was given to her (papers on outcomes for acute tubular necrosis) and demonstrated a great grasp of the concepts. 
Patient care skills: Katie performed a thorough history and physical exam in my presence, and she did an excellent job collecting, reporting and synthesizing information for the team.  She also was respectful of patient needs and very kind.
Presentations: I was particularly impressed by Katie's presentation of her patients, she did an outstanding job presenting from memory, was confident and clear.
Communication skills: Katie is an outstanding communicator, and worked well with the team, consult services and the multidisciplinary staff in order to provide excellent care to our patients.
Professionalism: Katie was able to accept feedback and also sought advice on how to improve her presentations and care of patients.
Team work: Katie was an excellent team player, and worked well with the entire team. She worked with Dan and they each took turns teaching each other physical exam findings.
Teaching: Thanks to her communication skills, Katie was also a very effective teacher, and I enjoyed learning about acute tubular necrosis outcomes as well as outcomes for patients with PEG tubes.

Katie: excellent fund of knowledge, very thorough presentations, took initiative to share articles and give short presentations on issues brought up on rounds. Over the course of the rotation, grew even more confident with her presentations and honed her communication skills, taking more responsibility in interactions with consultation teams and other services. A true pleasure to work with. 

Katie bell:
Fund of knowledge: Excellent
Patient care skills: She seemed thorough and careful 
Presentations: Excellent presentations, thoughtful, thorough and well-organized, though not from memory  
Communication skills: Excellent
Professionalism Excellent
Team work: She seemed to function very well as a member of the team

Katie picked up a complicated patient and gave an excellent synthesis of the case.   Her presentations were well done and complete with a well-thought out differential.  She also gave a nice informative presentation on a topic related to one of the patients.   I thought her performance was outstanding as this was only her second clinical rotation.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Dudley was a great medical student and an important addition to our medical team. He always had an upbeat, positive attitude and was eager to help out. His topic presentations were well-researched and applicable to discussions we had on rounds. 

Dudley is great! He is incredibly engaged and helpful. He had a very broad base of medical knowledge and is always looking for opportunities to learn more and to teach the team about the things he's learned. His patients loved him and he went out of his way to take care of the little things for his patients - one of his patients was on a lot of pain meds and was having difficulty remembering things, so Dudley brought him a little notebook and pen for him to write things down, and he was so thrilled to have it. Dudley was a great addition to the team! 

Fund of knowledge: Dudley never lacked the curiosity or motivation to learn relevant internal medicine clinical knowledge. I do feel at time there could have been a better understanding of the pathophysiology, however I mostly chalk this up to not having completed Step 1.  Overall from start to finish he worked hard at improving his knowledge and definitely become more effective in doing so. 
Patient care skills: Personally I felt he preformed this task adequately. Due to the new admitting guidelines within the general ward service, we at times lacked new admission. Furthermore, due to rounds in the morning and several afternoon didactic, it was hard to assess his skills as it did not flow within the daily schedule and I did not want him to stay later than necessary.   
Presentations: Accurate and clear, at times could be more from memory and more succinct.   
Communication skills: Absolutely wonderful job, interpersonal skills are one of Dudley's strongest characteristics. I really felt he was genuine it all his interactions and his respect for everyone was contagious. 
Professionalism Wonderful attitude and always willing to go the extra mile for patient care. 
Team work: Another one of Dudley's strongest traits. He worked effortlessly within the team construct and always was willing to help both the residents as well as the fellow students. 
Teaching: Difficult to completely assess, but is presentations and handouts were on point, especially his topic review on ATN, where he digested several very complex and detailed journals. 

Dudley was an excellent medical student. He was extremely positive and engaged. He clearly was enthusiastic and worked very hard to get to know his patients well throughout the rotation. He advocated for his patients at every possible time. He clearly read throughout the rotation, working to learn more about his patients and learn about pathophysiology. I had a great experience working with him and he will be a phenomenal physician!



I worked primarily with Dudley, who is an exceptional medical student. From day 1, he asked me to set expectations and met or exceeded all of them thereafter. He was organized, comprehensive, diligent, and compassionate. He was universally and deeply liked - his patients inquired after him when he left, nurses approached me about his impeccable professionalism and communication, and our team as well as neighboring teams remarked frequently on how well he was doing. Many patients, nurses, and residents have said that Dudley is one of the best medical students they have seen.  
Dudley revealed exceptional medical knowledge, answering questions easily about his own patients as well as general oncology topics. In particular, Dudley presented a new patient with prostate cancer and had clearly done a very comprehensive review of the subject, answering questions about pathophysiology, genetics, staging, treatment, medical history/anthropology and more. When a question was finally discovered that stumped him, it turned out that no one else in the room knew the answer. Dudley told me he had set the goal of learning from his patients and he clearly did - he is more expert in the disease processes that he saw on this rotation than I am.
Dudley was an absolute joy to work with, and I hope that he considers a future in internal medicine. Any field or program will be lucky to have this exceptional student. 


ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge:  Dudley is very enthusiastic and eager, which made him a pleasure to have on the team.  I think he can continue to improve his knowledge base, specifically focusing on pathophysiology.  
Patient care skills/presentations:  Dudley is very thorough and has an excellent bedside manner.  He should continue to work on his presentation skills- specifically re: organization of information, working on not repeating himself, and making things a bit more succinct. For his assessments, he should try to "cut to the chase" a bit quicker and say what he thinks is most likely going on (and why), followed by a discussion of other items in the differential.  For one of our patients with OSA, renal failure, and volume overload, he spent quite a bit of time discussing hypercapneic respiratory failure (good) but way too much time discussing Guillain barre syndrome when this was really not applicable.  
Communication skills: excellent rapport with patients and their families.  
Professionalism: outstanding- eager to improve and receive feedback
Team work: outstanding.
Teaching:  his presentations were well-researched and he made very nice handouts. 

Fund of knowledge: I spent a great deal of time with Dudley on call. He was intellectually very curious and enjoyed and mastered the topic of hyponatremia with me.  He had a great fund of knowledge and was very comfortable with pathophysiology.
Patient care skills: I also observed Dudley perform a history and physical, and he did a great job, though required prompting from his residents.
Presentations: Dudley learned to become less detailed and more clear with his presentations. He worked with Dr. Morris to improve his style of presentation and it did improve during our 2 weeks together.
Communication skills: Dudley demonstrated excellent skill communicating with our patients, the team, consult services, and the multidisciplinary staff
Professionalism: Dudley demonstrated excellent professionalism, it was a pleasure to work with him, and patients and housestaff responded positively as well.
Team work: Dudley was an excellent team player, he worked well with Delia and they each took turns teaching each other physical exam findings.
Teaching: Dudley was able to effectively teach about the biologic aspects of acute tubular necrosis recovery, a very scientific article, and be excited about it, with our group. 

I thought Dudley was excellent. He can work on honing His presentation skills as he move forward. Dudley read up on aspects of the care of his patients that were of interest to the team and he related well to his patients.


I think he did an outstanding job on this rotation. His fund of knowledge is appropriate for his level of training. He however, he has an incredibly keen curiosity and motivation for mastery of his skills (including knowledge).  He really applied himself and worked hard during this rotation to learn about oncology and as a result I think his knowledge improved greatly throughout the rotation. His biggest strength is in regards to patient care, his H&Ps are diligent and well thought through, and he has excellent rapport with patients and their families.  He was able to present medical information in a clear manner both to the team, but most importantly to patients and their loved ones. He has a great attitude and I loved having him as part of the team.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Pansy is a wonderful medical student, with an outstanding performance all across the board.  She has a very nice demeanor with patients and team, and is very clear and intelligent in her oral and written communication.  Pansy is very disciplined and systematic in her approach to patients, and her case presentations are clinically rich as are her topic reviews. Her emotional intelligence and modesty played very well with the team. Her fund of knowledge is excellent and she was always curious and rigorous in following up; her basic and clinical reasoning is superior indeed and well reflected in her superb writing and lively discussions. Working with Pansy has been a real pleasure. She will make a fine physician and would not be surprised if she graduates with honors.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Very thoughtful, outstanding medical student.  Her presentations were at an intern level.  She attended to details, was always eager to learn, and really came into her own during this rotation.  She was professional, engaged in her patients' care, and was always asking us interesting questions on rounds.  She showed real enthusiasm for the pathophysiology of disease, and was forward-thinking in her notes.  I think her exam skills leave something to be desired, but this is expected for where she is in her training.  I was particularly struck by the level of emotional maturity and depth of feeling she had for her patients.  Overall, I would give her the highest possible grade nomination, she was certainly above the level of her peers and I am confident that whatever path she chooses she will make a truly fine physician.  It was a real pleasure to work with her.  As always...read more! 

Pansy was very bright and knowledgeable, and I was especially impressed by her presentation abilities, which were easily the best of any MCY student I've seen so far. She was collected, concise, confident, and clearly read about what was important to share with the team. She was also wise beyond her level of training in her ability to read by herself, see the patient, collect her thoughts, and then independently come to the team with her ideas.
I think in terms of areas for improvement, she should learn to trust herself in coming up with a plan. I know it's very difficult, and it's difficult as an intern still! But she is smart enough to come up with A plan that makes sense and that matters more than the exact right answer. Otherwise I think it would be prudent to be more proactive in helping with consults, etc (my fault for not encouraging this) but I think as a sub-I taking ownership of the patients and learning from consult calling, outside collateral, etc. will be key. Overall she did a great job and we're lucky to have had her on the team. 

I worked with Pansy on the cardiology service for about 2 weeks. She was very self-motivated and bright, requiring minimal direction from me to develop comprehensive assessments and plans for her patients. She was always willing to help the team accomplish the tasks of the day. During the rotation she worked to refine her cardiac physical exam skills and made steady progress. She gave an illuminating presentation on sarcoidosis, focusing on cardiac manifestations. I wish her success in whatever career path she chooses. 

Pansy Parkinson:
Fund of knowledge: Pansy asks intelligent and insightful questions, and does this for even the patients she is not following, clearly demonstrating her attention to detail and curiosity and motivation to learn as much as possible.
Patient care skills: Pansy is focused and very diligent when it comes to interviewing her patients and performing a thorough and exhaustive history and physical. Although she performs a comprehensive interview and exam, she is able to synthesize the most relevant details and pieces of information to present it in the best way.
Presentations: Pansy has FANTASTIC presentation skills - including her ability to put together a cohesive yet succinct presentation, and then in her actual delivery of the patient presentation. She is able to distill very complicated patients and hospital courses into clear and concise histories, and presents this all from memory and in a very engaging way on rounds. It is clear that she spends a substantial amount of time reviewing records and really getting to know her patients and their histories in order to deliver such thoughtful presentations.
Communication skills: Pansy is excellent when it comes to communication - she spends a significant amount of time with her patients and is dedicated to their knowledge of the plan of care and management, and also communicates effectively with the team and various consult services.

Professionalism: Pansy asks for frequent feedback and incorporates it immediately into her future performance. She also does a good job of asking for specific points of feedback, which demonstrates the insight she has into what she would like to improve upon and allows her to better incorporate it into future presentations.
Team work: Pansy was an integral part of the team! She identified things she could help with, and was proactive with getting these things done. No matter what kind of task it was that needed to be done, she was always positive and incredibly helpful, even when it was for patients she was not directly following.
Teaching: Whether it was a specific topic she was asked to present on, or was simply something she came across in her patient write-ups/presentations that she wanted to learn more about, Pansy did a great job teaching the entire team on rounds, from her fellow students to the interns and residents. 

Pansy was an excellent addition to our team. She was enthusiastic about picking up new patients and learning from their cases. She created great therapeutic relationships with patients. She helped with tasks that needed to be done for her patients everyday, showing her commitment to the team. Her fund of knowledge was strong.


ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge: excellent.  
Patient care skills: excellent 
Presentations: The presentations were organized and coherent. Excellent overall. 
Communication skills: excellent.
Professionalism: excellent
Team work: was an integral part of the team. 
Teaching: contributed to discussions about cases in the team.  

I worked primarily with Pansy during her two weeks on service with us. Overall, her presentations were sharp and polished. She presented many complex patients without difficulty and incorporated feedback quickly. She asked appropriate questions throughout and remained interested in the entire service, not just the patients she was following. She has a strong fund of knowledge and answered difficult questions I thought more appropriate for the intern or resident. She was great to work with and I think will make an excellent resident. 

Pansy was at the end of her medicine rotation and it showed through her very organized presentations with clear emphasis on the presenting problem. She had very good differential diagnoses. She gave good short talk on the suggested topics. Her physical exam skills although appropriate for her stage, definitely improved during the rotation. Pansy was very professional and fit well into the team dynamic with very well defined roles. 

Pansy: good fund of knowledge. Good history and physical and oral presentations from memory. Communicated well with team and patients. Very professional and appropriately dressed. Gladly presented a difficult topic for us that was well delivered.
Nathan: also good fund of knowledge. Very eager. Also very good history and physical and oral presentations from memory. Communicated well with the team and patients. Also very professional and appropriately dressed. Delivered an excellent journal review to the team. 
They were a pleasure to work with!

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Penelope is a gregarious and enthusiastic young student who is excited by medicine and wants a career in it following in her father's cardiology footsteps. Her presentations were excellent covering most of the issues of relevance to the patient. While her analyses were always correct and appropriate, her knowledge of the pathophysiology of the areas presented were not as deep as I would have liked. She had an excellent demeanor with patients and was obviously very engaged with the work of her ward team and, I am sure, she was very helpful to the residents. Her relationship to her peers was superb, able to pose questions and answer them without any defensiveness. Her write-ups were very detailed (perhaps too detailed) and excellent, and she presented extensive discussions of the areas that the patient's case presented indicating that she did her "homework" diligently. I found the things that she looked up to be informative and I learned a lot from them.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Cho was very eager to participate in team activities and wanted to have an active hand in her patient's care. She had a good fund of knowledge and communicated clearly. I enjoyed having Cho on our team and it was clear that she is a true team player.  

Cho worked well with the team and was effective at completing tasks when given detailed instructions on how to perform those tasks. Compared to her peers, her fund of knowledge is lacking and her time management skills can be improved. For example, Cho had a presentation for her preceptor class the day after long call. She worked on both her powerpoint presentation and her new admission on the same day, and her bedside presentation suffered the following day because of her lack of sleep. We had a feedback session about this, and I recommended she create a plan for balancing her various tasks. I also suggested she study more general medicine (such as learning how to read CXRs, EKGs, etc). Despite this, Cho showed great interest in her patients - when one of her patients had a UTI that speciated into a bacteria everyone was unfamiliar with, Cho found an article and emailed the group with a summary of the information! 

Fund of knowledge: in the process of developing. Represents very early stage in clinical exposure
Patient care skills: history and physical exam skills, reporting skills, ability to synthesize information - limited; could improve upon thoroughness / obtaining and organizing relevant details of H&P and progress notes / flow of presentation, and formulating assessments that are both academic and clinical (ie, how is the patient doing now?). Overall, however, enthusiastic and eager to learn.  
Communication skills: very helpful and eager to communicate with patients / families, or gain collateral information from outside facilities
Professionalism: frequently seeks feedback, and strives to incorporate feedback; eager to improve
Team work: effective at helping to complete assigned roles; takes initiative in talking to families / patients
Suggestions to Cho: continue reading / expanding fund of knowledge, ask questions, practice presentations, practice history-taking and chart-review. Most importantly, remember medicine is an iterative process, and good doctoring will come with time and experience.  

I had the pleasure of working with Cho on the lymphoma service for one week. Cho is compassionate, dedicated to her patients, and consistently demonstrates curiosity and initiative regarding her patients' disease processes and management. She was a valuable member of the team and I believe she will be an excellent clinician. 

Cho was a wonderful med student to have around. She was always energetic, loved spending time with her patients, and did reading on all of her patient's medical issues, often informing us with latest data on rounds. She clearly loves what she does and is going to be a wonderful intern! 

ATTENDINGS

Cho Chang
I worked with Cho during her Gen Med rotation as her primary attending. Cho was taking care of two to three patients with direct supervision of her residents. She presented her patients on daily basis during morning rounds. She also gave the team a brief presentation about disturbances of potassium homeostasis on her initiative. She is a soft spoken and polite student. Her manner towards other team members and patients were excellent. Her patient presentations during morning rounds were excellent. They were very thorough, well prepared and well presented. Her skill to share knowledge with the team was excellent. Her presentation about potassium homeostasis was very well prepared and was of high quality. Also, she asked many interesting and pertinent questions during daily rounds which stimulated academic discussions. Her medical knowledge was good for a medical student in her stage.
Overall, I believe that Cho is an excellent medical student with sound fund of medical knowledge. Her presentations were very well prepared. She is very eager to learn more. She made a significant contribution to academic discussions during morning rounds, and she was considered as a valuable member of the team. I have no doubt that she will be an excellent doctor in near future. 

Cho Chang- 
Her fund of knowledge - very good to excellent
Presentations  - Cho was nervous during her presentations and this compromised the quality and clarity of her case presentations.  They were very good. 
I did not have an opportunity to see her interact with patients except in short exchanges.  Nor did I get a chance to see her work with her intern and resident.  

Cho did a great job. She was very hard working and incredibly helpful to her team. She was an eager participant on rounds.  She was a good communicator and delivered very good presentations. She gave a number of short topic presentations which were very informative for our team and helpful in better understanding our patients' care.  She was professional and respectful.  She seemed to connect very well with her patients. She was very diligent and comprehensive in her history taking and exams.  

Fund of knowledge: Cho is well read, and knows Internal Medicine well. She was motivated to learn more about cancer biology and treatment. 
Patient care skills: Cho was passionate about patient care, and established very good rapport with her patients. 
Presentations: Cho presented well, accurate and cohesively. She improved on summarizing the important and actionable issues. 
Communication skills: Communicated very well and effectively.
Professionalism: Hardworking. Willing to improve on advise. Good at self-learning. 
Team work: Well liked and respected. Very helpful.
Teaching: Good and effective. Taught us the MYD88 and BCR pathways.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

I worked closely with Hermione. She was motivated to do a good job. She sometimes needed reminded to fulfill tasks, but she picked up on this toward the end of the rotation and began taking on more initiative on getting tasks done independently. Her admission presentations were well constructed, especially as she has just started her clinical year. She was responsive to feedback and improved throughout the rotation. She had a great attitude, was gentle and supportive with her patients, who spoke very well of her. One patient specifically said to me "I like that Hermione medical student she's so nice to me". She always tried to be helpful and it was a pleasure working with her. 

Hermione performed detailed histories and physicals, with well-organized and thorough presentations. She clearly thought about her patients, and looked to the primary literature to understand treatment decisions made by the team, such as the unusual use of G-CSF as treatment of febrile neutropenia in her patient. She cared about her patients and checked in on them throughout the day. In particular, she was supportive to a patient with a new diagnosis of metastatic cancer and her family. Hermione will make a wonderful resident and doctor in the future, and I hope she considers medicine! 

Hermione was an absolute pleasure to work with and the best medical student I have worked with so far at Columbia. Her fund of knowledge is excellent and she was very helpful to the team. 

Hermione was the best medical student I have worked with this year - hands down. She knew every patient on our list and was critical in assisting with the care of not only her own admissions, but with all ten of our patients - handling complex consults, taking exquisitely detailed histories and finding clinically relevant physical exam details during preceptor sessions. She is kind, warm, actively contributed to the learning environment for other medical students, house staff and attendings on our sister team and our team, and made coming to work a total pleasure. She will be a wonderful physician and I can't wait to watch her continue to thrive as she progresses in her career. 

She was on my sister team and I did not work with her closely. I just have to say her presentations during rounds were extremely organized, very well-tuned, and overall outstanding.

ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge: Was eager to learn and curious regarding why certain studies were done.
Patient care skills: Was able to obtain and convey accurate information without any difficulty
Presentations: Needed little guidance in presentations. I guided her to be more succinct but that will come with experience and was improving during the short time with the team
Communication skills: Appeared to be very helpful to the team and was an integral manner 

Hermionea was excellent.  She made exceptional presentations of some difficult cases that were thorough, articulate with a well thought out plan.   Her communications skills are outstanding and she was always very professional.   She asked excellent questions.  She presented on the risks of chemotherapy in pregnancy.  It was very informative and complete.   The presentation results in a group discussion of the topic.  

Hermione also impressed me with the teaching she did on rounds, putting together two thorough presentations on scleroderma and the pathogenesis of nephrolithiasis in inflammatory bowel disease. She was able to take the knowledge she had gained studying IBD and apply it to a different clinical situation - answering several questions accurately about that the pathogenesis of nephrolithiasis following gastric bypass surgery. She also did an excellent job with her admission and follow up presentations on rounds, and clearly had a good grasp of the main clinical issues with her patients.  

Fund of knowledge: Very good fund of knowledge and demonstrated great interest in learning.  Asked important and relevant questions during rounds and was also self-directed to find clinical answers through literature searches. 
Patient care skills: Excellent history and physical exam skills. Aware of important exam and lab findings in her patients.  Understands importance and urgency of new clinical findings (ie unilateral leg swelling in bed-bound cancer patient).
Presentations: Very clear and accurate presentations from memory.  
Communication skills: Developed excellent rapport, not only with the patients she was following, but also with other patients on the team. Excellent communication skills. 
Professionalism: Very motivated and professional. Demonstrates empathy and compassion, very important on the oncology ward. Accepts and asks for feedback, which she integrates into her performance. 
Team work: Valuable member of the team.  Worked well with resident and Sub-I.
Teaching: Gave an excellent presentation on XRT and cardiotoxicity.  She was able to cover a complex and broad topic and present it in a succinct way.  She was able to incorporate an area of her interest (cardiology) into the oncology rotation.  Handout gave an excellent summary of findings and how to manage these patients.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Penelope was an excellent medical student. She went above and beyond furthering patient care, not just for her patients but for all patients on our team. She was a great advocate for her patients, ensuring that they got the care they deserved, and helped arrange complicated discharge planning to allow for safe and timely medical follow-up. We had one patient, for example, who was deaf and only minimally able to communicate (some reading lips in Spanish, some signing). She took the time to get in person Spanish interpreters and a sign interpreter to discuss our medical plan. While the patient was only able to understand a small amount, this additional effort at least gave her some ability to communicate, which had not been possible throughout her entire course. Penelope made efforts like this each day and it profoundly impacted the care of our patients. Her presentations were well though out and she clearly researched her patients conditions. She can continue to work on confidence with presenting, but she is beyond where she should be at this point in training. 

Penelope was an exceptional medical student.  Her intelligence and medical knowledge are far advanced compared to her level.  She is very hard working, very diligent, great team player, very helpful.  She was professional, had excellent presentation and communication skills, and very professional. I don't have much to recommend for her to improve at this time. 

Fund of knowledge: Penelope was quite knowledgeable about a very complex patient with advanced cardiopulmonary disease.
Patient care skills: Penelope went above and beyond in helping the team understand her patient's unique psychosocial challenges that was instrumental in providing patient centered care for a very challenging case.
Presentations: Unable to comment
Communication skills: Penelope's ability to communicate struck as someone beyond her training. I commented that I thought she was a resident and not a 3rd year medical student as she was quite knowledgeable and succinct but spot on with her communication.
Professionalism: No concerns. Great attitude. 

During our time together, I was very impressed by Penelope. I've worked with multiple students in starting their MCY in January, and accounting for experience gained as time passes, Penelope is easily the best with whom I have worked. Her knowledge base is beyond someone at her level of training, and her Intellectual curiosity is beyond that of someone who is looking to get test questions right. She owned her patients, and was incredibly invested in their care. We shared one patient on the service that, while we all knew she had a terminal illness, it initially seemed as though she would be able to have at least a few more rounds of treatment and go home and enjoy something on the order of 6 months with her family. During our two weeks, she went from walking around her room, to being unable to interact with her family members. With compassion, professionalism, and dedication, Penelope helped me navigate the family dynamics of 9 siblings and 4 adult children, ultimately transitioning the patient's goals of care first to DNR/DNI, and a few days later to hospice. She was often in communication with multiple family members, and developed relationships that, as her resident, was amazing to bear witness too. This was the first time Penelope had dealt with a situation like this, as while we tackled the issues together, she consistently handled the tough conversations with poise and professionalism. 
In addition to her excellent bedside manner and ability to connect with patients and families, she was also Incredibly organized. She was always prepared for rounds, and always came up with thoughtful differentials for new admissions prior to our discussions. 
It was my pleasure to work with Penelope, and I hope we can work on a team again in the future! (I would love to have her as my Sub-I next year!) 

ATTENDINGS

Ms. Clearwater is excellent in all regards, has a superior fund of knowledge, was diligent, pro-active in researching patient's histories, and at the expected level in the exam and patient interaction. My only negative is that she likes to show-off her medical knowledge (which is sometimes not quite accurate); this improved as she gained more confidence in our interaction, but she should be couseled (gently) on this behavior. 

Feedback for Penelope Clearwater: 
I had the pleasure of observing Penelope present during morning rounds for 2 weeks. Even with some of the more challenging patients assigned on her on the service, Penelope did an excellent job summarizing complicated hospital courses and devising plans of care. She always integrated evidence based medicine into her plans and I felt some of her suggestions to the team actually changed plans of care which is rare to see from a medical student on the team. I could tell from some our discussions regarding her patients after rounds her fund of knowledge was above her peers. 

I was most impressed with Penelope's patient care and teamwork skills.  She was integrated into the team like an intern.  She knew the details not only about the specific patients she followed but all of the patients on the service.  Each morning, I observed her taking histories from patients, examining them and talking to their families.  Along these lines, her communication skills were outstanding. She truly communicated professionally with patients, their families, the team, her peers, nurses and consultants. Similarly, she excelled in professionalism and attitude. In these aspects, she was superior to most P&S students I have known at her level. 
Her fund of knowledge of seemed to be solid. Importantly, she was eager to look up things she didn't know.  

Unfortunately, I only got to see Penelope present one new admission.  She did it from memory (something I don't see that much anymore)!  I would rate that one presentation as very good to excellent; a few things could have been improved, such as putting critical parts of the history in the HPI instead of the PMH.

Penelope Clearwater
1.       Fund of knowledge: excellent
2.       Patient care skills: She asked me to teach how to do percussion better because she was impressed by my percussion- this is one of the nicest compliments that I have received in my medical career. I took both students to see a patient to teach them. They improved within minutes. Their percussion sounded like that of a professional. 
3.       Presentations: outstanding.
4.       Communication skills; outstanding
5.       Professionalism and attitudes. Always super enthusiastic. Went out of her way to learn more. Not shy about asking for help. 
6.       Team Work: outstanding.
7.       Teaching: was well prepared for her presentations

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

Neville Longbottom
Fund of knowledge: He has a good amount of medical knowledge compared to his peers in 3rd year medical school.  He had good clinical reasoning for his differential diagnoses. 
Patient care skills: Neville was well liked by patients and did an excellent job collecting relevant information.   In the future he should strive to take more ownership of the plan for his patients into 4th year and beyond. 
Presentations: His patient presentations were good, and will get better with increased medical knowledge.
Communication skills: He did a great job with communication and was always helpful and cheerful.
Team work: Neville is a great team player and it was a pleasure to work with him. 
Teaching: Neville made a couple great presentations which he gave to our team.  He did an outstanding job!


His curiosity was excellent, though I think he could and will build on his fund of knowledge as he moves forward. I would encourage him to continue reading on his own. His patient care skills are excellent, and he gathered history diligently. He worked well to report it and had good formulation. His presentations were accurate and clear, as well as succinct. He communicated well with everyone in the hospital. He was a great member of the team, and was happy to share all he had learned with us.  


Neville did a great job on the rotation. He's very personable, eager to learn, and asks great questions. He also cares a lot about his patients, which is a great attribute. Keep up the great work! 


ATTENDINGS

Neville Longbottom:  bright, engaged, enthusiastic, good fund of knowledge, diligent care of his patients, clear communicator, capable. 

Neville Longbottom
Fund of knowledge: average
Patient care skills: n/a
Presentations: Rambling, and poorly organized, he stopped mid-HPI to ask questions about what was ultimately his assessment/plan.
Communication skills: unable to comment
Professionalism and attitude: He walked out of rounds one day while one of the night float presentations was happening, for no clear reason. He also didn't seem very engaged in hearing about other patients or cases.
Team work: unable to comment
Teaching: He gave a talk about endocarditis prophylaxis. I thought it was a little odd that he chose to focus on the European recommendations rather than the American ones. While it would have been appropriate to discuss pros/cons and how our recs differ from other professional societies ultimately we practice medicine in the US and I would have structured the talk differently.  

Neville Longbottom- very good presentations with some insights.  More interactive than many other students and participated in rounds. My overall impression is above average student. 
  
Neville was outstanding student. He was a team player. His presentation was clear.

Neville did a great job. He was engaged on rounds and exhibited curiosity and asked thoughtful questions. He delivered very well structured presentations that he clearly worked very hard on. He was a wonderful asset to his team and to his patients.  His patients spoke very highly of him and he seemed to connect well to them. He was always very professional and a pleasure to have on rounds. He additionally delivered several very informative topic presentations that were extremely helpful for our team.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
HOUSESTAFF

I had the pleasure of working with Weasley Ginny (Ginny) for a week or so, please find my comments below: 
Ginny is a very caring, thoughtful and meticulous student.  She took great care and effort to piece together patients' histories, labs, imaging and other data to come up with comprehensive and detailed presentations and insightful assessments of her patients.  Throughout her rotation, she showed enthusiasm for acquiring medical knowledge and learning hands-on skills.  She was always very courteous and professional with both the patients she followed and the medical staff.   

Ginny Ginny:
1. Fund of knowledge - excellent, very eager to learn, good baseline fund of knowledge
2. Patient care skills - Ginny was great with her patients, excellent physical exams
3. Presentations - thorough, appropriately detailed, well organized
4. Communication skills - effective communicator, good public speaker
5. Professionalism - extremely professional always
6. Teamwork - great team player
7. Teaching - gave a great teaching presentation to our team on rounds.  

Ginny was an excellent medical student on our general medicine service. In particular, I was very impressed by her thorough, yet efficient, presentations on rounds. She also did an excellent job teaching the team about several disease processes in great detail. Most notably, she gave an outstanding presentation on the clinical features of scleroderma and created a wonderful handout that would be very helpful as a resource to many students and residents. Ginny also did a wonderful job of taking care of two particularly difficult patients - one of whom had a significant personality disorder preventing the team from appropriately providing necessary medical care. Ginny was able to easily communicate with her by displaying compassion and de-escalating the patient's frustration with the medical team, ultimately allowing us to ensure that she receives her medications, address many of her psychosocial concerns, and ensure close follow-up with her outpatient providers. Ginny is also very receptive to feedback, and provides excellent feedback in return. Would encourage her to keep reading and learning about internal medicine, as she has been doing! Certainly look forward to working with her again


Ms. Ginny is an exceptionally talented, personable and professional student with a remarkably gifted fund of knowledge and a natural skill for team work. From her very first day on the Cardiology wards, it was evident that she had not only prepared for the subject material that she would encounter, but that she was also eager to apply that knowledge to the clinical setting- expertly and efficiently executing patient interviews and physical exams, accurately interpreting her findings and appropriately suggesting evidence-based clinical management. Her admission notes and formal patient presentations on rounds were similarly impressive: she succinctly and thoroughly presented the patient's history of present illness with important, relevant and difficult to attain details, physical exam with pertinent positive and negative, disease-specific elements, and her own assessment with well-organized, thoughtful, and thorough differentials. During teaching sessions, it was clearly evident that Ms. Ginny had a broad and deep fund of knowledge that she expertly resourced in order to dissect complex clinical questions, yet she consistently did this with the utmost professionalism and humility. In addition to these gifted talents, Ms. Ginny is a natural team-worker: she is consistently cheerful, incredibly resourceful and ambitious, and always communicated expertly with all members of the staff. She took full ownership of her patients: she offered daily recommendations in management, remained aware of the details, including small but important changes in physical exam or lab trends, and fully prepared patients for discharge, including making follow up appointments and ensuring patient accessibility to medications. In conclusion, it was an absolute pleasure to work with Ms. Ginny and I have absolutely no doubt that she will make an incredibly gifted and caring physician and colleague. 


ATTENDINGS

Weasley did a very solid job with us. She presented very well and was quite organized and clearly spent a lot of time on her presentations; she seemed very well prepared; her fund of knowledge was above what you would expect at this time of the year; she was affable and professional and respectful and was an integral member of the team. I could certainly see her here as a medical resident should she choose that specialty; a job very well done. 

Weasley is smart and has a very good fund of knowledge.  She was on the other team, so I had less of a chance to evaluate her patient care skills, but I suspect they were very good.  She is hard working and an highly motivated learn and improve.
Her presentations were quite good and thorough.  After some feedback she was improved on her ability to present from memory.  Her interaction with house staff and attendings was very professional and she worked extremely well with her team.  She did give a wonderful presentation to the team on scleroderma, which one of her patients had.    

Unfortunately I only interacted with her for about two weeks, which is not quite enough time to make a thorough evaluation, but I suspect she has earned very positive reviews from everyone she has interacted with.
Finally, she was a bit reserved, which I suspect is the reason she was a little more quiet than the other student.  However, I never had the sense that this was because she was insecure about her fund of knowledge.  She answered questions with confidence.

Weasley Ginny was terrific.  She was smart, able to apply information, was caring, very interested in learning.  She had a very good fund of knowledge.  Was very likable, always pleasant.  Her presentations were very good, and she was able to formulate appropriate differential diagnosis, and begin to formulate a plan of care. .  
She was also well liked and respected by the intern and resident that we worked with.
Overall she was a pleasure to work with.
