Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Neville's Medicine  performance peaked in the last three weeks of the Medicine clinical clerkship.  In his most sophisticated write up he reviewed potential causes of acute diarrhea in immunecompromised patients and make a specific diagnosis of Norovirus infection in his specific patient.  He also showed original thinking in questioning the attribution of his young patient's early end stage renal disease to hypertension (in the electronic health record) and surmised that a genetic or environmental toxin exposure likely played a role given the early onset.  Neville showed a talent for teaching when he taught his fellow students about the clinical manifestations of pituitary adenomas by using a sample clinical case.

eval_name: Student Performance Evaluation - Medicine Home Clerkship
question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Ginny distinguished herself as a leader among the students in our preceptor group.  She was exceptionally organized and professional.  Ginny's evaluation of a patient presenting with poorly controlled heart failure and with a background history of drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome that demonstrated her ability to grasp the complex biological and social forces affecting her patient's illness.  Ginny saw how the background DRESS syndrome led to selection of an expensive diuretic medication that the patient could not afford, ultimately leading to a broken treatment plan and an avoidable hospitalization.  Likewise, in a patient with acute dyspnea, Ginny was able to tease apart the contributions of acute panic attack and chronic but stable lung disease.  Ginny's exposition of the physiologic and molecular mechanisms of disease were always presented in support of her diagnostic reasoning.

answer_text: Katie was an excellent student on the neurology rotation.  She was noted by all to be a superb member of the team and gave excellent and educational presentations.  On her outpatient block, she took an excellent history and formed a good rapport with a relatively young patient. In taking a thorough history, she ultimately was able to formulate the case in a thoughtful and nuanced manner that exceeded what would be expected at her level of training.  All those she worked with noted her distinct ability to take an informative and thorough history to inform her differential diagnosis.   She was very professional in all aspects of her rotation and educated her team with background information regarding the conditions of her patients. question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Dudley was an excellent student on the neurology rotation.  He was highly inquisitive, enthusiastic, very organized and detail oriented with an excellent bed side manner.  He was a great team player and did a remarkable job on his inpatient rotations, even receiving a high five for his care from a patient.  His presentations were very organized and included the relevant information, demonstrating his understanding of pertinent positives and negatives of the case.  He was a "pleasure to work with" and a great asset to the team and always contributed in a meaningful way to his patient's care.  From the start, he showed a keen interest, passion, and enthusiasm about neurology which shined through. He consistently took the initiative to find out more detailed and higher-level information about pathophysiology and management of disease processes affecting his patients. He gave an excellent presentation on gliomas and even accompanied his patient to the OR to be involved in all aspects of his care.  He was remarkably empathic and established strong rapport with his patients, even continuing to follow them peripherally when they were transferred to other services.  He took excellent care of his patients and was always up to date on all of the details surrounding their case. This was evident in his daily presentations that were very detailed and organized, though succinct.  He took pride in all of his work, and he was willing to help on all levels of care.  He sought out feedback, and was very enthusiastic and motivated to continue learning and refining his clinical skills. His knowledge of neurological disease processes is more advanced than his peers and more than what was expected for a second year medical student. He eagerly absorbed any supplementary material and would bring in current literature to support his assessments on rounds.  He will be an excellent resident in the future (hopefully in Neurology!).

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Katie is encouraged to broadening her differential diagnosis in her clinical assessments.  Her write-ups were overall well written, however at times the histories included excessive details not relevant to the presenting complaint.  Though she excels at taking a thorough history, she should work on distilling her histories into a more concise and meaningful narrative, and think more critically about neuroanatomical localization.  Despite a very strong clinical performance, Katie did not meet Honors criteria due to a low performance on the shelf examination.

answer_text: Dudley was encouraged to continue practicing his neurological exam skills, and further honing in on his knowledge of neuroanatomy. Write-ups were very comprehensive with an excellent discussion, but they would have benefitted from more organization and editing of extraneous information.  Despite his outstanding clinical performance, Dudley did not meet Honors criteria due to a low performance on the shelf examination.

answer_text: Pansy was an outstanding student on the neurology rotation.  She was consistently interested, actively participated on rounds and asked excellent questions.  While rotating on the stroke consult service, she quickly learned all items of the NIHSS and participated in many stroke codes. She was eager to learn neuroanatomic localization and was an essential aid in gathering collateral. She did an outstanding job interviewing a patient with new onset headache, and both her history and physical exam were excellent.  She also was very helpful, knowing residency is busy, she was always willing to go the extra mile.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Seamus was an outstanding student on the neurology clerkship.  He takes initiative, is exceptionally self- motivated, interested, enthusiastic and engaged.   His personality and enthusiasm shine through, and he dedicated his time to his patients.  He is sharp, lively, and appeared very interested in the nervous system.   While on the consult service, one patient wound up going to the stroke service and was not doing well and Seamus followed up on the patient and provided research papers regarding the reasons behind the patient's plan of care independently.  He is very curious and inquisitive, and consistently demonstrated great initiative throughout his time on the rotation.  He did a great presentation on the syndromes of the thalamus which was at the level of a resident.  He was always eager to pick up more patients, and he formed great relationships with them. He would even spend afternoons talking with patients who didn't have frequent visitors. He performed thorough history and physicals, and he gave well-organized presentations. He was also able to discuss localization accurately and able to make accurate assessments about patients. He was a motivated self-learner, and he did reading/research to share with the group.  He was a great help to the team, especially on the weekends.  Seamus is a polite, professional, and hard-working student who ranks at the top of his class. During the clerkship he followed his patients very closely, often checking in on them several times throughout the day and providing relevant updates.  He also gave a presentation on Meniere's disease where he went above and beyond by discussing the latest evidence on treatment trials. His write-ups were very well written and demonstrated an advance knowledge of clinical reasoning and neurological localization, and he effectively used the literature to support his discussions.   He is extremely intellectually curious and a great personality to have around on the wards, inspiring his co-students and the residents to have fun with their work and we hope he considers neurology!

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Cho was an excellent student on the neurology rotation.  She is smart, engaged, thoughtful, and asked good questions.   She was a very enthusiastic and helpful team member, and exceptionally dedicated to her patients and always seeking out new admissions.  She consistently advocated for her patients and brought up issues on rounds to advance their care. She was curious about their cases and involved in all aspects of care.  She admitted a patient with a very complicated medical history and worked hard trying to piece together the history.  She is extremely involved in patient care, and went out of her way to make sure all plans and tasks were completed for all her patients.  For example, she researched and performed behavioral therapies for a patient with a disabling functional movement disorder, which they otherwise would not have been able to receive.  She consistently looked for learning opportunities. She followed a patient with NMDA receptor encephalitis and asked very relevant questions about her care. She was confident and proactive on rounds. Her history and exam skills, communication skills, and fund of knowledge were all sound.  Cho was "spectacular" on her pediatric neurology rotation. She was highly energetic and engaged throughout the rotation. She was eager to participate actively on rounds and took full responsibility for her patient care. Cho presented several full history and physicals on rounds, which were succinct, well prepared and contained a well though impression with appropriate recommendations. Cho was asked to prepare several mini presentations for which she presented the material to the group at nearly a resident level.  She will be a very strong resident in whatever field she Chooses.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Cho should continue to work on the organization of her presentations- she tends to get nervous when presenting and on rounds, and this may have made her forget things that she really does know.   Thus, at times it was difficult to understand the trajectory of her histories and it seemed that she didn't quite know what to include/exclude which confounded her formulations.   She should gain more confidence as the year progresses, and this will improve.  She should continue to work on her fund of knowledge and her knowledge of neuroanatomy.  Her write-ups would benefit from a more in-depth discussion and some editing of the histories, as they often were overly inclusive.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Ginny was an outstanding student on the neurology rotation.    She was a pleasure to have on the ward service- she clearly takes her work very seriously and is a strong patient advocate. She pays attention to details and is very meticulous and hard working. She was consistently up to date on the details of her patients and kept the team abreast of any new developments.  She gave a great presentation on neuromuscular junction disorders and myasthenia gravis.  She was always willing to help, consistently on time and very professional. She has a strong fund of knowledge and was always able to answer questions on rounds.  She has the ability to list a variety of differential diagnoses and prioritize them appropriately based on her history and exam.   Her presentations were thorough and well informed, and she speaks confidently and succinctly.  She has a very professional demeanor, though generally a very quiet member of the team.  She made very clear assessment knowing clinical relevance and priority. She diligently follows patients and discusses them with her own suggestions and quickly identifies and brings forward any clinical changes.   She is a very thoughtful student with good clinical insight, and overall well above the expected level of independence and fund of knowledge.   Her write-ups were concise though thorough with excellent discussions of differential diagnosis.  She was hugely helpful to the team in everyday tasks. She is very kind toward her patients, and she will make a superb doctor.

answer_text: Neville was an excellent student on the neurology rotation.  He was a pleasure to work with"Óhe was outgoing and took initiative to interview and examine consult patients. He was very inquisitive and showed an interest in learning more about neurology. He had smooth presentations with Dr. B! He was thorough in his exams, for example when testing mental status included tests for apraxia. Neville really excelled while on the pediatric neurology consult team where he was noted to be enthusiastic and hard-working, always willing to take on more work.  He seems to have a clear connection to children, and came into the pediatric neurology rotation and was clearly very enthusiastic and genuine. He was incredibly engaged with the team and very eager to learn. He was able to take on new consults with excitement and was open to constructive learning. He prepared a strong presentation for the group on a common pediatric neurology topic and even presented a journal article in front of a patient with newly diagnosis infantile spasms.  He performed at a very high level and will be a strong senior medical student next year.  He was wonderful with his patients, a team player and always went the extra mile! He "will make a wonderful doctor no matter what career path he takes" but does have a clear connection with pediatrics.  His write-ups displayed his superior ability to take a detailed pediatric history and use that history and his exam to come up with an appropriate and prioritized differential diagnosis.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Vincent was an outstanding student on the neurology clerkship.   He was always very professional, had great bedside manner, took a keen interest in learning about his patients, and delivered well organized presentations. Everyone enjoyed working with him, and he was very integrated in the team and took initiative with the patient's care by getting much-needed records and researching patient conditions. While on the stroke consult service, he was always on time, dependable and easy to engage. He accompanied a senior resident to several stroke codes and was more involved than any other student she had worked with and commented on how she could not have made it through seven stroke codes without his help. He caught on very quickly to how stroke codes were run and was extremely helpful. He gathered accurate information and correctly prioritized the next steps to take during a neurological emergency. He was trustworthy and definitely performing at a level above a 3rd year medical student.  Vincent was described as a terrific individual to have on the service. He was assigned several patients with extremely complex histories who required numerous hours of investigative work involving tracking down prior physicians and acquiring old records. He worked on this dutifully every day and was able to bring the team a lot of extremely useful information.  He is also very mature and professional which allows him to integrate easily into the milieu very well. He asks insightful questions which speak to his knowledge base and it is clear that he is actively engaged in learning material. He gave a short talk on spinal cord syndromes which was well received and informative.  He was an incredibly hard working student, took ownership of his patients, and was respectful and collegial towards his patients and the rest of the team. He is incredibly bright, with a strong foundation in knowledge.  His presentations were succinct, and honed in on the important data for his patients.   He was also very professional and friendly, and any residency program would be lucky to have him as one of their residents in the future.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Patil was an excellent student on the neurology clerkship.  She is exceptionally good at communicating with patients, and she is able to elicit a robust history because patients are comfortable with her and she elicits things others cannot.  She has a sense of what details not to miss and what diagnoses to consider.   Her notes and presentations were stellar.  She asked intelligent questions and her knowledge of neuroanatomy and neurology pathophysiology was at the late PY2/3 level.  She went to the literature and looked up information her patients without being prompted.  She often supplemented what the residents said from her own histories.   She took care of very complex patients and did a wonderful job summarizing her patient issues---she was challenged by her patients, though after a day or two of caring for them, did great work putting all the issues together. She worked incredibly hard gathering supportive evidence and helping with the team's daily activities. She took care of a patient with a complicated medical course involving multiple organ dysfunction and was reliable in informing the team of any new events or concerns.  She was enthusiastic about attending family meetings and learning more about goals of care discussions.  She was professional and compassionate with patients, and she had an excellent fund of knowledge. Even early in the rotation she was able to perform a full neurologic exam and was able to modify the exam to fit the needs of the chief complaint. She was also able to identify important abnormalities on exam and provide a good assessment. She was extremely helpful and was very proactive about finding ways to help the team.  Her questions demonstrated that she was critically thinking about her patients. She was able to recognize stroke syndromes and stroke risk factors while on the stroke consult service.  She was a pleasure to work with, was very professional and respectful. She was enthusiastic about the rotation and was always asking how she could be involved or help with patient care.   Many commented on her excellent bedside manner- one resident commented that upon seeing several neurological emergencies together, she was very helpful in calming patients down and making them feel safe.  She is quickly able to gain a patients trust, and this is a unique quality that cannot be taught and she will do very well in the future because of it. She also asked very relevant and in depth questions showing her clear understanding of basic concepts and the ability to build further on them.  Patil took a keen interest in learning about every patient, whether it was in the ED, ICU, or floor. She was always enthusiastic, had a positive attitude, and would take the time to read up on her patients. Towards the end of the consult block, the residents felt very comfortable having Patil see consults on her own before re-examining the patient together. Her assessment and plans were very thorough and impressive for a medical student.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Patil is encouraged to continue to work on organizing and gathering thoughts before oral presentations.  She is hard working, but needs to continue to improve her overall clinical acumen.  Her write-ups would benefit from addressing the chief complaint with more questions and pertinent positives and negatives in her HPI.  Her overall differential diagnoses were somewhat limited and should aim to be broadened.  At times, it seems that the relevance of certain findings in the exam or history were not addressed in the discussion or incorporated into the differential diagnosis.

answer_text: Lavender was an excellent student on the neurology rotation. She will be an excellent physician in any area she chooses. She is very hard-working and motivated.  She ended up taking care of a patient with critical illness myopathy along with a separate patient with paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. She showed excellent initiative in reading up on both of these conditions. She was also a great member of the team, always very engaged with rounds and offering to help out with tasks that need to be completed.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Cedric was an outstanding student on the neurology rotation.  One afternoon while on the stroke service, he helped resident out with six sequential stroke activations and was immensely helpful.  He always showed so much enthusiasm that it made everyone feel better even in times of deep stress. He was proactive and picks up on clues very quickly both from patients and from the team and is a great team player.  He puts patients at ease right away.  He would come up with ways to help immediately, got patient's home meds, reassured families, helped protocol imaging, transported patients, got more information on patients' baseline exams, you name it.  He was running in every direction always on top of everything with great initiative.  He fully understands how the system works.  Personally, he shows exceptional empathy and care.  He was noted to function as a neurology junior when on the stroke consult service.  He is inquisitive, and has a really deep fund of knowledge and knows how to dig into it for the information that matters for the patients on the team. For a patient (not his!) who came in with an intractable cough, it was Cedric who pointed out that he was on an ACE inhibitor -- this was missed by the junior resident, senior resident, and attending -- changing our management for the patient significantly. Cedric always volunteered to help out with patients who weren't his, and didn't just do a task, but used that as an opportunity to learn and teach about some aspect of neurology. His differentials are appropriately broad, and he knows how to prioritize. He has a calmness and maturity that surpass his level of training. Cedric was an extremely thoughtful and insightful student. He was always prepared to discuss patients, and always had very insightful ideas and contributed well to differential diagnosis discussions.  Cedric is a keen observer and impressively analyzed medical and socioethical considerations for some complex cases on the neurology service. He's confident, has a great bedside manner, and references the literature to support his assessments. He learned a lot of information pertaining to neurology quickly. He'll make an excellent resident and future physician.

answer_text: Gregory was an excellent student on the neurology rotation.  He consistently demonstrated thorough history taking and data gathering, including chart review, to obtaining collateral and complicated histories.  For the patients that he was following, Gregory would always perform a thorough chart review and go out of his way to obtain collateral history from family members and nursing homes, which was particularly helpful because many of them had complicated medical histories and presentations.   He establishes excellent rapport with patients and families, is easy to talk to, and very inquisitive.  He was consistently noted as being very poised and professional. His presentations are excellent and succinct.  In one case, he was able to correctly diagnose a patient with an intracerebral hemorrhage, and was dedicated to all aspects of their care which impressed his entire team.  His presentations were excellent, very articulate and polished.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Viktor was an outstanding student on the neurology rotation.  He was noted to be very methodical, well organized, and compassionate.  He appeared genuinely interested in learning neurology, and is very intelligent and hard working.  He is highly professional and organized and has a perfectly appropriate, calm, and reassuring demeanor with patients. He was always eager to learn and took opportunities to see new patients, taking a new patient almost daily and also over the weekend. He was a good history taker and was able to start a good assessment and plan, and was reliable in his follow-ups.  He gave reasonable hypotheses and differentials for patients, and his exams were thorough though appropriately focused.  With one particular patient, in spite of him having a very complex neurologic history, Viktor was able to digest the history appropriately and had a reasonable plan for the patients' care.  Viktor did a very good job taking care of his follow-up patients, and always knew their most recent updates. Additionally, he handled new consults very well, and gave great presentations.  Viktor is a strong student with a good breadth of knowledge and displays tremendous professionalism. He is poised, confident and great with patients.  He wrote elegant and very detailed notes and has a good bedside manner.  His personality is not to be aggressive, but an incredibly hard worker "behind the scenes".

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Penelope was an outstanding student on the neurology rotation.  She was noted to work at a subintern level, synthesizing information rapidly and thoroughly (seeing 3-4 consults a day).  She was able to present and highlight critical information, well above her level of training in efficiency and level of knowledge.  She was noted to be a "force of nature""Ówas totally engaged, fiercely enthusiastic, and interacted well with patients and colleagues.  Penelope is a highly motivated and capable medical student. She obtains comprehensive histories, seeks collateral information independently, and performs detailed exams on her patients. She is a strong communicator, and is confident in her presentations which were consistently solid. She seemed to have an above average fund of knowledge-- she correctly recognized a sensory aphasia in a patient and was able to identify the pathways involved in her stroke patient with little time for preparation in her first days of the rotation. She was reliable, providing good follow-ups on her patients, and she worked well with the team.  She worked hard on this rotation and spent a lot of time with her patients, which showed on rounds and in discussion with me about the patients. She took the time to read on her own and asked excellent questions.  She is incredibly efficient and has a strong knowledge base in neurology.  She is also an incredibly hard worker--she came to Allen at 6A one morning to preround.  She has already begun developing good clinical intuition. Her excitement to learn was contagious. She worked at a superior level, taking on the responsibility of a high patient load with complex neurological presentations. She was inquisitive and excelled at localizing the neurological symptoms and her presentations demonstrated that and were well organized.  Penelope was a very active team member and eagerly took on responsibility.  She was consistently dependable and professional. She would be a great neurologist if she chooses this as her specialty.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Penelope is encouraged to be aware of team dynamics as at times her enthusiasm and dominating personality can take over other people's presentations and she often takes charge of small groups.  She was provided feedback and was able to self reflect.  Though her write-ups were thorough and meticulously done, they could use some editing as they were quite long, which tended to distract from what she seemed to want to prioritize.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Several areas were offered for further improvement.   Though Oliver demonstrated a good understanding of brain neuroanatomy, he could brush up on spinal and peripheral anatomy/syndromes and his performance on the shelf suggests overall fund of knowledge is an area in which to aspire to continued improvement.   He was encouraged to work on his history taking and presentation skills, which at times were noted to lack organization and despite being very thorough could be overly inclusive.  Presentations overall were noted to lack focus and depth, and often focused on irrelevant rather than key parts of the history.  His performance was average in terms of examination skills and he is encouraged to develop this.  He should strive to continue to learn about neuroanatomic localization, and develop increasingly sophisticated assessments.  His write-ups were very thorough, however would benefit from a greater discussion of localization and a broader differential diagnosis.  Supervising physicians noted that he asked ask a lot of questions, which by some was misinterpreted as over- confidence as he appears to challenge those around him and was thought to be seemingly competitive with his peers.  Several team members also commented that though he was very insightful in listening to others on rounds and asked challenging questions to his fellow students, he could often not answer questions when he was challenged in turn.  In future team learning, he is encouraged to be aware of his interpersonal interactions and be respectful of his peers, allowing them to demonstrate their knowledge as well.  He may still be learning what his role is as a medical student, and in this sense should aim to be more self-directed and independent in his problem-solving, as he was noted to require significantly more guidance and direction than his colleagues.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Oliver was an excellent student on the neurology rotation.  He clearly seems to have a good grasp of the approach to neurologic patients and approach to basic workups.  He asked meaningful questions about patient diagnoses and management.  While on the consult team, he was able to do a good presentation with short notice.  It is clear that he has a keen interest in Neurology and went above and beyond to find learning opportunities and help the team.  He demonstrated a broad and advanced level of neurological knowledge was also thorough with his history taking.  He spent time speaking with patients, performing extensive chart reviews, and was able to use his history and physical exam to localize lesions and create a differential diagnosis.  He did a particularly good job with a patient with progressive spastic paraparesis.  He also voluntarily came in both days one weekend just to have more chances to see and present patients.  He consistently showed interest in learning about neurology and was motivated to see new consults.  Oliver is a strong student who drew on his background in neuroscience to impress those working with him on the child neurology service.  He was always trying to further tailor his differential, and trying to identify the most salient features of a patient's presentation. He has a great rapport with patients, will do very well as a Neurology resident should he choose to pursue this.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Dean was an outstanding student on the neurology rotation.   He has an excellent fund of knowledge and superb communication skills.  He was an exceptional student and a pleasure to have on the service.  He was enthusiastic and engaged, and followed up on his patients who all identified him as their doctor. He was self-sufficient and took control of his own learning, with great initiative and intellectual curiosity.  He asked excellent questions and had a genuine curiosity about neurology and about his patients.  He was always asking how he could help and what needed to be done. He played an active role in patient care and the team was able to trust him with tasks that often medical students cannot do without guidance (such as explaining medical information to patients, arranging for diagnostic studies and communicating with consultants). He was also very empathetic and intuitive to his patient's needs. He developed strong relationships with them and had a particularly difficult patient that he handled exceedingly well. One day this patient presented us with some research that he thought was related to his condition (it was felt by the team to be unrelated)-- Dean took the papers home and came back the next to go through all of the information with him. The patient was very grateful that his opinion was taken seriously and reacted very well when Dean explained (after discussing with the team) how this was not related to his condition. Everyone on the team expressed being very sad to see Dean go when his rotation was over.  He is passionate, very professional, asked great questions, reviewed literature for topics, and showed interest in learning.   He is very mature, organized, thoughtful, and actively sought out feedback throughout the rotation.  He is well on his way to becoming an outstanding physician and any residency program will be lucky to have him.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Oliver is a strong medical student, both in terms of hypothesis-driven H&P's as well as empathy and emotional support for patients. As a sub-I he handled a patient load at or above his level. He was always eager to pick up new patients, and on weekend call he helped care for other patients that were followed by residents during the week.  In one particular case, the team had to give an uninsured, undocumented woman with metastatic cancer the unfortunate news of her prognosis. Oliver, who has an interest in palliative care, was instrumental in that conversation and his interpersonal skills and ability to comfort during such a difficult conversation was beyond some attendings I've seen. He lingered at her bedside even after the team left to continue rounds. Oliver took ownership of his patients at a resident level and coordinated and involved their inpatient care with their outpatient doctors. Over the weekend, a senior neurology attending who was covering for only 2 days was so impressed with Oliver's skills that he made a point to tell us with hopes of recruiting him to our specialty. Oliver will make a thoughtful and brilliant physician.

answer_text: Although he was a sub-I on the team, Dudley essentially functioned at the first-year neurology resident level on our busy inpatient neurology team. He independently saw patients both in the emergency room and the inpatient services and would present well-thought differential diagnoses and formulations during rounds. He showed initiative in terms of following up on patients and was an essential part of our team. Most importantly, he showed the utmost professionalism and earned the respect of the other medical students and residents on the team. He gave an excellent presentation, answered questions well, and more importantly asked questions when he didn't understand something. He is a quick learner and a pleasure to work with.  He deeply cared for his patients and followed them closely. He will be a splendid neurologist. I will encourage him to apply to our program.

answer_text: Cedric was co-precepted by Drs. LS and PD. They had the opportunity to evaluate him in the L&D, ultrasound, and private practice settings.  He also spent a week on the antepartum service. Cedric performed well above his level of training during his Maternal Fetal Medicine rotation.  He displayed all the characteristics that one loves to see in a trainee -- an eagerness to learn, empathy towards patients in difficult situations, and kindness towards patients, staff, and colleagues.  Cedric is thoughtful and intelligent, always taking advantage of any downtime to read, ask questions, and expand his knowledge.  He always behaved in a professional manner and I enjoyed having him in the office seeing patients.  Overall, an excellent rotation and we are certain he has made the correct choice of OB/GYN!!

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Luna was co-precepted by Dr. CB and myself and we worked with her in the clinic, private practice, ultrasound, and L&D setting.  We both thought that Luna is a truly wonderful student and want her to stay with us!

My specific comments: "Luna "Luna" was a pleasure to teach and work with. She is earnest, proactive, intelligent and worked well with all members of our team. I really found her personally to be caring and sweet. Not only is she motivated to teach and share what she has learned with others, but she also seems to care about the attendings as well. At the end of long days, she just always demonstrated kindness and concern to me, which was refreshing. I tried to give her many opportunities to scan and do procedures and she was always very attentive to details. We spoke at length about her career plans and her projects (including ideas for modules/lectures for embryology) and I really admired her ability to come up with ideas, propose a plan and speak with the appropriate administrators in a timely fashion. When Luna has a plan, she is motivated to make it happen. Luna is strong clinically, she has great patient presentations and actively seeks feedback. She has been one of my favorite students that I have precepted and I know that she will do exceedingly well in any ob/gyn residency, hopefully she will want to stay!"

Dr. GB writes, "Luna was fantastic. She is extremely smart and a team player. I challenged her to think on her feet, and she was able to do so. She had an excellent rapport with my patients. I hope she chooses to do her residency with us."

Hermione was co-precepted by Dr.R and Dr. . The evaluation and comments are a composite of both attendings. 

They write that "Hermione did a fantastic job during her preceptorship month. She is sharp, motivated, and fun to work with. Hermione was very committed to our patients, their well-being, and the outcomes of their pregnancies. She kept herself updated on relevant obstetrical literature as it applied to patient care and asked thoughtful questions. She was a real team player when on-service. She regularly looked for ways to contribute as a member of the team, and her contributions were meaningful. Based upon our month together, I have every confidence that Hermione is ready to function as an intern in Obstetrics and Gynecology. HONORS work!"

Residents and fellows who worked with Hermione also commended that they enjoyed working with her, that she always demonstrated interest and a willingness to help out.  She gets our highest endorsement for her application to an ob/gyn residency!

answer_text:
Katie was co-precepted by Drs. K and C, who worked with her in their private offices, ultrasound, and L&D.  I also interacted with her briefly, which were always pleasant and professional.  The residents and fellows who worked with her also gave positive feedback about her time with us.

Dr. F wrote, "Katie was a delight; wonderful work ethic and fund of knowledge, bonded with patients despite limited contact. Would be a wonderful resident and I'd be thrilled if she chose to stay with us..."

Dr. C wrote, "It was a true pleasure to work with Katie. She was engaged and engaging-she came well prepared to clinic, having read about the patients before hand, and she had great interpersonal contact with the patients we saw together and the staff. She is composed, mature and appears to have excellent critical thinking skills. I trust that she will become an excellent physician-I hope in OB! "

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Pansy was co-precepted by Dr. RM and myself.  We had the opportunity to work with her in the clinic, private practice, ultrasound, and L&D settings.  We both felt that she was one of the strongest students we've had the pleasure to work with in recent years.

I felt that Pansy was a honest to goodness treasure. From the very beginning, she demonstrated all the attributes you could possibly want in a student and resident. She was polite, proactive, intelligent, charming and tireless. There was no task too small and she found something to learn from each patient we interacted with. I gave her many opportunities to scan and she really worked on her technique. When junior students were around, she really took the time and effort to teach them about obstetrics and give them guidance about med school. In a short time, I felt like I really had the chance to know her well and she is wonderful.

Dr M wrote, "Pansy was a wonderful addition to our high-risk obstetrical service during her preceptorship month. She is smart, focused, and committed to patient care. She has a positive attitude and great empathy, which helped her fit in quite well with our resident teams. Pansy's fund-of-knowledge was quite impressive, and her understanding of difficult concepts and conditions was often at a resident level or beyond. For concepts that were new to her, she dove into the medical literature with impressive self-motivation. She synthesizes diagnoses and creates management plans quite capably, as well. I have every confidence that Pansy is ready to function successfully as an intern in Obstetrics and Gynecology. HONORS work!"

Pansy is a super star and we hope that she will want to stay and do her residency with us!

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
This is a composite of the comments given to Vincent while he was on service for the month:

Vincent was a true superstar on our service.  Everyone who worked with him considered him to be an integral member of the team.  He was incredibly engaged and proactive in L&D, clinic and the OR.  Because of his interest in being a part of the team, he asked if he could do a week of night float with the L&D team and I said that I thought it was a great idea.  His night team were thrilled to have someone as engaging and excited about OB as Vincent on the team.  They wrote, "Vincent was a spectacular sub intern on nights for the week we spent together. He understood and integrated himself into the flow of the labor floor in a way few medical students do. He was maximally helpful in all ways, with clinical duties seeing triage patients, helping with translation, filling out baby papers, anything possible that was helpful to the team. He was always thinking critically about his patient's problems and asked insightful questions about the management of complicated medical issues that showed he had a good understanding of the underlying pathophysiology. He was respectful and had good situational awareness. His OR skills were easily at the level of an intern several months into internship. He was able to fill the role of primary surgeon through most of a C section, a role he had never practiced with ease and grace. We hope we have swayed him to pursue obstetrics and gynecology!"

It is without a doubt that Vincent is a self-starter and has the ability to take anything we teach him to the next level.  At the end of the month, we allowed him to have his own room at the high risk clinic to see patients, which is normally a PGY-2 privilege.  Vincent will be an asset to ANY ObGyn residency and we would hope that he would stay with us in NY, though wish him well in any top-rated program!

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Oliver is a motivated, hard-working student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. His baseline fund of knowledge was excellent. His clinical skills are developing well and he was observed to obtain appropriate patient histories and perform careful exams. His clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an interpreter. His patient care presentations were "clear" and felt to be "advanced... for this part of the year". His preceptor noted "Oliver participated each week in the preceptor sessions. His patient presentation was very good and well received by the group. His fund of knowledge was consistent with a student in the first clerkship. It was obvious that he had learned a lot by the end of the rotation." Oliver's interpersonal and communication skills are particularly strong. Evaluators complimented his "excellent bedside manner", and reported that his patients "were very comfortable with him." Always professional, residents felt "[he] demonstrated excellent situational awareness... [and was] a super helpful member of the team." Eager to learn, "he was always open to feedback and able to incorporate feedback into his work". Additionally, "he [was] never afraid of a challenge." He showed great initiative and "always was looking for ways to participate in his patient's care." In addition, he "was always open to feedback and able to incorporate feedback into his work". These traits made him "instrumental to the team on the floor and in clinic" and a valued member of his various teams. Submitted work included a clearly written patient education pamphlet on prenatal care. In sum, Oliver did an excellent job on the rotation.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following evaluation is a composite, derived from observations made by residents, nurse and faculty during the course of this clinical elective.
 

Mr Dean is an outstanding student, who performed remarkably during his first rotation of this major clinical year.  Staff uniformly remarked upon his skillful adaptation to the clinical learning environment, his apparent strong knowledge base, his enthusiasm and his strong clinical "sense".

 

Dean's exam skills are advanced beyond the level expected at this level of training.  He domonstrated a marked degree of comfort and facility in stablishing rapport and examining patients.  His history- taking and presentation skills are superior.  At this early stage of training, he is capable of formulating differential diagnoses "on the fly" and generating preliminary management plans

Perhaps most importantly- Deans enthusiasm warmly impressed all here who worked with him.  He consistently sought opportunities to participate in the care of patients, attempting to utilize and improve his medical Spanish skills, as needed.  He diligently followed the patients for whom he participated in care and graciously sought the feedback of his mentors.

 

It is our impression that Dean will be an outstanding physician.

Mr Krum is a fine medical student who readily adapted to the challenges of the clinical learning environment  during this, the first rotation of his major clinical year.

Staff uniformly remarked upon his strong knowledge base, his readiness to participate in clinical activity as well as his enthusiasm and curiosity.  His clinical skills are commensurate with his level of training- he demonstrated the ability to obtain a history confidently and perform the requisite physical examination.  He is developing fine presentation skills

It is our impression that he will be a fine physician.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Gregory is a student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. His baseline fund of knowledge was strong but he is "a quick learner" and he added to it over the weeks. His clinical skills are developing well and he was observed to obtain appropriate histories and perform careful exams. His clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an interpreter. Formal presentations included a "solid" presentation of endometriosis to his preceptor group; and his patient care "presentations and notes improved over the course of the clerkship." Submitted work included a well-researched, clearly written patient education portfolio on menopausal symptoms that nicely avoided the use of medical jargon. Gregory's interpersonal and communication skills are areas of particular strength. One resident evaluator commented "Excellent student, has a great demeanor with patients and staff, is a very effective communicator".  Another "[heard] from scrub techs and nurses he was always kind and helpful". Yet another noted he showed great interest in the patients and their stories.  Eager to learn and contribute, Gregory made good use of feedback to improve his performance. He also showed initiative and completed patient tasks reliably. These traits made him an effective and valued member of his various teams. In sum, Gregory did an excellent job on the rotation.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text:
1. Your excellent pamphlet would have been better yet with more developed content"Óhow are the different kinds of vaginitis diagnosed? Are there any sequelae? In addition, there have been reviews of the topic written more recently than the management article you referenced"Óalways refer to the most up to date references.

2. There was a wide range in assessments of your notes (1-5) and presentations (2-5). One evaluator wrote "While Cedric led by example in terms of empathy and patient rapport, however, his notes were sometimes late and contained redundant information that had been copied and pasted from the previous note without change. His patient presentations could also use more fluidity, organization, and efficiency. With more practice writing notes and with presentations, Cedric will be a valued member of any team". Another suggested: "Keep working on conciseness, efficiency in presentations but overall wonderful job!"

3. One evaluator who was complementary of your empathy for patients also wrote "Poor knowledge of anatomy in the OR and did not follow up on a topic that I asked him to which was disappointing".


Final Score 3.43: Clinical 3.59, OSCE 3, Shelf 3, Pamphlet 2.75

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Cedric is a mature, highly engaged student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. His baseline fund of knowledge was excellent and he added to it over the weeks. His clinical skills are developing well and he was observed to obtain appropriate histories and perform careful exams. His clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an early manager; his patient care presentations highlighted his understanding of his patients' issues; and evaluators felt he had "strong basic skills" in note-writing. Submitted work included a clearly written patient education pamphlet on Vaginitis. A topic presentation on vaginal discharge was "informational and appropriate for the intended audience".

Cedric' interpersonal and communication skills are superb. Multiple evaluators commented on his ability to develop good rapport with his patients and with members of his teams. One evaluator wrote "Very sensitive to patients' needs and emotional health. Nice to see a medical student care so much about our patients!"  Another commented "His compassion to care for his patients, his concern for different team members, and anticipation of team member's needs was exemplary... He would be a fantastic co-resident one day". Yet another wrote "Cedric helped to take care of one of our sickest patients on the service. He developed a strong relationship with her, and oftentimes would visit her unprompted and report new information about the patient that the team wouldn't know... Cedric led by example in terms of empathy and patient rapport..." His preceptor wrote: "Diggory is obviously a very thoughtful and critical observer. He was actively engaged in preceptor sessions. His contributions to the discussion showed that he was trying to process and analyze the clinical situations in which he was involved". He also demonstrated a desire to understand the various systems at play in the hospital and on the rotation. Another attending wrote "Cedric was very interested and engaged, not only with the patients to which he was assigned but also with all of the patients on the service. He had a lot of questions regarding both clinical and practical management of patients in the hospital, which showed he was thinking more broadly about how to enact health care in our current system". He was also thinking about ways to improve the clerkship, giving feedback respectfully and offering very reasonable suggestions for modifications (thanks again, Cedric!). "[Incredibly] eager to learn and take on an active role with the team", he accepted feedback graciously and used it to improve his performance. In addition, he "was always willing to help" and completed patient tasks reliably. These traits made him an effective member of his various teams. In sum, Cedric did an excellent job on the rotation.

Staff here at Stamford Hospital uniformly felt that Mr. Malfoy is an exceptional student.

Confident and personal, Draco readily demonstrated the ability to function independently, anticipating the needs of care team's to which he was assigned.  He has great situational awareness skills and in in for recognizing how he can contribute in a variety of clinical situations.

Draco's superior examination, presentation and documentation skills reflect a strong knowledge base, well beyond that expected at this level of training.  Is also flexible, demonstrating the ability to adjust his clinical approach to the needs of a given clinical situation- shortening time/length of notes and interviews during emergencies as well as returning for more in depth interviews/examination in cases of complexity.

Self-effacing and humble-staff reported that he was always ready to help, coming to each day with an attitude that "No task is  too small".  His enthusiasm was greatly appreciated by all.

It is our impression that Mr.Malfoy will be an outstanding resident.  We strongly wish him the best

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Lavender's baseline fund of knowledge was strong and she added to it over the weeks. Her clinical skills are developing well. One resident with whom she worked wrote "Lavender was a joy to work with. She was positive and eager to learn. I really got to see Lavender shine in the clinic setting. She took an in-depth history and focused medical history, gave an excellent focused but complete oral presentation. She was easy to work with, was able to anticipate the needs of her patients and seamlessly worked with the team to make sure her patients were cared for appropriately". Her clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an early manager. Submitted work included a well-researched, clearly written patient education pamphlet on prenatal care.
 
Lavender's interpersonal and communication skills are very strong. The proctor of her observed H&P noted she had "great" rapport with patients. Eager to learn and contribute, she made good use of medical literature and of feedback to improve her performance. She also demonstrated great enthusiasm in the OR! These traits made her a valued member of her various teams. 

In sum, Lavender did an excellent job on the rotation.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Pansy is a bright, reliable student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. Her baseline fund of knowledge was strong but she added it to it over the weeks, both by reading and by "asking great questions". Her clinical skills are developing well and she was observed to "obtain thorough histories with complex patients, perform physical exams and pap smears while maintaining patient comfort, and [write] cogent notes on her patient encounters". Her clinical reasoning skills were at the level of a manager. She wrote notes that required minimal editing. Her patient care presentations were "advanced", consistently highlighting her understanding of her patients and their key issues. Of her topic presentation, her preceptor wrote "Pansy did a great job in our small group sessions. She appeared to be an integral part of the team caring for the patient she presented in her case. She had an excellent grasp on her topic, PPH. She demonstrated this by her ability to effectively communicate her case presentation as well as discuss the important learning points of this topic to the rest of the small group. She was also able to correctly answer questions from her classmates. Job well done!" Submitted work included an informative, well organized patient education pamphlet on Gestational Diabetes.

Pansy's interpersonal and communication skills are excellent. She quickly developed rapport with a broad range of patients and demonstrated empathy in her interactions with them. She was also able to anticipate the needs of her patients, showing "holistic understanding of their care and condition". She is a "strong communicator with patients, as well as the team". Eager to learn and contribute, she was always ready to observe and assist in procedures. In addition, she was "prompt, professional and helpful on service" and "always comes prepared". She also "took initiative in the OR to assist with tasks without being asked". She accepted feedback graciously and used it to improve her performance. These traits made her an effective and valued member of her various teams. In sum, Pansy did an outstanding job on the rotation.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Vincent is an engaged, enthusiastic student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. His baseline fund of knowledge was solid and he added to it over the weeks. His clinical skills are developing well and was observed to obtain detailed patient histories and perform careful exams. His clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an interpreter. Patient care presentations became more "streamlined and focused" with practice. His formal presentation to his preceptor on vaginal bleeding in pregnancy was "excellent". Vincent's interpersonal and communication skills are excellent. A resident with whom he worked on the second half of the rotation wrote "I was impressed by his maturity and appropriateness with a variety of patient populations including those with difficult cancer diagnoses undergoing palliative care and patients of various demographics (requiring frequent use of translators). He was able to establish connections with many of our patients and they greatly appreciated his care. He also was proactive with helping our team with floor work and in the OR. We also had the opportunity to suture with him in the operating room and he was a quick learner with hands on skills. He is a star student with a combination of skills in both his clinical acumen and ability to establish rapport with the team and patients". Another evaluator from his GynOnc block wrote "I was really impressed by Vincent this block. He spent extra time staying late getting to know patients and understanding their needs, and was a wonderful patient liaison to our team". Eager to learn, Vincent made good use of feedback to improve performance. Hard-working and reliable, he always showed initiative and completed patient tasks reliably. These traits made him an effective member of his various teams. Submitted work included a very well researched, clearly written patient education pamphlet on Placenta Previa that was one of the better assignments in the group. In sum, Vincent did an excellent job on the rotation.

answer_text: Hermione is a bright, engaged student, and a stand-out in her group of peers. Her baseline fund of knowledge was excellent and she added to it over the weeks. A resident who worked with her on the Gyn Onc service noted "I had the opportunity to spend time with her and another oncology attending reviewing the details of uterine cancer and she demonstrated a level of knowledge surpassing even some of our sub-Is. We also worked together on suturing skills and she demonstrated she was willing and able to quickly learn on the spot. We hope she takes an interest in obgyn as she would make an excellent sub-I and intern". Her clinical skills are developing well and she was observed to obtain appropriate patient histories and perform careful, well focused exams. The proctor of her observed H&P noted she "does very well with obtaining details. Gathers and synthesizes details and boils [them] down to what's pertinent". Her clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an interpreter. Her patient presentations "are great; presents very minimal extraneous information". Her formal presentations were also excellent, especially an "honors level" presentation to her preceptor group. Hermione's interpersonal and communication skills are particularly strong and she was observed to develop wonderful rapport with her patients and her various clinical care teams. Evaluators noted she was an "active participant in all aspects of patient care, taking ownership of her patients". Eager to learn, she made good use of medical literature and of feedback to improve her performance. In addition, she always showed initiative and completed patient tasks reliably. These traits made her an effective, highly valued member of her various teams. Submitted work included a patient education portfolio on cervical cancer screening in young adults which highlighted her understanding of ASCCP guidelines, ability to translate medical jargon into patient-friendly language, and great sense of humor. In sum, Hermione did an outstanding job on the rotation.

Her clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an early manager. These traits made Ginny a valued and effective member of her various teams. Submitted work included a well-researched, comprehensive summary of PID for patients. In sum, Ginny did an outstanding job on the rotation. It is our sincere hope she will consider a career in OB/Gyn as we would love to have her as a colleague one day.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Luna is a standout in a group of strong peers. Her baseline fund of knowledge is excellent and she added to it over the weeks. Her clinical skills are developing well and she was observed to obtain "thorough" histories and perform accurate exams. In addition, she demonstrated "Good technical skills in OR". Her note writing "improved throughout the rotation". Her clinical reasoning skills were at the level of a manager for many of the conditions she encountered. Submitted work included a well-researched, clearly written patient education pamphlet on Pelvic Organ Prolapse. Genuinely enthusiastic about learning, she made good use of medical literature and actively sought out feedback, using it to improve her performance. In addition, she showed great initiative and completed patient tasks reliably. These traits made her an effective, highly valued member of her various teams. 

Her preceptor wrote "Luna was a very engaged and enthusiastic student in preceptor session. She chose a difficult topic for her preceptor presentation: TRAP sequence, and did an admirable job. I did not work with Luna in a clinical setting, but it was clear that she was a motivated participant with the team with which she was working".

A resident with whom she worked on her Gyn Onc block wrote: "Luna was a wonderful medical student on GYN ONC. She was a hard worker and went above and beyond on the floor to help with any tasks she could help with, frequently checking in with the team to see what else needed to be done. She took excellent histories in clinic and helped maintain an efficient flow. By the end of the rotation, she was able to deliver succinct oral presentations with minimal use of her notes." 

On her consult day, the resident with whom she worked wrote: "[she] was extremely efficient in seeing patients in the ER and was impressively ahead of her level in terms of formulating differentials and management plans. Her notes were also impressive especially for this early stage in the clinical year. She will be excellent in any field but should strongly consider ob/gyn!" 

Luna also shone on the OB half, inspiring one attending to write: "I worked with Luna on the labor floor for only one day, but I wish I could have worked with her more. She was enthusiastic, motivated and eager to learn. She was proactive about getting involved in deliveries and demonstrated a solid fund of knowledge. She was pleasant and professional in her demeanor and showed a strong interest in Ob/Gyn in the short time we worked together. I sincerely hope she will consider a second date with our specialty!" 

Finally, the fellow with whom she spent her elective day wrote "while our time was limited, she asked meaningful questions and demonstrated true interest in the field".

In sum, Luna is a star. She did an outstanding job on the rotation and we would love to have her as a colleague in our specialty one day.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Katie is a hard-working, highly motivated student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. Her baseline fund of knowledge was excellent and she added to it over the weeks. Her clinical skills are developing well and she was observed to obtain comprehensive histories and perform gentle, accurate exams. The proctor of her observed H&P wrote "Interacts with patients wonderfully... Asks clinically relevant questions and yet very efficient and empathetic". Her clinical reasoning skills were at the level of a manager. She also demonstrated strong basic skills in the OR including suturing, retraction and assisting with patient positioning. Katie is very "detail-oriented" and her notes were "consistently very strong", needing very little editing. Patient care presentations highlighted her understanding of her patients' key issues; and she "gave a thoughtful and thorough presentation on the postpartum visit and post partum depression" to her preceptor group.  Submitted work included a patient education pamphlet on postpartum contraception that wisely used current references and took the extra step of explaining why pregnancy spacing is important.

Katie's interpersonal and communication skills are superb. One evaluator wrote: "My interaction with Katie was limited to one day on consult however I was impressed by her compassion for patients and her history taking skills. We were with one particularly difficult patient who had a history of developmental delay and Katie was quick to pick up on using language and phrases at a level that would be understood by the patient. She navigated the difficult patient interview with poise and patience".  

Eager to learn, she made use of medical literature and always "took the extra time to prepare cases and learn about the patients she was taking care of".  She was also "very responsive" to feedback, immediately incorporating suggestions for improving her performance. She always showed initiative and completed patient tasks reliably. These traits made her a "tremendous asset" to her various teams, especially as she "needed very little supervision or guidance. She continuously found ways to be helpful without overdoing it, and offered to perform tedious work related tasks without prompting". 

In sum, Katie did an outstanding job on the rotation.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text:
Dudley is  an outstanding student will be an excellent physician  and a credit to the institution. His sense of professionalism deserve special comment as Dudley was part of a group of students who candidly and with great compassion communicated their concerns regarding the learning environment for our residents dimrectly and candidly prior to the completion of their rotation. This communication was made out of deepest concern  for the well-being of our staff at for the well-being of their fellow students. This degree of professionalism deserves to be acknowledged and represents a quality to which all of our students and faculty should aspire.

To be considered for honors, exam scores needed to fall within 1 SD of the national mean (Shelf) and group mean (OSCE)

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Staff uniforms reported that Mr Dudley is an outstanding student.  It was a privilege to host him during his recent OBGYN clerkship here.

Simply phrased, Dudley is "the whole package".  Staff at all levels reported that he functioned at the level of an international, in all aspects, during his rotation with us.  

He is extremely intelligent, with advanced, history-taking, exam and presentation skills. His material assistance in one particularly complicated obstetrical case was particularly noted by nursing and resident staff.  

Our nursing staff requested that we formally acknowledge Dudley's strong sense of empathy and his dedication to the care of patients in the second stage of labor.

A number of attending staff, in multiple disciplines, thought that Dudley was one of our new interns.

Resident and nursing staff noted that, during an emergency case, Dudley effectively managed the labor board at in intern level- continuing to check in on patients, answer physician calls and facilitate effective communication within the team.

We feel that Dudley is an extraordinary student- he will be an outstanding physician, in any discipline.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Seamus is a bright, eager student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. His baseline fund of knowledge was solid and he added to it over the weeks. His clinical skills are developing well and he was observed to obtain "comprehensive" patient histories and perform careful exams. In addition, the proctor of his observed H&P complimented his "superb" bedside manner. Seamus's clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an interpreter. His patient care presentations were "succinct but conveyed all appropriate information"; and his presentation to his preceptor group was a "phenomenal case presentation, thorough with differential diagnosis and explanations why each would apply or not". 

Seamus's interpersonal and communication skills are areas of particular strength. One resident who worked with him on both halves of the rotation commented "Excellent performance... He showed a lively interest and high level of engagement on the rotation. His presentation skills are strong - articulate, thorough, and able to form cogent plans. He was well prepared for the OR and studied patient's histories and general pelvic anatomy". Another evaluator noted he had especially strong situational awareness. While "willing to jump in and learn", he was also "respectful of team and patient dynamics (i.e. knows when to jump in and when to step back)". His preceptor noted he was "[extremely] empathetic to patients and their needs... should consider [Ob/Gyn] as a career path".
Eager to learn, made use of medical literature and of feedback to improve performance. These traits him made an effective member of his various teams. 

Submitted work included a well-researched, clearly written patient education pamphlet on Gestational Diabetes. 

In sum, Seamus did an excellent job on the rotation.
