answer_text:
Lee is a compassionate, empathic student, who was a pleasure to have on the rotation. His baseline fund of knowledge was solid and he added to it over the weeks. His clinical skills are developing well and he was observed to obtain appropriate histories and perform careful exams. His clinical reasoning skills were at the level of an early manager. His patient care presentations were well organized. A presentation to his preceptor group on the management of psychiatric conditions in pregnancy was "excellent". Submitted work included a patient education pamphlet on Postpartum Depression that had a lovely, reassuring tone. 

Lee' interpersonal and communication skills are excellent. Resident evaluators noticed he was "engaged and sensitive to his patients' concerns" and "showed extraordinary compassion and empathy in sensitive situations". On one occasion, he easily established rapport with a nervous patient before her Gyn procedure, calming her anxieties and making "quite the impression" on her. These traits made him an effective member of his various teams.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text:
1.	Professionalism. At orientation, students are instructed to email the clerkship director, psmcy and their resident team when they are out sick. Several evaluators submitted versions of the following: "There is one morning where he was sick and did not inform the team that he was not coming to his cases until he was contacted by a team member. This to me shows a lack of professionalism. When contacted about why he was not at the hospital his response was plainly "I'm sick" and showed no real insight into the fact that he should have made contact with the team to explain his absence sooner".
2.	Lee can continue to read to expand his fund of knowledge.
3.	One evaluator wrote "He was pleasant and on the quieter side. In my few interactions with him I would have liked if he would have generated more questions ad discussion to show he was engaged". This is not a sentiment that was repeated, but is reported to share an impression that was created.

Final Score 3.28 (Clinical 3.65, Shelf 2, Pamphlet 2.875)

answer_text:
Katie was universally perceived as a "wonderful," "important," and "impressive" member of the team. 

She was noted to have detailed and appropriate histories and physical examinations, with one attending remarking how in caring for multiple patients with the same chief complaint (abdominal pain), Katie appropriately teased out relevant details of the illness scripts and examinations to arrive at sound assessments and differential diagnoses that reflect her fund of knowledge. 

Her patient management was noted to be at the level of a "strong intern," with one faculty member noting that she often forgot Katie was not a resident. She was noted to do well with multi-tasking 2-3 active patients at a time, calling consulting services, and updating patients and families. Residents also commented that both her fund of knowledge and management skills developed over the course of the month. 

Faculty remarked that Katie was a good team player, with a cheerful attitude that was appreciated during taxing/stressful ED case loads. She was noted to be kind and caring with families. 

Katie was "always professional," arriving promptly before the beginning of her shift and introducing herself to team members. Faculty, fellows, and residents commented that it would be a pleasure to have her at CHONY as a resident.

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Katie was an outstanding sub-intern in the pediatric ICU. Her presentations were clear, well organized and easily showcased her meticulous preparation for rounds. She became a well respected member of our team and her work was well regarded by our residents, fellow and nurses. She will have a bright future in pediatrics. Superb job!

Excellent performance in the PICU sub-internship. Presentations were complete, well-organized and well beyond current level of training. Good clinical judgement and well thought out treatment plans.
Pleasure to teach.

Katie performed very well in the Pediatric ICU. I was the service attending at the beginning and the end of her rotation and she make remarkable growth over the one month period. Specifically, her patient presentations were at the level of mid-year pediatric intern, she was able to formulate excellent plans on her patient at the level of a resident and she was an active learner. She always knew everything about her patients and used literature to create excellent plans of care. She handled the stress of a busy PICU very well and worked well as a team member. I often forgot she was a Sub-I given her maturity, knowledge base and strong clinical performance. I know she will make an excellent pediatrician and hope she will consider pediatric critical care medicine in the future. Any residency would be extremely lucky to have her.

It was a pleasure working with Katie as a sub-I in the PICU. The PICU can be an intimidating place with complex patients but Katie stepped up to the plate taking on difficult patients and taking true ownership of their care at a resident level. Her presentations were on point and she was making plans for patients in an impressive manner. Nurses trusted her to be first call which is rare. She was also pleasant to work with and team player.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Hermione Granger fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Hermione displayed excellent ability in her patient care activities in all settings of this rotation.  She was committed to providing comprehensive patient care and challenged herself to take ownership of her patients to the greatest extent possible.  "Hermione is an intelligent and hard-working student who did a fantastic job during her pediatric cardiology rotation. She is thorough in her histories and physicals and presented very well on rounds."  "Hermione did a wonderful job, especially for her first rotation in MCY. She clearly read about her patients and asked appropriate questions when necessary. Her presentations for her level of training were very good, and I anticipate she will be able to further refine and shorten them as time passes. She understood a medical student's role on the team and appropriately asked for tasks she could help with." Notes were timely, and Hermione was always able to efficiently finish her daily work.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Hermione's fund of knowledge was judged to meet, and at times exceed expectations for her level of training. She was often able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting. "Hermione is an excellent student! She consistently presented her patients from memory and took full ownership of her patients. She was very interested in learning and will do very well as she continues her clinical year. She was a pleasure to work with!" She scored just below the group average and below the national mean on the NBME shelf exam. 

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Hermione was committed to outside reading during the clerkship in an effort to build a broad base of pediatric knowledge and deepen her experiential learning.  She was eager and hungry for all learning opportunities.  "Hermione was a wonderful addition to our pediatric cardiology team. She followed very complex patients and took the time to learn about every detail of their care. She formulated detailed plans with little assistance and had advanced presentation skills, especially for her first rotation. She was confident but also knew when to ask for help. On a busy day she was incredibly helpful with team tasks, volunteering to transport a patient to radiology and helping with performing bedside EKGs."  Her case write-up of a patient with complex cardiac disease who was awaiting transplant and developed hyperglycemia and epistaxis patient was of excellent quality.  She was an engaged member of her team-based learning group and she enriched both small-group and large-group discussions.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Collaboration: 
Hermione consistently created excellent rapport and therapeutic relationships with her patients and displayed superb interpersonal skills.  

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Hermione consistently placed her patients' needs before her own, while balancing her own need to learn in the clinical setting.  "Hermione was a very motivated, enthusiastic and hard-working student, who improved steadily throughout the clerkship. It was a pleasure to teach Hermione."  She was on time and present for all clerkship activities.

Systems-based Practice: 
Hermione was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  "Hermione did a great job, especially considering this was her first rotation in MCY. She was enthusiastic in learning about her patients, eager to receive feedback, and was always looking to help out the team. Her presentation skills got better and better as the clerkship went on."

Hermione is a motivated individual who was dedicated to sharpening her pediatric clinical skill set and her ability to deliver comprehensive patient care.  Without fail she took ownership for her patients and made significant contributions to the healthcare team.  Her enthusiasm and self-direction were welcomed and appreciated by the health care team.  She is well on her way to becoming an outstanding clinician.

NBME Student Score - 67   Group Mean - 68.7   National Quartile Mean - 75.1 (SD 8.6)

The following suggestions were made for Penelope regarding areas for improvement:

"Penelope was less enthusiastic about doing patient care tasks and helping me with work for the day for her patients. I never focused too much on this as she was clearly a fantastic medical student and never once did I see her "sitting around," but looking back, I would have reinforced the kind of hands on learning one can receive from updating pediatricians, speaking to nurses about plans, and even helping a patient be more comfortable."

"Her presentations were good; I would challenge her to make them more succinct."

"If I were to offer any constructive criticism, it would be on this front - as she moves forward, to be cautious about remaining a "team player" and striking the appropriate balance between her eagerness and performance, and supporting those around her."

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative for Weasley (Ginny) Ginny during her Pediatric Clerkship:

Patient care: Ginny displayed outstanding ability 
in her approach to patient care in all settings of this rotation. Although her first MCY rotation Ginny was committed to providing thoughtful patient care and readily took ownership of her patients. Her service attending noted "Her presentation was so succinct that I thought she was on her last clinical rotation and was pleasantly surprised to know that it was her first. She asked appropriate questions and actively participated in rounds." She is naturally curious and was an active participant in discussion and management of patients not only on the floor but in the PICU as well."

Knowledge for Practice: Ginny's fund of knowledge was judged to exceed expectations for her level of training. She was able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting in a meaningful way from day one implying that she had prepared for this rotation. She continued to work throughout the 6 weeks and excelled not only in the clinical realm but also in testing.  TBL scores and engagement were excellent and her SHELF score was well above class and national average.  Very impressive.

Practice-based learning: Ginny was clearly committed to reading throughout the clerkship in an effort to build a broad base of pediatric knowledge.  She was prepared in each area of the clerkship"Óinpatient, ED and outpatient.  One example noted by her clinic attending: "Ms. Ginny did a very good job seeing an adolescent girl with a chronic history of headache presenting with worsening headache. Ms. Ginny's write-up captured both the long standing history of symptoms and the acuteness of new headache symptoms for which she came to be seen in the walk-in clinic. I offered an article on pediatric headache for her to read and afterwards we had a lively discussion on the differential diagnosis of headache." She brought articles to rounds and gave presentation during the rotation. Her write up of a child admitted with clinical pneumonia was succinct but complete in the H&P while the discussion captured all aspects of the respiratory complaint.  Exemplary write up.


Interpersonal/Communication skills and Interprofessional Collaboration: Ginny displayed good interpersonal skills and created relationships with families and the team. Although a quiet person she was able to connect with parents and patients of all ages to not only obtain necessary information via history and PE but also to relate pertinent information to patients in a clear and understandable way.

Professionalism and Personal Development: Ginny was punctual, motivated and professional in all settings of the rotation, and she easily accepted responsibility for patients. She was receptive to feedback that was integrated into her educational and clinical experience.

Systems based practice: Ginny was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  

Overall, Ginny performed exceptionally well in this clerkship. Although quiet, she is a highly motivated individual who was enthusiastic about clinical work and displayed dedication to learning pediatrics and participating in patient care.   She took ownership for her patients and made significant contributions to the healthcare team in all areas of the clerkship.  Ginny is a self-motivated mature and confident student. She is able to process information, formulate differential diagnosis and treatment plans with aplomb. She was an important part of the team in all three settings of the rotation, was helpful in patient care in in the team's education. She has a kind professional manner with patients and is able to communicate in a clear and understandable way. She has an important blend of critical thinking and compassion that will allow her to care for patients thoughtfully and.  Ginny impressed in her first rotation and will continue to excel to evolve into an outstanding clinician.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Neville Longbottom fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Neville displayed excellent ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation.  He was dedicated to his patients and their families and he worked tirelessly on their behalf.  He strived to take ownership for his patients and their medical issues.  "Neville was a great addition to our pediatric cardiology team. He worked hard to understand the complex cardiac lesions and comorbidities of his patients. He took great care in formulating plans for his patients. He was sensitive, calm and had a great bedside manner."  "Neville is an extremely intelligent compassionate student who is committed to learning and providing and excellent care to his patients."  "I was impressed with his conscientiousness and diligence and he really seemed to enjoy himself." Neville was able to report on and interpret patient status and, at times, showed stirrings of managing patient care.  At their best, his presentations were on-point and lucid. Neville was attentive to the details of patient care and he routinely finished his daily tasks.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Neville's fund of knowledge was judged to meet, and at times exceed expectations for his level of training and he was usually able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting.  He scored below both the group average and the national mean on the NBME shelf exam.

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Neville was clearly reading throughout the rotation and built a broad base of pediatric knowledge that he shared with the team at all appropriate moments.  "Neville made excellent progress in his inpatient pediatric rotation. His presentations improved and, as the rotation progressed, he asked more and better questions. It is obvious that he follows his patients closely and thinks about them critically."  His inpatient write-up of an adolescent with sudden cardiac arrest was of excellent quality. Neville covered the basics of the approach to the patient and gave a nuanced differential that was well referenced.  Neville was an engaged member of his team-based learning group and participated in all of the phases of the group problem solving process.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Development: 
Neville has excellent interpersonal and communication skills and he created warm and therapeutic relationships with patients and their families.  "Despite limited opportunities for independent work in our setting, Neville consistently developed rapport with patients/families and paid close attention (as he was asked to) to developmental details. Followed up on clinical questions/issues without being asked to do so."  Neville was deemed a key contributor to the health care team by patients, families, and his co-workers.  

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Neville always attempted to put the needs of his patients and families above his own.  "Very good attitude. Hard worker and responsible. Level of knowledge good for his stage of training."  He was on time and prepared for all clerkship activities.  

Systems-based Practice: 
Neville was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  

Neville displayed a thoughtful and committed approach to patient care in all settings of the rotation.  He challenged himself to bond with families and develop therapeutic relationships with his patients.  He is a motivated learner and was committed to improving his fundamental clinical skills and deepening his fund of knowledge. He is well on his way to becoming an excellent clinician.

question:

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Penelope Clearwater fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Penelope displayed excellent to outstanding ability in her patient care activities in all settings of this rotation.  She was deeply committed to providing comprehensive patient care and challenged herself to take ownership of her patients to the greatest extent possible.  "Penelope truly impressed me daily. By the end of our two weeks on Cardiology, I felt her to be more of a colleague rather than a medical student in her first block of MCY. She is self-motivated and constantly found opportunities to learn and teach throughout the day. She did not waste much time and was proactive, whether she was with her patients or helping her fellow medical students review concepts/topics in pediatrics. She is assertive and has confident demeanor, and thus it was easy to trust her with tasks. Penelope went above and beyond to know every detail of her patient's history. Impressively, she was able to understand the big picture concepts very well and put together the often complicated history puzzles of our cardiology patients. Her fund of knowledge is excellent, which is a testament to her hard work. Lastly, Penelope always circled back to the patient and their family."  "Penelope is way beyond her level. Her history taking, presentation and overall clinical skills are those of a MSIV! She consistently took initiative in both patient care and learning. She would read extensively about her patients and their conditions and educate the team when appropriate."  "I was thoroughly impressed with Penelope's performance in this portion of her clerkship - even as she presented her very first case of MCY year, she was performing at a level I would expect of a sub-I, or perhaps an intern! I was able to precept Penelope personally for 3 or 4 patients, and her patient histories and physical examinations included a thorough level of detail that reflect her strong fund of knowledge (i.e., in a patient with headache, obtaining history of floaters, palpating sinuses, performing forward bend, etc.). Her presentations were superbly organized (again at a level far beyond where she is in her education), and even on day 1, she offered management plans that were supported by evidence that she cited. She demonstrates a commitment to being a superlative practitioner. Morever, after offering a management plan (for a patient with ankle sprain), she subsequently personally wheeled her patient to radiology when a tech was not available, demonstrating an ownership of patient care. Such gestures reflect her professionalism and adaptation of professional identity. Her fund of knowledge also shone through during small-group didactics, when she knew the answer to every - literally, every - question posed, and I could tell that she would try and hold back to give her colleagues a chance to answer."  Notes were timely, presentations were consistently on-point, and Penelope was always able to efficiently finish her daily work.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Penelope's fund of knowledge was judged to meet, and at times exceed expectations for her level of training. She was often able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting. "Penelope was an excellent addition to our pediatric cardiology service. She clearly has great interest in cardiology and congenital heart defects - and has experience and knowledge that greatly contributed to the team. With her experiences in adult cardiology, she introduced the team to software that reconstructed cardiac CT into a 3D model - greatly helping the residents and medical students visualize a complex cardiac defect. She has great enthusiasm and is always asking for more information and insightful questions. I'd encourage her to continue this excitement to learn - and keep her curiosity broad to make the most of her clerkship year." She scored above the group average and below the national mean on the NBME shelf exam. 

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Penelope was committed to outside reading during the clerkship in an effort to build a broad base of pediatric knowledge and deepen her experiential learning.  She was eager and hungry for all learning opportunities.  "Penelope knew her patients inside and out. She was able to connect with several patients and their families. She learned from her patients and ask many great questions."  Her case write-up of an adolescent with complex cardiac disease status post transplant was subperb.  She demonstrated a sound approach to the diagnosis and management for this dangerous condition and made certain to have a carefully referenced write-up that discussed the differential and management of the patient.  She was an engaged and vocal member of her team-based learning group and she enriched both small-group and large-group discussions.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Collaboration: 
Penelope consistently created excellent rapport and therapeutic relationships with her patients and displayed superb interpersonal skills.  "The mother of one of Penelope's patients, who herself was just diagnosed with a DVT, days before her daughter's emergent heart surgery. Penelope took time to help the mother of this patient, recognizing the importance of the health and wellbeing of the entire family. I found her to relate well with patients and dig deeper." 

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Penelope consistently placed her patients' needs before her own, while balancing her own need to learn in the clinical setting.  "Penelope is very bright qand self confident and exudes this when seeing patients who seem to really trust her."  She was on time and present for all clerkship activities.

Systems-based Practice: 
Penelope was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  "The interns on the team specifically commented on how great Penelope was at identifying areas where she could be helpful - volunteering to make phone calls and even gathering more detailed history, finding out PMDs, pouring over outside record - which she had identified as a need on rounds and taken the initiative to do for the benefit of the team without being asked. She is very hardworking and will continue to do well as a med student and will make a very good resident."

Penelope is a highly motivated individual who was dedicated to sharpening her pediatric clinical skill set and her ability to deliver comprehensive patient care.  Without fail she took ownership for her patients and made significant contributions to the healthcare team.  Her enthusiasm and self-direction were welcomed and appreciated by the health care team.  She is well on her way to becoming an outstanding clinician.

*******************************************

answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Cho Chang fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Cho displayed excellent ability in her patient care activities in all settings of this rotation.  She was extremely committed to providing comprehensive patient care and challenged herself to take ownership of her patients to the greatest extent possible.  "Cho did a great job with her first rotation. She developed confidence throughout and I would encourage her to continue to put herself in new positions to expand her skill set. She showed a strong ability to "read the room" which stood out and will serve her well throughout her career."  "It was a pleasure to work with Cho during her first clinical rotation. She did a wonderful job in getting to know her role as a medical student on the team and was very proactive in helping gain more history from the patients that she followed. Her presentations showed significant improvement as the three weeks progressed and demonstrated that she could be trusted in accomplishing various tasks for her patients."  Notes were timely, presentations were consistently on-point, and Cho was always able to efficiently finish her daily work.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Cho's fund of knowledge was judged to meet, and at times exceed expectations for her level of training. She was often able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting. "She scored below both the group average and the national mean on the NBME shelf exam. 

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Cho was committed to outside reading during the clerkship in an effort to build a broad base of pediatric knowledge and deepen her experiential learning.  She was eager and hungry for all learning opportunities.  "Cho is adjusting to the clinical environment. She is eager and open-minded. She was responded well to direct feedback about using medical jargon and the following day her presentation was better. She later had an adolescent with chronic back pain, and advocated for her during rounds, which is unique for an early level medical student. She gave a presentation on hypernatremia and I recommended to her that she try to keep her wards presentations case-based in the future."  "Cho did a great job on her pediatrics rotation. She was thoroughly invested in her patients' health and well-being, including both physical and emotional/psychiatric aspects. Her presentation skills improved dramatically during the first two weeks of this (her first) rotation, and although there is still room for improvement (ie: editing to include only pertinent information), her presentations are at an appropriate level for her current training. She had a good fund of knowledge, but was also willing to admit the limits of her knowledge and showed interest in investigating topics without prompting, all of which will benefit her in the future."  Her case write-up of a patient with rash, arthralgia and abdominal pain was of excellent quality.  She demonstrated a sound approach to the diagnosis and management for this condition and her discussion was nuanced and well-referenced.  She was an engaged member of her team-based learning group and she enriched both small-group and large-group discussions.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Collaboration: 
Cho consistently created excellent rapport and therapeutic relationships with her patients and displayed superb interpersonal skills.  "Having Cho as a team member was great. She always came in with a smile on her face and motivated to learn. During her few weeks on inpatient pediatrics she really made great progress in her presentation skills and by the end consistently had succinct, clear and accurate patient presentations on rounds. She was also very helpful to us as interns and a great team player" 

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Cho consistently placed her patients' needs before her own, while balancing her own need to learn in the clinical setting.  "Cho was an excellent student who was always extremely interested in her cases and enjoyed working with children and families."  She was on time and present for all clerkship activities.

Systems-based Practice: 
Cho was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  "Cho is bright, positive and eager to learn. She took initiative in seeing patients and presenting."

Cho is a motivated individual who was dedicated to developing her pediatric clinical skill set and her ability to deliver comprehensive patient care.  She took ownership for her patients and made significant contributions to the healthcare team.  Her enthusiasm and self-direction were welcomed and appreciated by the health care team.  She is well on her way to becoming an outstanding clinician.

question:

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Pansy Parkinson fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation. 

Patient care: Pansy displayed excellent ability in her patient care activities in all settings of this rotation.  She challenged herself to take ownership of her patients and successfully managed common pediatric problems with ease. One ER attending noted "At times, one might have confused Pansy for a new intern. One of her very first patients was a young boy who presented with a second episode of a seizure like activity. Pansy was able to obtain a through history and complete physical exam. She developed a broad differential and followed all his lab results."  

Knowledge for Practice: Pansy's fund of knowledge was judged to exceed expectations for her level of training. She clearly read throughout the rotation and applied her knowledge to clinical practice. She scored well above average on the NBME shelf and her TBL scores were excellent.

Practice-based learning: Pansy was committed to learning and improving in response to the clinical experiences she was having.  She required little direction. "She has natural intellectual curiosity, which makes rounds interesting with active discussion." "Pansy was interested in presenting a variety of cases. She constantly participated in case discussion" One of her clinic preceptor noted "Pansy has a very logical approach to her oral presentations and a well organized thought process when doing her write-ups. I greatly enjoyed discussing cases with her including guidelines for myringotomy tubes and the evaluation of heart murmurs. During two sessions in Continuity Clinic Pansy asked very good questions and showed understanding of the elements of well child care & immunizations."  This is demonstrative of her effort each day. She gave several presentations on head trauma, hematuria and the PECARN study"Óall were very well done and relevant. Her write up of an infant with conjunctivitis was complete in the history and physical exam sections. Her discussion of the need for neonatal eye prophylaxis was an interesting choice and included issues around the benefit and results of the practice.

Interpersonal and Communication skills/professional collaboration: Pansy possesses excellent interpersonal and communication skills.  Her professional, warm and kind manner was noted by everyone who worked with her. She was eager to learn and actively participate in patient care.  She easily assimilated into the ER, clinic and floor working well with fellow students and residents. One ER attending noted "She displays great empathy for her patients and has strong communication skills. She was noted to stay back after the end of her shifts to obtain resolution for her patients."

Professionalism and Personal Development: Pansy worked diligently on her patients' behalf.  She was engaged in all areas of the rotation, asked many questions and presented herself as a confident young physician. She was always present, ready to participate in patient care.
 
System based learning.  Pansy worked to understand and access the EMR. She worked within the sometimes difficult hospital system to provide the best care for her patients. .

Overall, Pansy excelled as a clerk in the pediatric rotation and was an important contributor to our team.  She was dedicated to patient care and worked diligently to learn a pediatric skill set. Pansy was able to function autonomously with ease and cheerfulness. She has genuine empathy, compassion and passion for patient care and learning that is evident in all interactions.  Pansy is that rare combination of intellectual excellence, empathy, kindness and passion for learning that will ensure her development into an exemplary physician.

****************************************************

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Luna Lovegood fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.

Patient care: Luna displayed excellent ability in her patient care activities in all areas of the rotation.  She challenged herself to take ownership of her patients and performed as if she was the primary physician.  An ER attending noted "Excellent notes that focus on pertinent findings and aspects of PE and relays train of thought behind differentials and management."  The floor team noted her motivation and interest in patient care and management stating that "she has an exceptional set of communication skills and did very well in coordinating the care of the patients she was taking care of." Her senior resident commented "we had a sick patient with HIV  myocarditis in the PIC and I was very impressed by Luna's ability to build rapport with the family and be comfortable to sit with them and get a history on her own initiative."

Knowledge for Practice: Luna's fund of knowledge was judged to meet and exceed expectations for her level of training. She was able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting and to develop appropriate differential diagnoses. She worked to learn pediatrics and scored at about the class average on the NBME shelf exam and below the natioanl average.  Her individual TBL scores were strong and above the class average.

Practice-based learning: Luna was committed to learning and improving in response to clinical experiences. She used the rotation assignments to expand her knowledge. She has a solid foundation of excellent history taking and physical exam skills. She was proactive in reading and presenting to the inpatient team. She gave a presentation on pneumonia, preseptal and septal cellulitis and HIV medications and side effects.   Her write up of a child with HIV presenting with respiratory distress was very well done.  Her discussion focused on the differential that included both cardiac and respiratory diagnoses.  Her discussion was well formulated and well referenced.

Interpersonal and Communication skills/Professional Collaboration: Luna possesses very good interpersonal and communication skills.  She was able to create comfortable rapport and therapeutic relationships with her patients and their families independently.  As on of her supervisors noted, ""÷Luna has a very pleasant and friendly personality that made her get along very well with all team members." She was able to effectively articulate to patients and families illness processes, complications and therapy.

Professionalism and Personal Development: Luna worked consistently on behalf of her patients in all areas of the rotation. She was motivated to learn and to teach.  She functioned as a primary provider.  In the outpatient setting she  saw many patients efficiently with focused histories and physicals and was able to communicate with parents without much oversight. She was very open to feedback and incorporated suggestions effectively.

Systems based practice: Luna worked well as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care and was able to function independently.

Overall, Luna demonstrated a compassionate commitment to her patients. She is a quiet but thoughtful student who demonstrated great motivation to learn and participate in patient care.  She has excellent critical thinking skills good physical exam and diagnostic skills. She is able to communicate well with patients and fellow clinicians with patience and empathy. She will be an outstanding clinician.

**************************************
Luna Lovegood

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Seamus Finnigan fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.

Patient care: Seamus displayed very good to excellent ability in his patient care activities in all settings of this rotation. To the best of his ability he took ownership of his patients and performed as if he was their primary physician. Initially, Seamus was not as confident in his ability to work with children but with feedback and motivation he made steady progress throughout the rotation.  Preceptors saw that he was able to eventually take full ownership of inpatients. He is conscientious, diligent and interested in all aspects of pediatric care and worked hard to improve his H&P and presentations.   He was active in patient management and made contributions to the team with articles regarding treatment and management.

Knowledge for Practice: Seamus's fund of knowledge was judged to meet expectations for his level of training. He was able to correlate basic science principles to some clinical settings and worked to improve his fund of knowledge.  One attending noted "He has a good fund of knowledge, and is using his basic science knowledge and previous rotations to help to improve his knowledge base."   He scored above class average and below the national mean on the NBME shelf exam.  His individual TBL scores were excellent and his individual and group means were below the class average.  

Practice-based learning: Seamus was dedicated to learning and improving in response to clinical experiences. He gave several presentations one on peritonsillar/retropharyngeal abscess on the inpatient service that were clinically based and well received. His write up of a patient with sickle cell disease and aplastic crisis due to parvovirus was very well presented, the formulation focused and the discussion practical and relevant--well done.
  
Interpersonal and Communication Skills/Professional Collaboration: Seamus possesses excellent interpersonal and communication skills. He worked well with team members, patients and parents. He has a very kind and gentle demeanor with patients and was able to engender confidence. 

Professionalism and Personal Development: Seamus worked to improve himself throughout the rotation.  Initially Seamus was somewhat hesitant to take on patients but as the rotation evolved he became more confident. As noted by one of his outpatient attendings "Seamus was pro-active to ask for feedback from me on his write-up. We spent time discussing ways for him to improve integrating pertinent positives and negatives from the history & physical exam in his discussion of how we went through the differential diagnosis and then arriving to the final diagnosis. Seamus was very open to accepting of constructive criticism." He worked to improve his physical exam and presentation skills and was facile by the completion of the rotation.

Systems based practice: Seamus was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.
 
Seamus is a diligent, thoughtful and introspective student.  He worked conscientiously to improve his physical examination skills, clinical assessments and overall interaction with children. He became confident as the rotation evolved and demonstrated his mastery of the pediatric skill set. Seamus has a gentle demeanor, he is extremely dedicated and passionate about becoming a good clinician. He has an innate kindness that is noted by parents and patients engendering confidence and openness. Seamus's great empathy and passion for children combined with his diligence and dedication with make him a great physician and hopefully pediatrician.

**************************************************

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Patil Parvati fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Patil displayed excellent to outstanding ability in her patient care activities in all settings of this rotation.  She was deeply committed to providing comprehensive patient care and challenged herself to take ownership of her patients to the greatest extent possible.  "Patil is an exemplary student and was a wonderful addition to the team. She always knew what was going on with her patients. She tailored her presentations to what was most appropriate for the environment/team (for example, if the presentation was in front of a family, she used language that they would understand). She read the literature about her patients and did a great job informing the team about the differential of possible immunodeficiency diagnoses in one of her patients. She really went above and beyond in terms of doing tasks for her patients. She obtained records from outside hospitals, stayed late to help with last minute discharges, and more! She really was an integral member of our team and her contribution was quite helpful. Patil is also a lovely person and we really enjoyed having her rotate with us."  "Patil was a pleasure to have on this rotation. She was friendly, engaged, and cared about her patients. Her presentations were comprehensive, yet succinct. Her plans were thorough and well thought out. She always knew her patients well and took the time to get to know their families. She was engaged and eager to learn. She gave a great presentation the last day of the rotation. I'm confident Patil will be a wonderful doctor and great asset to any team moving forward."  Notes were timely, presentations were consistently on-point, and Patil was always able to efficiently finish her daily work.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Patil's fund of knowledge was judged to meet, and at times exceed expectations for her level of training. She was often able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting. "Patil was dedicated and passionate about taking care of her patients. She helped to take care of an infant with many subspecialists consulting and with a complex social situation. On rounds, she remained organized and concise despite the many teams involved in her patient's care. It was clear to me that she knew her patients well and that she had a good sense of the big picture. She was enthusiastic about independently reading and learning about her patients - she gave the team an excellent presentation on various immune deficiencies that we suspected one of her patients might have had. Patil was never afraid to jump in and help the team, even with patients that she was not primarily following, especially with translating for families on rounds." She scored below both the group average and the national mean on the NBME shelf exam. 

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Patil was committed to outside reading during the clerkship in an effort to build a broad base of pediatric knowledge and deepen her experiential learning.  She was eager and hungry for all learning opportunities.  "Patil is a thoughtful, intelligent student and was a genuine pleasure with whom to work. She is hardworking and proactive and immediately felt like a member of the team. The rotation only gave us two weeks to work together due to the timing of the shelf exam but together we were able to identify an additional clinic day to give her a more complete Pediatric experience. Not many students, especially those without a voiced interest in Pediatrics, would choose to do an extra clinic day but Patil did so enthusiastically. She was great with the patients and families, highly professional, communicated well with me and with the team, was always on time and completed her work in a thorough yet efficient manner. I'd happily work with her again."  Her case write-up of an infant who presented with gastroenteritis and neck and flank masses associated with MSSA bacteremia was strong.  She demonstrated a sound approach to the diagnosis and management for and went into detail regarding immunodeficiencies.  Would have liked to see more regarding the case resolution.  She was an engaged member of her team-based learning group and she enriched both small-group and large-group discussions.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Collaboration: 
Patil consistently created excellent rapport and therapeutic relationships with her patients and displayed superb interpersonal skills.  "Patil was exceedingly warm, gracious and affable. She really enjoyed working with her patients and seemed to really enjoy pediatrics," 

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Patil consistently placed her patients' needs before her own, while balancing her own need to learn in the clinical setting.  "I absolutely loved working with Patil this month. She was incredibly professional at all times but also fun and upPatilt. She made sure to pick an interesting range of patients to follow and kept up with all of their care. I had the great experience of working with her on nights and she took care of important tasks as well as brought energy to the team. Her presentations were always thorough without being overly detailed. I hope to work with her again!"  She was on time and present for all clerkship activities.

Systems-based Practice: 
Patil was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  "Patil was wonderful to work with. She was engaged and took great initiative to learn from the team and participate in patient care. She took her presentations seriously and reviewed them with the intern she was working with before rounds. This attention to detail made her presentations excellent and very well organized. She is kind and compassionate and integrated very well with the team. She volunteered to help whenever she could and this did not go unnoticed."

Patil is a highly motivated individual who was dedicated to sharpening her pediatric clinical skill set and her ability to deliver comprehensive patient care.  Without fail she took ownership for her patients and made significant contributions to the healthcare team.  Her enthusiasm and self-direction were welcomed and appreciated by the health care team.  She is well on her way to becoming an outstanding clinician.


**************************************
NBME Student Score - 63  Group Mean - 75.1   National Quartile Mean - 76.6 (SD 8.5)

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Vincent Crabbe fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Vincent showed excellent to outstanding ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation and he clearly developed a solid approach to pediatric care during this clerkship.  "Andew was an exceptional student who was a real team player. Always interested in learning and ready to take on additional responsibilities for his own education and to help out the team. He knew his patients well and provided excellent care. His presentations were very organized, concise, and above expected for his level."  "Vincent was an outstanding addition to our team. He was eager to learn each day, and consistently up to date on his patients' clinical status. His presentations were accurate and succinct, and adaptable to many situations. He was quick to offer assistance to the team during rounds and in the afternoons. He incorporated feedback about his presentation style and overall performance well throughout the clerkship." "Vincent was mature, confident, had excellent history taking skills, and was able to form very complete differentials."  "Vincent was amazing in our pediatric cardiology rotation. His presentations were very thorough and he had a wonderful bedside manner. In addition, he always asked very thoughtful questions that helped the team as a whole, learn. He did everything that was asked of him and more. He took on new patients, presented them fully, and worked with the residents to make sure everything was done for the patient. He stayed late without asking and had a inspiring love for learning. It was great working with him and he will make an amazing doctor."  Vincent was a reliable reporter and interpreter of patient information and challenged himself to take an even greater role in patient management.  Notes were thorough and timely and Vincent consistently and efficiently finished all daily tasks.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Vincent's fund of knowledge was judged to meet and at times exceed expectations for his level of training and he was usually able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting. He scored below both the group and national mean on the NBME shelf exam.

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Vincent was challenged to read throughout the rotation and build a broad base of pediatric knowledge.  "Vincent was very interested in working up a differential diagnosis. He improved greatly in physical exam skills. Vincent was extremely engaging with patients and families and made them feel very comfortable. He asked lots of questions and was very inquisitive."  "It was a pleasure working with Vincent and watching his confidence and clinical skill set mature over the course of the three weeks that we worked together. Vincent initially was somewhat reserved and presented quietly on rounds. With practice, however, he became more comfortable presenting in front of the team and the patient's family. I appreciated that he always took the time to introduce (by name) the family members in attendance before starting his presentation, which acknowledged the family's presence and I think made them feel more comfortable contributing to the discussion about their child's plan of care. By the end of the rotation Vincent was able to present one of our more complex patients, and delivered a presentation that went through each issue in a systematic, organized manner. He offered up an excellent assessment for someone at his level of training and followed through with very reasonable plan that took into account each of the child's medical problems and how they interacted with one another. In the afternoons, I trusted Vincent to help with tasks such as updating pediatricians (for patients with more extensive hospital courses) and calling consults." His write-up of a child with a rash on amoxicillin was very well done.  Vincent developed a comprehensive differential related to the patient's presentation.  The write-up was well constructed and well referenced. Vincent was always prepared for team-based learning sessions and he made contributions to the small-group and large-group learning process. His individual average on TBL was above the class average.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills: 
Vincent has excellent interpersonal and communication skills and he consistently created warm and therapeutic relationships with patients and their families.  Vincent was polite and very easy to work with."  

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Vincent always put the needs of his patients and families above his own. He worked tirelessly to better his clinical skills. "Vincent was a pleasure to work with. He demonstrated the utmost dedication to the practice, a good deal of compassion for others, and maturity."  Vincent was a very thoughtful and professional medical student. He engaged very well with patients and their families. He was on time and prepared for all clerkship activities.  

Systems-based Practice: 
Vincent was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.

Vincent displayed a true commitment to his patients and to learning during this rotation.   He sharpened his pediatric clinical skills and refined his approach to pediatric patient care.  He consistently made significant contributions to his patients, their families, and the health care team and demonstrated excellent interpersonal skills.  He is well on his way to becoming an outstanding clinician.

**************************

The following is a narrative assessment of how Cedric Diggory fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Cedric showed excellent to outstanding ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation and he clearly developed a solid approach to pediatric care during this clerkship.  "Student doctor Diggory demonstrated critical thinking, communication skills, and compassionate care during his inpatient pediatrics rotation. I was quite impressed with his novel approach to patient care. He consistently thought outside of the box when faced with clinical decision making, especially with complex patients. He was able to effectively communicate his thinking in a group setting, and clearly presented on rounds with both parents and the team alike."  "Did an excellent job on a difficult inpatient rotation. Was attentive and eager to learn at every opportunity. Presented patients on rounds with poise, identified and organized problems and addressed them in their plan."  Cedric was a reliable reporter and interpreter of patient information and he is encouraged to challenge himself to take an even greater role in patient management.  Notes were thorough and timely and Cedric consistently and efficiently finished all daily tasks.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Cedric' fund of knowledge was judged to meet and at times exceed expectations for his level of training and he was usually able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting.  "Works well with families and patients. Excellently researches conditions and treatments in order to better care for patients. Great presentations."  He scored above the group and national mean on the NBME shelf exam.

Cedric was challenged to read throughout the rotation and build a broad base of pediatric knowledge.  "Cedric is a very thoughtful and self-motivated student. He took a lot of initiative with his patients. In particular, he was following a very medically complex patient who was transferred to the PICU. Cedric made it a point to visit the patient and family in the ICU and update the team about his progress. His assessments and plans were very thoughtful and showed that he was thinking critically about his patients."  His write-up of an infant with fever was succinct.  While he developed a differential related to the patient's presentation would have liked to see a more thoroughly referenced discussion.  Cedric was always prepared for team-based learning sessions and he made contributions to the small-group and large-group learning process.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills:

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Cedric always put the needs of his patients and families above his own. He worked tirelessly to better his clinical skills. "Very willing to take on tasks and very self-motivated. High degree of sensitivity to family needs."  He was on time and prepared for all clerkship activities.  

Systems-based Practice: 
Cedric was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  "Responded to feedback where appropriate. Gave thorough and nuanced presentations on sickle cell anemia and on thalessemias. Was a great asset to the team and will make an exceptional physician in the near future."

Cedric displayed a true commitment to his patients and to learning during this rotation.   He sharpened his pediatric clinical skills and refined his approach to pediatric patient care.  He consistently made significant contributions to his patients, their families, and the health care team and demonstrated excellent interpersonal skills. question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Draco Malfoy fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.

Patient Care:  Draco showed excellent ability in patient care in all areas of the rotation. He worked to take ownership of patients as noted by floor resident "He took ownership of his patients on the pediatric ward, both in respect of establishing the closest rapport with the patient and their family, but also considering their medical management." In the ER he was "a very efficient medical student, with excellent work ethics. Very good clinical judgment".  He worked to improve his presentations but was always analytical in his application of knowledge to his patients.  He was able to establish good rapport with both children and parents as he functioned as their intern during the rotation. In clinic setting he was proactive in seeing patients, worked to learn preventive health care and its role in pediatrics.

Knowledge for Practice:  Draco's fund of knowledge was deemed to meet and sometimes exceed expectations for his level of training.  He was able to apply pathophysiology to the clinical setting and was enthusiastic to learn.  He did read throughout the rotation on patients seen but he scored well below class and national average on SHELF. TBL scores were average.

Practice-based learning:  Draco was dedicated to ongoing reading to enhance his pediatric knowledge throughout the clerkship. He was a very engaged and energetic student. "He gave a particularly good presentation on Traumatic Brain Injury to the team." One resident noted "He would read up on the pathology a patient would present with, and even gave a 15 minute presentation on Traumatic Brain Injury so that the team could review a patient we had recently managed." He also gave a presentation on AKI that was very well organized in relation to his write up of a patient with malaria.  The history was somewhat disjointed but his discussion of malaria and sequelae was fairly complete.

Interpersonal/communication skills and Interprofessional Collaboration:  Draco exhibited excellent interpersonal skills with both patients and team members in all areas of the rotation.  He was enthusiastic to see patient in ER and clinic and took ownership of his patients. He has a positive attitude and genuine enthusiasm. He was an excellent team player. He established good relationships with his patients.

Professionalism/Personal Development: Draco is a motivated learner and consistently read and sought out feedback.  His floor attending commented "He is a self-motivated learner, actively seeking feedback, and you can see continued improvement as he implements the feedback given into his daily practice. He was a dependable and trustworthy member of the team while he was on the floor, and showed himself to be a good advocate for the patients that he was assigned."

System-based practice:  Draco was an integral member of the health care team to promote good patient care. He quickly learned how to work in each clinical setting, notes were well organized and concise.

Draco is an energetic, engaged and motivate student who was an integral part of patient care.  He worked diligently to learn pediatrics with a joyful attitude.  He has a curious mind, good critical thinking skills and a gentle spirit that engenders confidence and trust from his patients.  These qualities along with his dedication to learning clinical medicine will make him an exceptional physician in any area he chooses.


Draco Malfoy

question:

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Oliver Wood fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Oliver displayed excellent ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation.  He was dedicated to his patients and their families and he worked tirelessly on their behalf.  He strived to take ownership for his patients and their medical issues.  "Oliver demonstrated his excitement about the rotation through clinical interactions with patients, clearly incorporating his increasing knowledge base whenever possible, and willing participation in the Pediatric Emergency Department mock codes."  "Oliver was great to work with. He was extremely intellectually curious and committed to his patients. He will undoubtedly be an excellent resident."  "Oliver was able to report on and interpret patient status and, at times, showed movement toward managing patient care.  At their best, his presentations were on-point and clear. Oliver was attentive to the details of patient care and he routinely finished his daily tasks.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Oliver's fund of knowledge was judged to meet, and at times exceed expectations for his level of training and he was usually able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting.  He scored above the group average the national mean on the NBME shelf exam.  His TBL was below the group average.

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Oliver was clearly reading throughout the rotation and built a broad base of pediatric knowledge that he shared with the team at all appropriate moments.  "Oliver was a good medical student who clearly cares about his patients. He did a great job checking in with residents and following up with his patients over the course of the day."  His inpatient write-up of a chronically ill adolescent with worsening neurologic findings. Oliver covered the basics of the approach to the patient and covered an extensive differential and potential work up.  Oliver was an engaged member of his team-based learning group and participated in all of the phases of the group problem solving process.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Development: 
Oliver has excellent interpersonal and communication skills and he created warm and therapeutic relationships with patients and their families.  "It was a pleasure to have Oliver on our team during his pediatrics rotation Pediatrics rotation. He was very enthusiastic about patients on our team and was a good team player."  Oliver was deemed a key contributor to the health care team by patients, families, and his co-workers.  

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Oliver always attempted to put the needs of his patients and families above his own.  He was on time and prepared for all clerkship activities.  

Systems-based Practice: 
Oliver was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  

Oliver displayed a thoughtful and committed approach to patient care in all settings of the rotation.  He challenged himself to bond with families and develop therapeutic relationships with his patients.  He is a motivated learner and was committed to improving his fundamental clinical skills and deepening his fund of knowledge. He is well on his way to becoming an outstanding clinician.

Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Viktor Krum fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Viktor showed excellent to outstanding ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation and he clearly developed a solid approach to pediatric care during this clerkship.  "Viktor was an exceptional student to work with! He not only took complete ownership of his patients, quickly caught up on the nights and morning events, interpreted data appropriately and was thorough in his management plans but he also made an effort to develop deep and meaningful relationships with his patients and their families. A pleasure to work with!"  "This cardiology service is challenging for interns and medical students alike due to the complexity of the patient population and the many teams of physicians caring for the patients. Despite this, Viktor had excellent command of his patient's pathophysiology and their management in real time. His assessments were honest, and well conducted, and his differential diagnoses well reasoned. He was always motivated to know more about his patients and to adopt additional work to help the team and to improve his knowledge base."  Viktor X was a reliable reporter and interpreter of patient information and he is encouraged to challenge himself to take an even greater role in patient management.  Notes were thorough and timely and Viktor consistently and efficiently finished all daily tasks.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Viktor 's fund of knowledge was judged to meet and at times exceed expectations for his level of training and he was usually able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting.  "Viktor was an excellent addition to the team, he was very friendly and enthusiastic - always asking good questions and was eager to learn."  He scored below the group and national mean on the NBME shelf exam.

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Viktor was challenged to read throughout the rotation and build a broad base of pediatric knowledge.  "Pleasant demeanor and ability to empathize translated to building great rapport with his patients and their families. Thorough in his histories and physicals, knew his patients very well and thought deeply about treatment plans. This knowledge of his patients allowed Viktor to talk conversationally about his patients on rounds, making good eye contact as a full member of the team and presented the patients in a clear, concise, and accurate manner."  His write-up of an adolescent with syncopal events in the setting of recent lyme diseae had a developed and comprehensive differential related to the patient's presentation and explored the possibility that the patient's preexisting condition set the stage for his illness.  The write-up was well constructed and well referenced.  Viktor was always prepared for team-based learning sessions and he made contributions to the small-group and large-group learning process. His TBL average was below the group average.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills: 
Viktor has excellent interpersonal and communication skills and he consistently created warm and therapeutic relationships with patients and their families.  "Viktor was an excellent medical student. He checked in with his patients and answered family's question. He always ensured things got done for his patients. He dedication to his patients was seen when he walked around the halls with his patient after surgery since PT had not had a chance to see the patient. His presentations are succinct and to the point."  Viktor was deemed a valued member of the health care team by patients, families, and his co-workers.  

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Viktor always put the needs of his patients and families above his own. He worked tirelessly to better his clinical skills. "Viktor was prompt, well prepared, and professional in conduct and appearance throughout. I would issue my highest recommendation for Viktor."  He was on time and prepared for all clerkship activities.  

Systems-based Practice: 
Viktor was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care. "Viktor was enthusiastic about learning form patients; he is a team player and willing to help out the team w logistics and discharge.  Presentations were succinct and highlighted important clinical points."

Viktor displayed a true commitment to his patients and to learning during this rotation.   He sharpened his pediatric clinical skills and refined his approach to pediatric patient care.  He consistently made significant contributions to his patients, their families, and the health care team and demonstrated excellent interpersonal skills.  He is well on his way to becoming an outstanding clinician.


******************************************************

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Gregory Goyle fulfilled the competencies required in the Pediatrics rotation.

Patient Care: 
Gregory displayed outstanding ability in his patient care activities in all settings of this rotation. He was committed to his patients and their families and worked to take ownership of their care. His history taking was skillful and physical exams were attentive to patient comfort and carried out with increasing skill over the course of the rotation. His patient presentations were delivered at a level that far exceeded expectations. "Gregory developed an easy rapport with the patients and families he helped care for. He also began to develop his teaching skills during his time with us. For example, he was able to provide effective asthma education to a patient and his family prior to discharge." "Gregory did an excellent job in helping to gather historical data from patients and families, and always was up-to-date on his patients' interval events and current status. He was responsible and caring, and checked back on his patients multiple times throughout the day. His presentations were very good, and he did make adjustments based on feedback." "I think Gregory is naturally a humanistic physician and moreover, he makes the effort to go above and beyond for his patients. In addition to his humanistic clinical skills, Gregory has impressive clinical reasoning and solid differentials. He integrated clinical information very well and had a strong grasp on the medical conditions of his patients. He clearly is very dedicated and hard working." Gregory committed himself to providing compassionate care, was a fierce patient advocate and always up-to-date with their clinical status. Gregory was usually able to anticipate the needs of his patients and with the assistance and support of his team he made significant contributions to patient care. His notes were timely and complete and he was always able to efficiently finish his daily work. 

Knowledge for Practice: 
Gregory's fund of knowledge was judged to exceed expectations for his level of training. He was consistently able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting. He scored above both the group mean and national average on the NBME shelf exam.  

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Gregory was committed to learning and improving in response to the clinical experiences he was having and was clearly reading about his patients at all opportunities. "Gregory grew tremendously over the three weeks we spent together on the pediatrics inpatient service. During his first few days with us he was more reserved, and his patient presentations on rounds - which were quietly delivered and could be difficult to hear - reflected this. As he became more confident in himself the quality of his patient presentations matured accordingly. This culminated in an excellent presentation during the last week of the rotation of the sickest patient on our service that blew me away. Gregory was able to wade through the mire of data in the EMR and outside records and identify the two key issues for this patient, MRSA bacteremia and acute hypoxic respiratory failure. His presentation was well-organized, including only the key details, and he offered a thoughtful assessment and plan for each issue. He further was able to help field the questions this parent posed throughout the presentation, drawing on his knowledge of pathophysiology to do so. I was impressed that he remained calm and unflustered and was able to return to his presentation smoothly each time." His case write-up of this patient was exceptional. All elements of the write-up were characterized by thoroughness, lucidity and sound clinical reasoning. Gregory developed a comprehensive differential diagnosis that was appropriate to the patient's presentation and extensively referenced. He demonstrated a deep understanding for each etiologic entity he explored. He was prepared for team-based learning activities and consistently made contributions to small-group and large-group problem solving. His individual score on the TBL was higher than the average. 

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Development: 
Gregory created comfortable rapport and therapeutic relationships with his patients and their families. He displayed outstanding interpersonal and communication skills. "Gregory performed extremely well on this rotation and was loved by his patients. I was extremely impressed with his professionalism when it came to patient care. He delivered presentations from memory and translated to family-centered language, performing at the level of an intern. He was very conscious of complex social issues and tuned into the emotions of the families. His presence was always very welcoming and he evoked empathy towards his patients."

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Gregory placed his patients' needs before his own. "Gregory arrived on time and well-prepared for patient care activities. On patients we followed together I knew I could rely on him to be up to date on the patient's current status. It was a great pleasure working with Gregory." He sought out feedback and used constructive elements to better his clinical performance. He was on time and present for all clerkship activities.

Systems based Practice: 
Gregory was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care. "Gregory did particularly well getting a history and physical on a patient with an undiagnosed inflammatory disease. The residents and ID fellow & attending all read his H&P felt that it was very precise, and included all relevant travel and personal questions. Gregory was nice and thoughtful, and a pleasure to work with on our team. He would be a great pediatrician if he decided to pursue this career."

Overall, Gregory consistently demonstrated a commitment to compassionate patient care. He was a vital member of his team and he made essential contributions to patient health and well-being. He eagerly built upon his solid clinical skill set and displayed outstanding interpersonal skills. He is functioning at a superior clinical level and he is well on his way to becoming a superb clinician.

********************
