question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment for Dean Dean

Patient care: 
Dean displayed excellent ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation.  Despite only the second rotation Dean worked to take ownership of patients and to actively participate in clinical care in all areas of the rotation.  He was enthusiastic and motivated. His senior resident described him as a "great team player".  He was active participating in the ED and clinic offering to see as many patients as possible. An ED attending commented that Dean "is a great student, he is very motivated, very efficient, and very helpful, it was a pleasure working with him". A ward attending commented that  "Dean impressed me by the OUTSTANDING care he provided to a teenage girl with Sickle Cell."


Knowledge for Practice: 
Dean's fund of knowledge was judged to meet and often exceed expectations for his level of training.  Dean clearly read in preparation for the rotation and came to pediatrics with a self-learned base.  Individual TBL scores improved but he did score slightly below the class and national average on the NBME shelf. 

Practice-based Learning: 
Dean read throughout the rotation and built a broad base of pediatric knowledge that he shared with the team throughout the rotation.  He presented "an outstanding presentation to the Inpatient Team on the Diagnosis & Management of Sickle Cell VOC with well researched EBM articles." "He created a presentation on Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia because he came across a pediatrics test question on a topic he'd never heard of; the synopsis was suitable as a study guide for an intern." He was engaged and interactive throughout the 6 weeks.  


Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Collaboration: 
Dean has outstanding interpersonal and communication skills as he genuinely enjoyed children and this experience.  He has a professional yet accessible manner and was able to clearly communicate plans with parents. As his attending summarized "I'd also like to highlight that in addition to his intellect/professionalism he showed an admirable humanism. A child in the PICU was getting panicky as specialists, house staff, and RN's & support staff started to pile up in the room. Seeing the child's anxiety, Dean alone, took it on himself to distract the child & took an anxious, whiny, whimpering 3yo boy & had the kid giggling, giving hi5's & completely relaxed. Admirably human!"

Professionalism and Personal Development: 

Dean has an outgoing positive attitude and professional demeanor.  He was always present and ready to help care for our patients at every turn.  He was receptive to feedback and incorporated into his development.  He used all his experiences to improve.

Systems based practice: 
Dean was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  He worked diligently in all areas of the rotation.

Dean is an energetic, passionate and motivated young clerk.  His compassion, humanism and good humor were welcomed by the children and their parents.  He displays an enthusiasm for patient care and for improving his own skills as a clinician.  He worked diligently to improve his fund of knowledge, pediatric physical exam and management.
He was and is an asset to any team he works with and he will be an excellent physician.
We encourage him to choose pediatrics.







Dean Dean

Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text:

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Lee (Lee) Jordan fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Lee showed excellent to outstanding ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation and he clearly developed a solid approach to pediatric care during this clerkship.  "Lee' presentations were concise, organized, and modified appropriately for family-centered rounds. He picked up additional patients without being asked to and always offered to help residents. One example of his excellent patient care was when he followed up a complex patient even a week after his discharge to ensure he was able to schedule and attend outpatient follow up appointments. Overall very hardworking and excellent student who will be a great resident no matter what field he goes into!"  "Lee was a great addition to the team, he consistently demonstrated competence in developing assessment and plans and established good rapport with his patients" "Lee was a reliable reporter and interpreter of patient information and he is encouraged to challenge himself to take an even greater role in patient management.  Notes were thorough and timely and Lee consistently and efficiently finished all daily tasks.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Lee' fund of knowledge was judged to meet and at times exceed expectations for his level of training and he was usually able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting.  "Lee went above and beyond every day to build relationships with the patient and their families. He took initiative to learn about topics relevant to his assigned patients and presented the information during rounds."  He scored well below both the group and national mean on the NBME shelf exam.

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Lee was challenged to read throughout the rotation and build a broad base of pediatric knowledge.  "Lee did a great job connecting with his patients and truly cared about the families he interacted with. He was always prepared and willing to work hard. He took feedback well and worked each day to improve on any feedback that had previously been given."  His write-up of an infant with HSV was extremely well done. The write-up was well constructed and well referenced.  Lee brought in important perspectives that related to the sociocultural context for this child.  Lee was always prepared for team-based learning sessions and he made contributions to the small-group and large-group learning process.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills: 
Lee has excellent interpersonal and communication skills and he consistently created warm and therapeutic relationships with patients and their families.  "Lee was a pleasure to have on our team. He knew his patients very well and was able to give comprehensive presentations without his notes. His plans were appropriate and well thought through. He did a great job including family in the conversation on rounds and was extremely patient centric."  "We enjoyed having Lee on team 1. He gave excellent presentations and was well read on the literature that applied to his patient's. He spent extra time aiding in the coordination of care of his patient's which was much appreciated by the team."

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Lee always put the needs of his patients and families above his own. He worked tirelessly to better his clinical skills. "He is a team player who showed enthusiasm and was clearly ready to learn about pediatrics." 

Systems-based Practice: 
Lee was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care. "Lee was a really great member of Team 1 and incredibly helpful during a busy service. He took the time to make sure that his patients had a comfortable discharge by ensuring follow-up success and going beyond what is expected of most students by contacting pharmacies and clinics outside of the city. He knew his patients well and was able to develop substantial differential diagnoses for new patients. He was also clearly very empathetic towards the patients and the team."

Lee displayed a true commitment to his patients and to learning during this rotation.   He sharpened his pediatric clinical skills and refined his approach to pediatric patient care.  He consistently made significant contributions to his patients, their families, and the health care team and demonstrated excellent interpersonal skills.  He is well on his way to becoming an outstanding clinician.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text:
The following areas for improvement were suggested by supervisors who worked with Lavender during this rotation:

"As discussed in mid-clerkship feedback, Lavender should try to be more proactive in both learning and patient care. MCY year can be difficult - it is often hard to find 'your role' on the team. However, we discussed specific ways to be more proactive (such as creating a list of necessary tasks for patients and going over it with the intern) and taking on more patients, and i would have liked to see even more of that. Lavender is extremely smart and capable and will certainly be a great doctor."

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Lavender Brown fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Lavender displayed excellent ability in her patient care activities in all settings of this rotation.  She was deeply committed to providing comprehensive patient care and challenged herself to take ownership of her patients to the greatest extent possible.  "Lavender always came to patient-centered rounds prepared, having seen her patients beforehand. She worked well with the residents who were also following her patients, and together they formulated a plan. Each presentation was clear and organized and took into account the family's level of medical sophistication. Her interactions with patients were sincere and reassuring. Although she started, as most students in her class did, with a basic knowledge of Pediatrics, she clearly gained from each patient experience by reading up on the patient's medical problem. By the end of the rotation I believe she felt comfortable with patients of varying ages and degrees of illness."  "Lavender was enthusiastic and had focused and concise presentations, which was great!" "Lavender did a good history and physical and presented the patient which she saw on her own very well. Interacted well with the patients and families. Asked appropriate questions"  "Notes were timely, presentations were consistently on-point, and Lavender was always able to efficiently finish her daily work.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Lavender's fund of knowledge was judged to meet, and at times exceed expectations for her level of training. She was often able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting. "She was prepared, confident, and organized during rounds. She asked and answered questions with an appropriate level of certainty and seemed interested in learning in pediatrics." She scored at the group average and just below the national mean on the NBME shelf exam. 

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Lavender was committed to outside reading during the clerkship in an effort to build a broad base of pediatric knowledge and deepen her experiential learning.  She was eager for all learning opportunities.  "Lavender showed improvement over the course of her clinical rotation. Her presentations became more concise and better organized. She was thoughtful about differential diagnoses for patients."  Her case write-up of a patient with an allergic reaction was of solid quality.  She demonstrated a sound approach to the diagnosis and management for this condition and made certain to make the all-important distinction between etiological subtypes.  She was an engaged and vocal member of her team-based learning group and she enriched both small-group and large-group discussions.  Her individual average score was above the class average and her team score was at the group average.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Collaboration: 
Lavender consistently created excellent rapport and therapeutic relationships with her patients and displayed strong interpersonal skills.  "Lavender was very committed and conscientious and had good rapport with patients and their families; she was well read and asked appropriate questions." 

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Lavenderely consistently worked to place her patients' needs before her own, while balancing her own need to learn in the clinical setting.  "Lavender is a very strong medical student. She is very hard working and thorough in her work. She constantly checked in with me during the day offering her help."  She was on time and present for all clerkship activities.

Systems-based Practice: 
Lavender was able to work as an contributing member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  "Her presentations were very complete, and as the year goes on, I think she will be able to take it to the next level in creating a management plan."

Lavender is a motivated student who was dedicated to honing her pediatric clinical skill set and her ability to deliver quality patient care.  She worked to take ownership for her patients and made significant contributions to the healthcare team.  Her enthusiasm was welcomed and appreciated by the health care team.  She is well on her way to becoming an outstanding clinician.


**********************************

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Dudley Tong Dudley fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Dudley showed excellent to outstanding ability in his patient care activities in all settings of the rotation and he clearly developed a solid approach to pediatric care during this clerkship.  "Dudley was a very strong medical student. Enthusiastic, engaged, willing to help. Professional, punctual, respectful of patients. Good presentation skills and clearly thinks through differentials and management plans. Clearly did reading outside of the hospital and was able to cite review articles and papers during rounds. It was great to work with Dudley."  "Dudley was a really incredible medical student on the rotation. He was clearly very proficient in the reporter phase, and I felt that he was already advancing towards the next phase. He built great relationships with his patients and always found out more background information to supplement a patient's clinical picture, which was really helpful. For example, we shared a patient who was in the foster care system, and Dudley always made sure to contact the foster care agency daily to give them updates and obtain collateral information. He also always made it a priority to include teaching points and literature in his presentations to help the team learn as well. Amazing few weeks working with him!"  "Great job of providing evidence to the team including a patient for whom Dudley corrected the course of antibiotics based on his reading."  Dudley was a reliable reporter and interpreter of patient information and he is encouraged to challenge himself to take an even greater role in patient management.  Notes were thorough and timely and Dudley consistently and efficiently finished all daily tasks.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Dudley's fund of knowledge was judged to meet and at times exceed expectations for his level of training and he was usually able to apply his understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting.  "It was a joy having Dudley on our team this block! He contributed consistently to the team and was well prepared for rounds. He did a particularly great job of reviewing the literature before rounds and sharing his findings with the team."  He scored just below the group and below the national mean on the NBME shelf exam.

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Dudley was challenged to read throughout the rotation and build a broad base of pediatric knowledge.  "Dudley is an enthusiastic and self-motivated student. In the week that we worked together, he would frequently look to the literature to help him with his management plans and discuss them on rounds. He did a good job with family-centered rounds and often explained things to family as he was presenting without using medical terminology."  "Dudley was always eager and willing to help with patient care related tasks. He was open to feedback and altered his presentations based on this feedback. He learned with time and feedback how to present in a patient centered manner and how to approach patients and their families by using less scientific/medical jargon." His write-up of a neonate with fever and UTI was well done.  Dudley developed a comprehensive differential related to the patient's presentation.  The write-up was extremely well constructed and well referenced.  Dudley was always prepared for team-based learning sessions and he made contributions to the small-group and large-group learning process.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills: 
Dudley has excellent interpersonal and communication skills and he consistently created warm and therapeutic relationships with patients and their families.  "Dudley consistently came prepared to rounds. He was an active member of the team and consistently helped with patient care and daily tasks. Routinely brought articles about relevant topics to present to the team."  Dudley was deemed a valued member of the health care team by patients, families, and his co-workers.  

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Dudley always put the needs of his patients and families above his own. He worked tirelessly to better his clinical skills. "Very enthusiastic and always eager to come in early or stay late for the benefit of getting to know his patients more in helping the team. I was particularly impressed with his overwhelmingly positive attitude even when he had very complex patients."  He was on time and prepared for all clerkship activities.  

Systems-based Practice: 
Dudley was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care. "Always a joy to have on the team, I was consistently impressed by both work ethic and fund of knowledge. Did a great job of getting to know his patients and establishing a bond with them. I was especially impressed by Dudley's motivation and level of self-direction."

Dudley displayed a true commitment to his patients and to learning during this rotation.   He sharpened his pediatric clinical skills and refined his approach to pediatric patient care.  He consistently made significant contributions to his patients, their families, and the health care team and demonstrated excellent interpersonal skills.  He is well on his way to becoming an outstanding clinician.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
The following is a narrative assessment of how Katie bell fulfilled the competencies required in this rotation.
 
Patient Care: 
Katie displayed outstanding ability in her patient care activities in all settings of this rotation.  She was committed to her patients and their families and worked to take ownership of their care.  Her history taking was skillful and physical exams were attentive to patient comfort and carried out with increasing skill over the course of the rotation.  Her patient presentations were delivered at a level that far exceeded expectations.  "Though we only worked together for one week, Katie was outstanding. She collected and shared data at a very high level, being sure to include only the most pertinent information. She gave clear and efficient oral presentations during rounds, and was able to make connections with patients and families. She was able to think through complex problems and offer possible solutions and management plans. She was supremely professional, and gave an excellent teaching presentation (mostly from memory) on a nuanced topic (coronary artery dilation in non-KD febrile patients) that I would expect from more senior residents. And she had a great attitude and approach to pediatrics."  "I had the distinct pleasure of working closely with Katie during her pediatrics clerkship. From day one she made it her mission to integrate herself into the team and make herself instrumental toward furthering patient care. What stood out in Katie's performance was the way she conducted herself during family centered rounds. It is rare to see a medical student who was able to appreciate the subtleties required to present accurate and relevant medical information, in a sensitive manner that is appropriate for both the patient's family as well as the medical team. Katie was able to accomplish this task better than any medical student I have ever worked with. I was also able to observe the way Katie gathered information from patients and performed medical exams. She was able to elicit all the required details with ease and was able to appreciate subtle findings on exam. Her notes on these patients were thorough and organized and clearly reflected accurate and appropriate clinical judgement."  She committed herself to providing compassionate care, was a fierce patient advocate and always up-to-date with their clinical status. Katie was usually able to anticipate the needs of her patients and with the assistance and support of her team she made significant contributions to patient care. Her notes were timely and complete and she was always able to efficiently finish her daily work.  

Knowledge for Practice: 
Katie's fund of knowledge was judged to exceed expectations for her level of training. She was consistently able to apply her understanding of pathophysiology to the clinical setting.  "Katie offered thoughtful differential diagnoses on her patients, particularly one with a puzzling presentation of anasarca. She fit in well with the team and worked seamlessly alongside the residents." She scored above the group mean and national average on the NBME shelf exam. 

Practice-based Learning and Improvement: 
Katie was committed to learning and improving in response to the clinical experiences she was having and was clearly reading about her patients at all opportunities.  "Katie truly stood out during her rotation. No matter how busy, she was always enthusiastic to take care of her patients. On rounds, her presentations were clear and concise. She established great rapport with family members and always included them in her presentations. When she was able, she fearlessly jumped in and offered to help the team translate in Spanish and was able to calm down worried parents on rounds by bridging the language barrier." "Katie did an excellent job on a difficult inpatient rotation. She was attentive and eager to learn at every opportunity. Presented patients on rounds with poise, identified problems and addressed them. Responded to feedback where appropriate. Katie was a great asset to the team and will make an exceptional physician in the near future."  Her case write-up of 14 month old admitted with anarsarca was exceptional.  All elements of the write-up were characterized by thoroughness, lucidity and sound clinical reasoning.  Katie developed a comprehensive differential diagnosis that was appropriate to the patient's presentation and extensively referenced.  She demonstrated a deep understanding for each etiologic entity she explored.  She was prepared for team-based learning activities and consistently made contributions to small-group and large-group problem solving.

Interpersonal and Communication Skills and Interprofessional Development: 
Katie created comfortable rapport and therapeutic relationships with her patients and their families.  She displayed outstanding interpersonal and communication skills.  "I cannot speak highly enough of Katie. She was consistently a functioning and helpful member of our team on a busy inpatient service. Her history and physical exam skills are on par with residents. She identified areas of need for patient care and independently completed tasks to ensure better care for our patients (even if she was not following them herself). Her presentations were well thought out and clearly showed her thought process and decision making."

Professionalism and Personal Development: 
Katie placed her patients' needs before her own.  "Katie was consistently working for the best interest of her patients. She was interested in learning and asked relevant questions. She was open to feedback and always working to improve."  She sought out feedback and used constructive elements to better her clinical performance.  She was on time and present for all clerkship activities.

Systems based Practice: 
Katie was able to work as an integral member of the health care team to promote the best in patient care.  "Katie was a pleasure to work with and a very strong medical student. She showed up on time and was very well prepared for rounds. She knew her patients well and went above and beyond to read about them and contribute novel questions and ideas to their management plans. Her presentations were well organized and eloquently delivered."

Overall, Katie consistently demonstrated a commitment to compassionate patient care.  She was a vital member of her team and she made essential contributions to patient health and well-being.  She eagerly built upon her solid clinical skill set and displayed outstanding interpersonal skills.  She is functioning at a superior clinical level and she is well on her way to becoming a superb clinician.

********************************

answer_text: "Pansy can continue to develop insight into how her patients cope with a range of emotions and thus improve her ability to tolerate and support the expression of painful emotional states."

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Pansy was assigned to the NYP consultation-liaison service for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience. The senior resident on her team described her as "wonderful to work with. She was very professional in her communication with the team, timeliness and accuracy of her notes, and in communicating with the patients and their families. She is able to develop great rapport with her patients. We worked on obtaining a full and thorough history, which she is able to do well. Her presentations of her cases during rounds were clear and succinct. Pansy's knowledge of psychiatry significantly improved during the course of the rotation and she asked very relevant and thoughtful questions. She is very bright, inquisitive and eager to learn." Pansy's team attending made the following comments: "Pansy was a pleasure to have on the team. I was amazed that this was her first rotation of MCY, as she presented from day one at the level of a seasoned intern. Not only had Pansy organized and formulated her cases well, but she presented without notes extremely fluidly. Pansy was able to develop good therapeutic relationships with her patients, including one whose family was fundamentally opposed to the involvement of psychiatry. She prepared an extremely well organized review of psychiatric symptoms that can occur in the post stroke setting. Pansy was a true team player. Overall she did an outstanding job." A preceptor who provided weekly group supervision for the 3 medical students assigned to the consultation-liaison service added that "Pansy is a highly intelligent, thoughtful, compassionate and mature young woman. She is intuitive, verbal, related and very empathic with patients. Her write-ups were flawless from the beginning." The faculty member responsible for overseeing the medical students on the service noted that this was a "very strong performance from this student on her first clerkship of MCY." Overall, Pansy is a bright and mature student who threw herself into every aspect of the rotation with enthusiasm and grew significantly in her knowledge and clinical skills. She has clearly made an easy transition to the new demands of the clinical setting. Pansy will make a superb physician in whatever field she chooses and I would encourage her to consider psychiatry as she would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Ron has performed in a superior category in psychiatry. His growth and development across this year has been impressive and he is on his way to becoming an outstanding house officer. Ron is also one of the most consistent and even-keeled medical students we have worked with. He is patient, kind and very thoughtful and considerate in the patient encounter; he also brings clinical acumen in such a way that he takes comprehensive and hypothesis-driven histories all the while being therapeutic with patients. One attending cited his wonderful interview with a patient who was anxious and disorganized in thought process. Ron was able to really let the patient tell her story, calm down and then add necessary structure to the interview. One attending commented on his ability to see numerous follow-up patients in a clinic within one afternoon and rapidly assimilate/filter large amounts of information, focus in on the task at hand, manage uncertainty and manage the patients who were sometimes difficult. He is always able to synthesize the history into a case formulation and cast a broad, on target differential diagnosis. He captures nuances, as he did in his write up discussing a patient's traits and coping style and dealing with it in a sophisticated manner. Never wasting a moment, Ron came to a clinic with no new patients and he created an annotated bibliography of sorts on cannabis reference materials for patients and staff. He is organized and a quick, critical thinker. We have been very impressed with Ron's performance.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: For an MCY student there are few things Ron necessarily needs to improve upon, however, we encourage him to continue working on management and education domains within psychiatry such that whatever field of medicine he chooses he will continue to broaden his capacity to assess and treat psychiatric patients.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Fleur has functioned in an overall superior category this year. She brought a high level of enthusiasm to all clinics, is outstanding in terms of her comfort with complex patients and challenging subject matters, and she brings a fierce determination to learn and do her job at a level beyond expectation. She is a student that never needs prompting to follow leads, call collateral and do as much as possible to manage patients. Attendings appreciate her very comprehensive history taking and ability to give an organized and thorough oral presentation of a patient. She is always careful to contextualize the history and note what information she was unable to obtain and come up with ideas for how to get it. She has an excellent knowledge base in psychiatry and picks up subtleties in the patient encounter. For example, she interviewed one adult male with a very complex history and presentation. He did not have a clear axis I disorder and she was able to discuss, among many things, his arrested psychosocial development and schizoidal traits. Fleur has also been able to identify and address issues of transference-countertransference in a self-aware and sophisticated fashion that is well beyond the level of expectation. This consistently happened with different Attendings, in different clinical settings and she also wrote about it in her reflections. For example, with a severely personality disordered male patient, Fleur was able to non-defensively accept the observation that she appeared less empathic in this particular encounter compared to her usual patient interactions. She thoughtfully assessed the situation and identified that she felt a resistance to connect with him for fear of being manipulated or victimized by him. This patient had a history of childhood sexual abuse and we later came to know he carries a sex offender status; his interpersonal interactions are dominated by victim-perpetrator dyads. Fleur was able to discuss all of this and thoughtfully consider the information in the diagnostic formulation. Given Fleur's skill set and traits, she will thrive as a house officer with increased responsibility for patients and her team of clinicians.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Inpatient: "Although his team presentations were detailed, Neville sometimes seemed to find it difficult to organize all the details of his patients' care into a cogent oral presentation which focused on the most important aspects of his patients' current status. There were several occasions when he did not know his patients' medications -- dosages or serum levels. Neville did not seem to pay consistently close attention to his written notes and the feedback he received from his PGY2 resident; apparently on more than one occasion he carried forward errors from one week to the next which the resident found and addressed."

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Neville's supervising attending on the NYS Psychiatric Institute inpatient unit to which he was assigned for the majority of his clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments:  "Neville's performance during his clerkship in Psychiatry was very good.  His pleasant demeanor and compassion toward his patients made him a pleasure to work with. Neville's intellectual curiosity manifested each time he spoke to one of his patients or thought about a related clinical issue. He applied his psychiatric knowledge both when developing differential diagnoses for his patients as well as in team discussions regarding treatment plans. Neville combined his knowledge of Psychiatry together with his familiarity with his individual patients, when obtaining histories and mental status exams. He developed broad differential diagnoses and  participated in the process of treatment and disposition planning, using as his guides what he knew of the latest scientific recommendations and his patients' preferences, as well as his own clinical judgment. The plans which he helped create were on target, focused and safe. Neville's interpersonal and communication skills, particularly in regard to his work with patients, were a strength.  He formed strong therapeutic alliances with his patients, who trusted him with the thoughts and feelings which made them feel vulnerable, and which they were reluctant to share with anyone else.  He also communicated effectively with his patients' families, as well as with other members of the interdisciplinary treatment team.  His presentations in team rounds were detailed and thorough, as were his notes.  Neville's individual work with his patients made his appreciation of issues such as transference and counter-transference clear. Neville was professional, timely and responsible.  He was compassionate and concerned about his patients' welfare.  He was also sensitive to the needs of patients from a wide variety of backgrounds.

With respect to practice based learning and improvement  Neville was receptive to feedback and supervision, and incorporated this into his daily performance.  He participated in family meetings where, after researching the literature for the latest thoughts about treatment of different disorders, he participated in the psychoeducation of patients and families. In the area of personal and professional development, Neville was trustworthy and had a level of self-confidence appropriate for someone at his level of training.  When he could not answer a question posed by a patient or one of their family members, he always looked it up so that the next time he saw the person, he could provide the answer.  When an answer was not so easily found, he could tolerate the uncertainty, and worked to help the patient and/or their family member do the same. Finally, in the domain of interprofessional collaboration, Neville worked well with all the other members of the interdisciplinary treatment team.  He acknowledged their expertise and experience; he also turned to them with questions.  Staff felt that he was easy to work with. Neville worked with a number of severely ill patients.  He was a compassionate and dedicated student who worked closely with the other clinicians on the treatment team.  Although he was often quiet, when asked for his thoughts about what to do next for one of his patients, Neville typically had a well-conceived answer ready.  I believe that with further clinical experiences, Neville will feel more comfortable allowing his confidence to shine through, and that his patients and their families, as well as his colleagues, will continue to respond to it."

Neville's outpatient supervisor added that he demonstrated "fast learning of critical thinking." An attending who worked with Neville in the Psychiatric Emergency Room noted that he appropriately completed the evaluation of a patient but left without communicating before the end of his shift, even though the attending was expecting him to see another patient.  Overall Neville is a bright student with excellent interpersonal skills who provided excellent care for his patients and grew significantly in his clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. With further attention to consistency Neville will make a fine physician in whatever field he chooses.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Cho was assigned to the NYP consultation-liaison service for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience. The junior resident on her team described her as "a wonderful medical student and a joy to work with. She is a team player, very considerate and has excellent communication skills. She is detail-oriented, wrote excellent notes, and worked very hard to perfect her presentations. She is enthusiastic and intellectually curious about psychiatry, asked insightful questions and put thought into her treatment plans. She is humble and worked hard to elicit and incorporate feedback. 
She cares a great deal about her patients and took her role as a patient advocate seriously. She has a warm, calm, and approachable demeanor that enabled her to form strong alliances with patients, and made her a very welcome part of the team. She has a very strong interest in psychiatry and I think that the field would be lucky to have her, but she would excel in any residency that she Chooses. Overall, she is a mature, thoughtful, kind medical student, and did a stellar job in this rotation."  Cho's team attending worked with her for 4 out of 5 weeks of the rotation and made the following comments: "Cho is a consummate team player; approached day with enthusiasm and a desire to learn.  She is eager and worked well with team members.  Enjoyed reading about her patients' illnesses and delivered an excellent presentation on psychiatric manifestations of Parkinson's Disease after working with a PD patient.  She easily gained the trust of patients and families including one particularly personality disordered woman admitted with heart failure. I was delighted at the end of the rotation to learn she plans to apply to a psychiatry residency program. She will be of great value to our field."  A fellow on the service added that Cho "was a pleasure to work with, always enthusiastically participated in discussions on rounds, showed good initiative by often looking up relevant literature and sharing.  I was impressed by her genuine interest in understanding the experience of her patients and their psyChopathology.  Seemed to easily form rapport with patients and in particular demonstrated great skill with a difficult patient with antisocial personality disorder, was able to set boundaries with the patient while maintaining rapport.  Overall great work!"  Overall Cho is a bright and hard-working student who threw herself into every aspect of the rotation with enthusiasm and grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation.  Cho will make a fine physician in whatever field she Chooses and I would urge her to pursue her interest in psychiatry as she would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Penelope's supervising attending on the Allen Hospital inpatient unit to which she was assigned for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments: 
"I cannot rave enough about Penelope. She is a uniquely enthusiastic, bright, and compassionate medical student. During the clerkship, she managed several challenging patients and was able to appropriately consider patients' illness in the context of complex social situations in a manner that is unusual for medical students. She cared for a wide breadth of patients, including those with personality, substance abuse, mood and psychotic disorders and demonstrated an ability to relate to all types of patients. She truly advanced care of many patients and has an ability to engage them in meaningful psychotherapy under supervision. Her ability to moderate her responses to patients based on feedback and to delve into her countertransference is well beyond her level. She took initiative on multiple occasions, calling family members, writing discharge summaries, and participating in the multidisciplinary team in a manner that is unusual for medical students. She made medication charts to help patients understands their medications on her own initiative and made appropriate recommendations to patients regarding their relationships and illness management. She gave an excellent presentation about the approach to the transgender patient that was helpful for the entire team as well as engaging and interesting." Penelope is a bright student with superb interpersonal skills who threw herself into every aspect of the rotation with enthusiasm and grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills. She will make a wonderful physician in whatever field she chooses and I would urge her to consider psychiatry as she would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Ginny's supervising attending on the NYS Psychiatric Institute inpatient unit to which she was assigned for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments:  "Ginny did an outstanding job during her rotation on the Washington Heights Community Service inpatient unit.  She was consistently curious and enthusiastic, and demonstrated a level of psychopharmacologic and psychotherapeutic knowledge notable for her level of training. She was able to work autonomously when appropriate, and readily sought supervision when unsure how to proceed.  Ginny also demonstrated exceptional clinical reasoning skills, and she was able to apply her knowledge well in the domains of diagnosis and treatment.  She proposed diagnostic and therapeutic interventions based on her daily interviews with patients and demonstrated exemplary clinical judgment.  Ginny possessed an advanced knowledge of psychiatric disorders including severe psychotic, mood, and personality disorders.  She also exceeded expectations in the domain of clinical care.  Her interview skills, history-taking, and mental status exams were notably advanced and she was able to establish and maintain rapport with a variety of challenging patients.  Ginny also demonstrated excellent communication skills, effectively communicating with her patients and with all members of our multi-disciplinary treatment team.  She liased with consulting physicians from other medical specialties and communicated their recommendations to the treatment team.  Her written documentation was well-organized, comprehensive, and timely, and her oral presentations during team rounds were thoughtful and concise.  Ginny worked with several challenging patients during her rotation on our unit, including a woman with severe schizoaffective disorder, a man with psychotic depression, and a young woman with delusional disorder versus schizophrenia.  Through her careful and empathic interactions with these patients, she was able to skillfully establish and maintain therapeutic alliances despite their challenging presentations and paranoia toward health care professionals.  Ginny consistently demonstrated professionalism and was trustworthy, honest, reliable, and ethical, taking initiative and responsibility in completing tasks on behalf of her patients and the treatment team.  In terms of systems-based practice, Ginny was an integral member of the treatment team, making meaningful contributions to the diagnoses and care of her patients.  She demonstrated awareness of the issues and situations which impact the availability and quality of care, and made helpful suggestions to insure her patients received the best treatment possible.  She demonstrated strong awareness of the role of cultural differences in the diagnosis and treatment of a diverse patient population.  She incorporated feedback from both the attending and resident physicians into daily practice and demonstrated a level of confidence that put patients and staff at ease.  Ginny participated in the education of patients and colleagues, making use of the academic literature as it pertained to her patients' diagnoses and treatment plans.  Finally, Ginny was a well-liked member of the treatment team and genuinely a joy to work with.  She will clearly excel in residency, and will be especially suited to the field of psychiatry should she choose to pursue it as a specialty."  

Ginny's outpatient supervisor added that that "it was a pleasure working with Ms. Ginny. She expressed enthusiasm about improving her psychiatric knowledge. Ms. Ginny expressed kindness and empathy to the patients she met with."

Ginny conducted an exemplary interview during a simulated standardized patient exercise at the end of the rotation. Overall, Ginny is a bright student who threw herself into every aspect of the rotation with enthusiasm and grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills. She has a gift for working with psychiatric patients and I would urge her to consider a career in psychiatry as she would make a wonderful psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Lavender was assigned to the NYP consultation-liaison service for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience. The senior resident on her team made the following comments: "Lavender is a hard worker and has medical knowledge above her expected level. She is interested and incorporates feedback into her work." The team attending noted that she "presented cases well and gave a good talk about medication use in pregnancy." A preceptor who provided weekly group supervision for the 3 medical students assigned to the consultation-liaison service added the following comments: 
"Lavender joined us the second week of the rotation and fit in seamlessly. She was prompt, professional in all ways, was a cheerful and curious learner, clearly better versed in psychiatric concepts and methods as the rotation progressed. The consult report she sent me was complete, clear and excellent. In an interview the last week of our rotation she demonstrated empathy, patience and skill"Óshowing her style and comfort had progressed. She accepted criticism." The faculty member responsible for overseeing the medical students on the service summarized Lavender's performance noting that she "joined us midway through and fit in very well; professional in all interactions and clearly interested and motivated to learn necessary skill set." Overall Lavender is a bright and hard-working student who navigated a stressful start to her rotation in which her initial assignment needed to be modified due to safety issues with maturity. Lavender grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. She will make a fine physician in whatever field she chooses and I would encourage her to consider Psychiatry as she would make an excellent psychiatrist.

Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Katie's site director at Rockland Psychiatric Center made the following comments, which reflect input from all of the services, including most particularly the inpatient unit, and attendings with whom she worked: "Katie had a strong base of knowledge in psychiatry. She worked very well with her patients, making good connections with them. Katie was a strong interviewer, and was very good at presenting data and summarizing findings in a concise progress note. She writes excellent evaluations based on her interview and recognizes major psychiatric symptoms. She participated in community meetings and by the end of the rotation was participating in running groups as well. The patients trusted her and told her things they did not share with other team members. She was excellent in communicating with all team members, coming across as confident and interested in the patients' well-being.  She was prompt, professional and reliable at all times. She would make a great house officer in a psychiatry residency program." Overall Katie is a mature and hard-working student with superb interpersonal skills. She grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. Katie will make a wonderful physician in whatever field she chooses and I would encourage her to consider psychiatry as she would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Dudley's site director at Harlem Hospital made the following comments, which include feedback from the services where he rotated: "Overall, Dudley stood out for his intellectual curiosity, his engagement with his patients and his interest in the field. During his observed patient interview, he was able to maintain a good rapport with a patient who was irritable and had poor insight. His clinical case conference presentation was thorough and compassionate, providing the background to truly understand the patient when she came into the room. He incorporated the literature in his formulation of the patient. Notably, the patient was publicly highly laudatory about Dudley and favorably compared him to other clinicians with whom she has worked in the past. Dudley asked great questions, took notes, and demonstrated a genuine care for his patients and in the quality of his work. According to his inpatient attending, Dudley was 'enthusiastic to learn' and would spend a lot of time with his patients, enabling him to build a strong therapeutic relationship with them. He was punctual and dedicated and appreciated constructive criticisms and incorporated feedback. He was described as 'most helpful.' He was professional and courteous to staff, patients and a patient's father with whom he was observed interacting." Overall Dudley is a bright and hardworking student who provided excellent care for his patients and grew significantly in his clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. Dudley will make a fine physician in whatever field he chooses.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Viktor's site director at Rockland Psychiatric Center made the following comments, which reflect input from the other services and attendings with whom he worked: "Viktor has done a fantastic job on this rotation.  He demonstrated a superior knowledge base in psychopharmacology (he always volunteered answers during questions posed in lecture).  He was very involved in the care of his patients (as well as the other patients on the unit) and met with them often, which was very helpful to the ward attending.  He communicated well with the clinical staff.  He was very professional at all times: reserved in nature, punctual, responsible, and dependable.  He was a strong interviewer ('excellent and comprehensive') and presented his cases in a 'mature and polished manner.'  He was good at identifying problems and potential treatments.  Of particular note, he was praised on his suicide assessment and fund of knowledge.  Viktor's notes were also excellent from the get-go. Viktor had very good rapport with his patients.  He showed initiative by leading a group by the end of the rotation."  Viktor conducted 2 exemplary interviews with standardized patients at the end of the rotation.  Overall Viktor is a bright and hard-working student with superb interpersonal skills who provided outstanding care for his patients and grew significantly in his clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation.  He will make a fine physician in whatever field he chooses and I would encourage him to consider psychiatry as he would make a terrific psychiatrist.

His ability to work in teams, his professional attitude and patient care were all exemplary, contributing to creating an atmosphere of collaboration and collegiality felt by everyone on the team. His interactions with patients showed great ability to develop a strong alliance from the beginning, and to navigate difficult family interactions fairly independently. Gregory's outpatient supervisor added that he "was a pleasure to work with. He is organized and  efficient with his patient interviews and write-ups and clearly understands how to compose a thoughtful psychodynamic formulation and safety assessment. He is a kind and caring clinician." Overall Gregory is a bright and hard-working student who provided superb care for his patients and grew significantly in his clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. Gregory will make a wonderful physician in whatever field he chooses and I would encourage him to consider psychiatry as he would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.

Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Dean did an outstanding job during his rotation on the Washington Heights Community Service inpatient unit.  He was consistently reliable and enthusiastic, and demonstrated a level of psychopharmacologic and psychotherapeutic knowledge pertaining to severe psychotic, mood, and personality disorders notable for his level of training.  Dean's supervising attending on the NYS Psychiatric Institute inpatient unit to which he was assigned for the majority of his clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments: "Dean's clinical reasoning was well above average, and he was able to apply his knowledge in the domains of diagnosis and treatment.  He proposed diagnostic and therapeutic interventions based on his daily interviews with patients and outside reading, and demonstrated exemplary clinical judgment.  In patient care, Dean also exceeded expectations.  His interview skills, history-taking, and mental status exams were notably advanced and he was able to establish and maintain rapport with a variety of challenging patients.  Dean also demonstrated outstanding communication skills, effectively communicating with his patients and with all members of our multi-disciplinary treatment team.  He liaised with consulting physicians from other medical specialties and communicated their recommendations to the treatment team.  His written documentation was well-organized, comprehensive, and timely, and his oral presentations during team rounds were thoughtful and concise.  Dean worked with several challenging patients during his rotation on our unit, including and young man with schizoaffective disorder and antisocial traits and a woman with chronic schizoaffective disorder and severe substance use.  Through his careful, empathic, and organized interactions with these patients, he was able to skillfully establish and maintain therapeutic alliances despite their challenging presentations.  Dean's outstanding ability to communicate with patients and family members was noted by multiple treatment team members, including a social worker with 30+ years' experience after she observed him run a family meeting.  Dean consistently demonstrated professionalism and was trustworthy, honest, reliable, and ethical, taking initiative and responsibility in completing tasks on behalf of his patients and the treatment team.  In terms of systems-based practice, Dean was an integral member of the treatment team.  He demonstrated awareness of the issues and situations which impact the availability and quality of care, and made helpful suggestions to insure his patients received the best treatment possible.  He was able to work autonomously when appropriate, and readily sought supervision when unsure how to proceed.  He incorporated feedback from both the attending and resident physicians into daily practice and demonstrated a level of confidence that put patients and staff at ease.  Dean participated in the education of patients and colleagues, making use of the academic literature as it pertained to his patients' diagnoses and treatment plans.  Finally, Dean was a well-liked member of the treatment team and genuinely a joy to work with.  He will clearly excel in residency, and will be especially suited to the field of psychiatry should he choose to pursue it as a specialty."  Dean's outpatient supervisor added that he was "impressive as evidenced by his outstanding critical thinking, curiosity and openness to learn. His knowledge of Spanish will serve him well."  Overall Dean is a bright and hard-working student who threw himself into every aspect of the rotation with enthusiasm and grew significantly in his clinical knowledge and skills.  Dean will make a fine physician in whatever field he chooses and I would encourage him to consider Psychiatry as he would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Harry is very professional, energetic and kind. He made significant improvements across the year in his ability to gather a history, perform a mental status exam and in his psychiatric knowledge base. He is a capable reporter with more straight-forward psychiatric presentations; he struggles with complex patients to capture the necessary information in order to generate a robust case summary and differential diagnosis. He continues to work on synthesizing all of the information gathered in such a way that captures the person as well as the diagnosis. Harry is much more comfortable in the clinical encounter. His psychological mindedness has improved; we encourage him to continue working on this as patients with psychiatric illness can be more sensitive/reactive (e.g. being very careful how you clarify what a patient said so as to minimize the risk of triggering defensiveness-- this is sometimes unavoidable but worthwhile to minimize the risk). His written work, when given some time, demonstrated capacity to take a comprehensive history and present it in an organized fashion, summarize the information into nice case summary and cast a broad differential-- even considering a binge-eating disorder for one patient-- and his treatment planning was patient centered including thoughts about the importance of vocation.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Colin is an outstanding student in psychiatry, and he seems to do it effortlessly! Colin is endowed with the traits and skills of a great psychiatrist-- a keen observer of the intricacies of human behavior, a natural capacity for empathy, an impressive degree of self-awareness, and thinking on the meta-level comes easily and with joy. Although not formally graded, his patient reflection demonstrated these traits in spades. In reflecting on his experience in an addictions clinic, he mused about the "centrality of the urine drug screen," how the "bladder not the eyes" are the window to the soul, and how this simple test impacts the clinician-patient relationship and acts as the "bad cop" of the treatment team. His patient write-ups have consistently been superior-- well organized filtered, flows well, descriptive and accurate MSEs, differential diagnosis always on target and his arguments solidly supported with knowledge of diagnostic criteria. His biopsychosocial formulations, whether on the spot, or with time in a write up, are very sophisticated and he always sees the big picture while not losing sight of the important details. As an interviewer, he functions like a psychiatry resident-- he is gentle, unassuming, and patient, but then also assertive enough to redirect patients and skilled with navigating sensitive topics such as trauma. Colin is also incredibly flexible and quick on his feet. One attending noted how the objective of a particular clinic changed and he "didn't blink," successfully interviewing a cognitively and hearing impaired patient. Colin has also engaged in extra-curricular activities related to psychiatry, working on a research study investigating changes in depression on PHQ9 after back surgery. Colin will be a star no matter which field he chooses; we think he is particularly skilled in psychiatry and know he would be an outstanding house officer and psychiatrist.

His psychiatric knowledge was good and he was noted to be actively working to expand his psychiatric knowledge. His communication skills were good. He incorporated feedback around psychiatric interviewing and he actively read around patient care issues. He demonstrated a curiosity and interest in understanding social context and how this impacts medical conditions and treatment. His communication strategies and ability to initiate a collaborative alliance with challenging and complex individuals were effective." Overall Seamus is a bright student who provided excellent care for his patients and grew significantly in his clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. Seamus will make a fine physician in whatever field he chooses.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Cedric' supervising attending on the NYS Psychiatric Institute inpatient unit to which he was assigned for the majority of his clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments:  "Cedric' performance during his clerkship in Psychiatry was outstanding!  He performed at or above expectations in each of the competency domains, and in many of them he shone.  He was mature and interpersonally gifted, and worked effectively with our population of severely mentally ill patients.  He was thoughtful and eager to learn, applying what he learned in classes and on his own to his clinical work. He was also self-reflective, spending time thinking about how his own past experiences impacted his clinical work, as well as about how his clinical work impacted him personally.  He was a pleasure to supervise. 

Cedric arrived on the unit with a strong fund of knowledge in Psychiatry.  He demonstrated significant intellectual curiosity, reading diligently throughout the rotation, and using patient interviews as opportunities to re-evaluate patients' diagnoses.  Having done so, he applied his knowledge to think about issues of treatment and prognosis.

Cedric' patient care skills were impressive: he took careful histories and mental status exams, and followed up on statements or answers to questions which were unclear.  Based on what he learned from patient and family interviews, reading that he had either done on his own or for class, as well as his own excellent clinical judgment, he made significant contributions to team discussions about treatment and disposition plans.  Ultimately, Cedric was able to play a key role in prioritizing some next steps for his patients' care plans, as well as to participate in the process of explaining these steps to his patients and their families.

As the above suggests, Cedric' interpersonal and communication skills were particularly impressive.  One of his three patients was a relatively young person who appeared to have been paranoid for much of her life, and had been transferred from Milstein after having been admitted there with fronto-temporal dementia with associated hallucinations and paranoid and persecutory delusions.  This patient had minimal insight into any aspect of her ongoing psychotic symptoms, and was disinclined to believe anything the team had to say as she felt persecuted by the Neurology team at Milstein for having transferred her to PI when there was "nothing wrong."  Cedric was able to form an alliance with her, however, and was able to start an ongoing conversation about her difficulty with reality testing -- "entertaining other possibilities."  He was also able to bring up the topic of dementia and help us convince her to undergo neuropsychiatric testing -- which confirmed this diagnosis.  Cedric also participated in family meetings with this patient and her daughter, and tried to help them both imagine what it might look like to have this formerly independent and even help-rejecting woman move in with her adult daughter, who had recently been diagnosed with her own incurable neurological illness.  Cedric did an outstanding job helping these women, as well as helping his other patients and their families, navigate the often choppy waters in which the chronically mentally ill and their families find themselves.  He conveyed the content of these meetings to other members of the team both in his oral presentations in team and in his written notes, all of which made clear the extent to which he understood the priorities of his patients' care.  Working with such ill patients, Cedric was also very thoughtful about issues of transference and counter-transference, and how they can affect treatment.  He was honest and forthcoming about his thoughts and feelings about his patients, and discussed them in appropriate venues.  Having done so, he was able to use his understanding of his counter-transference and treansference relative to a particular patient more effectively when interacting with them.

Cedric was nothing but professional throughout the rotation.  He showed tremendous initiative and enthusiasm, going with a patient and her family to clinic so that he could watch her outpatient provider interview her and then he and the provider could discuss the findings in real time.  He accompanied another patient to a Neurology Conference, listening to the neurologists' impressions of her and then sharing our thoughts with the neurologists.  Such actions also give ample evidence of Cedric' ability to collaborate interprofessionally, as does his respect for the expertise of the other members of the interdisciplinary treatment team on 4 South. Cedric showed enormous compassion and respect for his patients, and even the most paranoid among them responded to his warm, empathic manner.  He followed through on whatever he was asked or volunteered to do, and was reliable and punctual.  Finally, working with a diverse patient population on a community psychiatry unit, Cedric' sensitivity to his patients' many and varied needs was clear, as was his willingness to work to try to meet these needs.

With respect to practice based learning and improvement, Cedric repeatedly took the initiative to learn as much as possible about the illnesses affecting his patients, about the systems affecting the care his patients received, and about some of the issues prevalent on an inpatient psychiatry unit -- doing his research presentation on the assessment and management of violence on inpatient psychiatric units, for example. He asked for feedback and integrated the feedback he received into his practice.  As noted earlier, he read the literature related to his patients' presentations, and used this information to help psychoeducate his patients and their families, using language that maximized the chances of their understanding.

With respect to personal and professional development, Cedric demonstrated a trustworthiness, sound clinical judgment and quiet self-confidence that allowed both housestaff and me to feel secure when he was responsible for our shared patients.  The same characteristics put his patients and their families at ease, as well, and enabled us all to discuss sometimes challenging clinical issues, such as a new diagnosis of dementia and how it might impact not only a patient's life, but a fragile family system, as well.  Cedric' maturity and prior life experiences allowed him to appreciate and manage much of the ambiguity inherent in caring for such ill patients, and to help him help his patients do the same.

With respect to interprofessional collaboration, Cedric excelled.  He was in frequent contact with his patients' outpatient providers, obtaining parallel history, providing them with clinical updates and generally maintaining an open line of communication.  He worked equally closely with the other members of the inpatient treatment team, respecting their expertise and learning from their experience.

In short, working with Cedric was a pleasure.  He was warm and compassionate, enthusiastic and hard-working.  He approaches his patients creatively, and is as able to consider the details of their care as he is the larger picture.  I encourage him to consider a career in Psychiatry."

Cedric' outpatient supervisor added that he "impressed me by his sophisticated thinking when discussing clinical cases. He also shows compassion, curiosity and thoughtfulness during patient interviews."

Overall Cedric is a bright, mature, and hard-working student with superb interpersonal skills. He grew significantly in his clinical skills and knowledge over the course of the rotation and provided exemplary care for his patients. Cedric will make a wonderful physician in whatever field he chooses and I would urge him to consider psychiatry as he would make a terrific psychiatrist.
