question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Hermione's supervising attending on the NYPH inpatient unit to which she was assigned for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments:  "Hermione was a pleasure to have on our unit. It was clear over time that she came to be more and more interested in the patients and psychiatric work. She responded to tips for improvement effectively and improved in her abilities notably following mid-clerkship feedback. I came to rely on her for various tasks. She was able to bring information to my attention that I otherwise could have missed. She was extremely helpful to me in the management of a medically complicated patient on the unit. She was an enthusiastic and hard-working team-member." The junior resident who worked very closely with Hermione on the team added that "Hermione did a fantastic job with her patient. She was reliable and was a valued participant on the team." Hermione's outpatient supervisor noted that "Despite the fact that we only had her with us briefly, Hermione did a terrific job. She participated in a consultation on a very complicated patient with multiple psychiatric comorbidities who wants to become pregnant. The patient demonstrated significant signs of early trauma and borderline features, which can be difficult to explain to younger clinicians. However, Hermione participated in our discussions about this case actively, and demonstrated a sophisticated understanding of the issues in diagnosis and treatment recommendations, as well as some of the patient's behaviors. She was able to discuss these with empathy, despite the difficult nature of the case. She was engaged, interested, and communicated well with this difficult patient."

Overall Hermione is a bright and hard-working student who provided superb care for her patients and grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. She will make a fine physician in whatever field she chooses and I would urge her to consider psychiatry as she would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Mr. Malfoy was assigned to the inpatient residency training unit at Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, as well as to the adult evaluation clinic and psychiatric emergency room at New York Presbyterian Hospital.
At Creedmoor Mr. Malfoy's attending preceptor felt that he performed at an honors level.  In his work with the two patients with whom he met daily, he made great efforts to develop the details of history necessary for an in depth understanding of the patients and their struggles, all while employing a naturally empathic approach which allowed for the development of a solid therapeutic alliance in each case.  His case write-up was solid and comprehensive, and he showed an impressive ability to synthesize the historical, diagnostic and psychodynamic aspects of the case into a three-dimensional case formulation.  He was professional and collegial with patients and staff alike, and his efforts were greatly appreciated by both.  In supervision he participated actively and was thoughtful and open-minded at all times.  In sum it was a delight to work with Draco.
Mr. Malfoy's supervisor in the adult evaluation clinic considered his work to be at a high pass level: "Draco overall performed excellently. He particularly possessed an excellent knowledge base, and obviously had read, and learned, material from his didactic psychiatric class. Further, he was gentle and caring in relating to the patient whom he interviewed, and worked hard to establish appropriate, empathetic rapport. Draco asked required questions for establishing, and 'fine-tuning,' a differential diagnosis, and very thoughtfully applied gathered data to considered diagnostic entities. Finally, Draco admirably sought to improve his interview skills, seeking supervisor's feedback after each patient session."
Mr. Malfoy's overall performance in the clerkship was at an honors level.  He is a talented, dynamic, engaging and empathic student who will make an outstanding physician.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.

Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Patil's supervising attending on the NYS Psychiatric Institute inpatient unit to which she was assigned for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments: "It was a pleasure to have Patil join our team for her clerkship in psychiatry. Patil came from another clinical site during the second week of the clerkship period due to circumstances beyond her control. Despite this mid-clerkship change, she was able to excel -- showing voracious appetite for learning and outstanding motivation to maximize her clinical experience. At all times, she demonstrated in-depth preparation and thoughtful application of complex psychiatric concepts in the care of very sick patients with complex diagnostic co-morbidities. She quickly impressed the primary team with superbly organized and very well-reasoned analyses of the patients' biological and psychological diagnostic bases of illness. She proactively and enthusiastically volunteered to assist in the care of several patients and presented daily at the team meetings. Social workers, nursing staff and consulting teams appreciated her ongoing input, as she was a reliable source of information about the patients she followed. Most importantly, she was also able to communicate effectively with several patients who were severely ill. She volunteered several evidence-based presentations that were well researched and advanced the treatment of patients she cared for. Patil is pleasant, respectful and has a natural gift of being able to form a strong empathetic and therapeutic connection with the patients she works with, at times provided the necessary psychological support and at other times gently and successfully provided psycho-education that gently challenged some maladaptive coping strategies. She provided outstanding care throughout. Patil is superbly well organized and was able to impressively juggle complex schedule of a very busy clerkship in an exemplary way, at all times demonstrating deeply empathic insight into her patients' illness and readiness to work extra hard to provide the much appreciated relief. Very early on in the clerkship she demonstrated professionalism and reliability to follow the maximum number of patients allowed by the clerkship guidelines. Remarkably, she made a positive contribution to ease the suffering of all the patients she worked with. She consistently provided highly professional care and demonstrated sensitivity to diverse issues, all done with high degree of reliability and enthusiasm. Of note, and to underscore her high level of mastery in the clerkship, she was able to do all her work in an efficient manner with some time to spare that allowed her to participate in other cultural and student activities. Patients, nursing staff, as well as interdisciplinary health workers remarked often that it was a pleasure to work with Patil and appreciated her calm but impassioned, collected and knowledgeable approach that inspired confidence in both patients and her co-workers."   Patil's outpatient supervisor added that "It was a pleasure to work with Patil although brief.  She is inquisitive, thoughtful and motivated.  She will be a great asset to any field she chooses to pursue."  Overall Patil is a bright and mature student who threw herself into every aspect of the rotation with enthusiasm and grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills.  Patil will make an excellent physician in whatever field she chooses and I would urge her to pursue her interest in psychiatry as she would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Mr. Crabbe was assigned to the inpatient residency training unit at Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, as well as to the adult evaluation clinic and psychiatric emergency room at New York Presbyterian Hospital.
At Creedmoor, Mr. Crabbe's principal attending supervisor considered his work to be at an honors level: "Vincent came across as a caring, compassionate clinician. He was a delight to work with. He wondered about and discussed ways in which treatment issues are dealt with for an acutely psychotic patient who was constantly pacing and talking to herself. This sensitivity and thoughtfulness towards other patients is wonderful; it reflects his maturity as a clinician. He was thoughtful, intuitive and flexible in his interviewing style. These characteristics helped him build rapport with the two patients assigned to him. He was fascinated by the level of dysfunction in his first patient, who is a college graduate, as opposed to his second patient, a high school graduate who seemed to relate better in the sessions. He sat in on family sessions of  his first patient and was able to identify the strained relationship between the patient and her mother. He was empathic towards  the patient's limitation in asserting herself, the conflict of wanting to please her mother versus herself and the limited insight of her mother posing a threat to patient's compliance with treatment. His second patient had difficulty cooperating with weekly sessions; Vincent was flexible, patient and gentle in trying to engage this patient. He was able to appreciate the mood lability and associated exacerbation in thought disorder that caused variations in the patient's level of cooperation. He did a joint presentation on the Use Antipsychotics in Pregnancy; the presentation was clear, well coordinated, and informative. He handed in one write up, which was comprehensive with a psychodynamically sophisticated formulation."
Mr. Crabbe's attending in the evaluation clinic rated his performance as at an honors level: "This is an outstanding medical student. His evaluation patient presentation was smooth, concise, organized and accurate, and delivered without the use of the evaluation document to guide him. This was quite impressive! I appreciated Vincent's professional demeanor with both patients and staff. It was clear to me that he takes both his education and his responsibility as a medical provider quite seriously. His diagnostic assessment and formulation were thoughtful and accurate, which particularly impressed me given that this is Vincent's first experience in psychiatry. Incredible!"
Mr. Crabbe's clinical performance in the clerkship was at an honors level.  He is a talented, sensitive, empathic and dedicated student who will make a first-rate physician.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Outpatient: "I recommended to Vincent that he continue to gain confidence in the field in order to participate more fully in team discussions, including asking questions or making comments/observations, particularly regarding patients that are not his own."

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text:
Luna's supervising attending on the NYS Psychiatric Institute inpatient unit to which she was assigned for the majority of her clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments: "Demonstrated careful preparation and thoughtful application of complex psychiatric concepts in the care of chronically sick patients with complex diagnostic co-morbidities. Soon after starting her rotation, she impressed the primary team with succinct and very well reasoned analysis of the patients' biological and psychological diagnostic bases of illness. She enthusiastically volunteered to assist in the care of several patients and presented daily at the team meetings. The inpatient team appreciated her ongoing input as Ms. Lovegood was a reliable source of information about the patients she followed. Ms. Lovegood is very well organized and was able to impressively juggle complex schedule of a very busy clerkship in an exemplary way, demonstrating deeply empathic insight into her patients' illness and readiness to work hard to provide the much appreciated relief. She demonstrated professionalism and reliability sufficient to allow for gradual increase of her workload to follow the maximum number of patients allowed. Remarkably, she made a positive contribution to ease the suffering of all the patients she worked with. She consistently provided highly professional care and demonstrated sensitivity to diverse issues, all done with commendable degree of reliability and enthusiasm. At the end of her rotation, Ms. Lovegood presented a well-researched, practical approach to difficult treatment options as far as risk-to-benefit ratio goes, for women contemplating pregnancy. She is pleasant, respectful and is able to form a strong empathetic and therapeutic connection with the patients she works with. Patients shared with me that during their independent meetings, Ms. Lovegood was able to provide the necessary psychological support, including psychoeducation that gently challenged some maladaptive coping strategies without breaking the therapeutic alliance. She provided outstanding care throughout. Of note, and to underscore her high level of mastery in the clerkship, Ms. Lovegood was able to do all her work in an efficient manner with some time to spare that allowed her to participate in other cultural and student activities. Patients, nursing staff, as well as interdisciplinary health workers remarked often that it was a pleasure to work with Ms. Lovegood and appreciated her calm and knowledgeable approach that inspired confidence in both patients and her co-workers." 

Luna's outpatient supervisor added that she was "curious and incorporates feedback." Overall Luna is a bright and hard-working student who provided superb care for her patients and grew significantly in her clinical knowledge and skills over the course of the rotation. Luna will make a fine physician in whatever field she chooses and I would encourage her to consider psychiatry as she would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Please comment on this student's performance in each of the competency domains
 (psychiatric knowledge, patient care, interpersonal and communication skills, professionalism, practice
 based learning and improvement, personal and professional development, and interprofessional
 collaboration). Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify above ratings, and
 particularly address areas of strength and weakness.
answer_text: Lee's supervising attending on the NYP inpatient unit to which he was assigned for the majority of his clinical psychiatry experience made the following comments: "Lee did a superb job on this rotation on 9GN, an adult inpatient psychiatric unit. He demonstrated a sophisticated and nuanced approach to his patients which was compassionate, flexible, and extremely effective. Lee took on some of our most challenging and unconventional patients. He worked very closely with a man who recently had a liver transplant who presented as a transfer to the unit from the transplant team with symptoms of delirium or mania. The diagnosis was unclear and there was much debate on the appropriate treatment for this very ill man. Lee did not rush to any conclusions, but rather allowed the clinical information to develop during his work with the patient. He was a very valued member of the team in this regard. Additionally, he showed exceptional patience and maturity as he managed the patient's wife who was having quite a difficult time managing the stresses of her husband's illness. Lee helped the team, the patient, and the wife, with his steady presence. Lee also did great work with a man admitted with a truly severe and refractory depression who had failed multiple medication trials and ECT was not an option for him given terrible cognitive side effects. Lee read a recent New York Time's article about chronotherapy and he was intrigued. He searched the scientific literature and devised a chronotherapy protocol based on previous studies which could be implemented on our unit. I was very impressed with his excitement, his attention to detail, and his ability to think out of the box, especially when standard treatments had failed. Lee also spent time getting to know the psychosocial stressors which contributed to this man's biological depression, helping the team understand more about the intimacy issues between the patient and his wife which were undoubtedly a major aspect of the recurring illness. Lee will be an excellent house staff officer as he combines academic prowess, intellectual curiosity, attention to detail, with compassion and a lovely sense of laid back humor. His psychological sixth sense will serve him well in whatever field of medicine he eventually goes into. Well done indeed!!!" Lee' outpatient supervisor agreed with the outstanding evaluation and added that he "showed thoughtfulness, dedication and curiosity. He will be a great asset to the field of psychiatry." Overall Lee's clinical performance was one of the strongest by an MCY student that I have seen in several years. He provided extraordinary care for his patients and grew in his clinical skills and knowledge. Lee will make a wonderful physician in whatever field he chooses. I would urge him to pursue his interest in psychiatry as he would make a terrific psychiatrist.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Very bright student, asked insightful questions, active participant in discussions in preceptor sessions. Gave an excellent presentation about a patient he was following with chronic pancreatitis.

	Cedric did a good job on his surgery clerkship. He showed empathy and compassion for his patients.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Ron showed initiative during his rotation logging in above average number of major cases. He scrubbed in surgeries from ductal excision to a pulmonary wedge resection. It was impressive to see that he understood the anatomy and resulting pathophysiology manifestation after the CEA. Ron was able to communicate his assessment and plans on a number of patients in a concise and clear manner. He is intense in seeking opportunities to learn and participate. In the operating room, he was able to demonstrate he can perform interrupted inverted suturing of trocar incisions. Ron also came into the operating room to see a colectomy on a patient he saw in clinic, which showed very impressive initiative. When questioned about the relevant anatomy, he was very well read on the subject. He challenged me on a few occasions to defend my reason for surgical or non-surgical management of similar patients. Ron was an excellent student in his urology rotation. He was described as very attentive, smart and interested. It was obvious he spent time reviewing topics related to the patients presenting to clinic. The attending reported that they discussed cases and his discussions showed his excellent fund of knowledge. Ron's presentations were organized and focused. They were impressive because he always developed a management plan for the patients. The staff enjoyed having him in clinic because he went out of his way to help them and was very respectful. Ron was a valuable team member on the colorectal/general surgery service. He demonstrated different physical exam maneuvers to assess for hernias. He took the initiative to seek out new patients to interview in clinic. Ron worked well with the residents in clinic and the OR. He completed an inguinal hernia by performing as the first assistant. He dissected through the layers down to the spermatic cord and later performed the layered closure. During a robotic case he made the incisions and inserted the trocars in a patient with abdominal adhesions without injuring then bowel. During the left colectomy Ron was able to name and identify the relevant vasculature and the find the planes of dissection in different locations. At the end of the case, he closed the sites via running subcuticular sutures as well as surgical interns. Ron also spent time in the vascular clinic and OR with Dr Moglia. He independently arrived at assessments and plans which included thoughtful work ups. He was comfortable with patients and performed complete vascular exams. Ron was able to name the vasculature on CT angiography images. After a short ultrasound tutorial he quickly learned to recognize arteries and veins on exams. Ron performed above the level of his peers. He took on independent projects including a presentation on aortic aneurysm and dissections for the team. It was prompted by his interest that led him into a CABG operation. I personally worked with Ron in the operating room on two laparoscopic cholecystectomies - in both cases he mobilized the gall bladder off the fossa without perforating it or causing bleeding. His control of the hook cautery was exceptional for his lack of surgical training. On his weekend day he took the initiative to scrub in on a craniectomy with our neurosurgeon. His eagerness to be in the operating room was evident and appeared sincere. All residents and Attendings were impressed with his preparation and ability to engage in the discussions surrounding the patient care. On rounds he was thorough in his presentations. Ron continued his strong performance from the rest of the year in the orthopedic and ENT clinics. He was always well read and was able to participate in clinical discussion of pathophysiology of patients. He independently developed management plans and was able provide his reasoning for them. This was only possible due to his outside reading and research, his fund of knowledge was above average in his group. He had limited participation in the operating room due to the individual providers.

Gregory was an exemplary medical student. He was dedicated to his patients and a true patient advocate, spending time teaching them about their conditions and how to care for themselves at home. He was a pleasure to have on the team, anticipating tasks and volunteering ways he could help make the day run more smoothly (even volunteering to arrive EVEN earlier than pre-rounds to take down dressings, call translators, etc.). He was an efficient multi-tasker, studying in his down time while bird-dogging cases for the team. His calm, friendly demeanor was an asset to the team dynamics and made him a favorite with patients.

	excellent fund of knowledge. strong clinical skills. excellent teamwork. very eager to learn and participate.

	Gregory was absolutely essential to our Vascular Surgery team. His work ethic, confidence, and willingness to be a part of the care of our patients made it feel as though we had another Intern on our team. Gregory demonstrated respect and compassion for both patient and colleague alike, showed sensitivity and responsiveness to a diverse patient population, and was always accessible to the patient's he followed--Gregory displayed exceptional professionalism throughout his time on this clerkship. His fund of knowledge and ability to discuss the complex management of Vascular Surgery patients far surpasses that expected of a student at his level of training. He will make a phenomenal physician; in fact, he already is.

man	Superior work ethic and learning efforts; excellent progress in all phases of the clerkship including presentations and clincial skills; highly personable; outstanding teamwork; aggressive in managing his patients and seeking out learning opportunities; comes off a bit quietly and reserved but clearly delivers in responsibility, reliability, initiative, patient management and assisting his team

	Gregory was a pleasure to have on service. As a third year medical student, he far exceeded expectations for a student at his level of training. Gregory's oral presentation of patients were concise, well-presented, and well-thought out. His notes were thorough and comprehensive. On rounds and throughout the day, he was consistently helpful and was always anticipating the needs of the team. He would make an excellent addition to the house staff. His strong work ethic and enthusiasm for learning did not go unnoticed.

Patil was very dedicated to patient care. Her communication was genuine, meticulous and thorough. She met all of the expectations of a medical student in surgery and went above and beyond in demonstrating humbled attitude, proactiveness and efficiency. Would trust Patil as my physician in the future.

	Very compassionate toward her patients. Spent time building rapport with each patient she came into contact with. She went above and beyond for patients in her care.

	Ms Parvati always shows enthusiasm and interest during rounds and to scrub and participate in the OR. She was very interested in learning how to suture and tie in the OR.

	A very extensive fund of knowledge superior to her colleagues and was able to integrate this knowledge with clinical cases. She is very motivated in self-learning and asks very pertinent insightful questions. She worked very well the residents and faculty She was adept in the OR and was able to anticipate technical steps and their application to the operation.

	Excellent student. Patil has an exemplary attitude to learning. Her surgical skills are excellent for her level of training. Patil involves herself in all aspects of patient care. She is very empathic.

	It was a pleasure to have Patil rotate with us. She was very polite and respectful. She was very motivated and eager to learn basic surgical skills. She always took initiative in the OR to close skin incisions and tie knots. On the floor she was always looking for more responsibilities. She was always in the OR whenever we had complex surgical cases going on. In summary, I believe that she is very self-motivated and intelligent student and will excel in whichever specialty she chooses to pursue.

	Vincent did a great job on his surgery rotation. He has a strong work ethic and made significant improvements over the course of the rotation. Vincent would be an asset to any general surgery residency program.

       Very good  student. Very committed to his patients and to being part of the team. Shows up early. Professional. Very independent learner and clearly spends time preparing for both rounds and cases. Worked very hard to improve his suturing skills.

       Vincent did well on the surgery service. He was inquisitive and eager to learn and participate both on the floor and in the operating room. His presentations improved throughout his time on service, but still at times lacked individual decision making. Right or wrong did not matter, we just wanted to see synthesis of information into a individualized plan. This also improved, but is an area for continued improvement.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Colin was involved in all aspects in patient care. In reviewing his progress notes, it was evident that he understood the important points of a patient's post-hospitalization care. In the discharge of a flap patient, he included instructions about bed elevation, nutrition and seizure medications. During that same case, Colin showed endurance and remained for the majority of the entire case until he was dismissed. In this case as in others, he demonstrated a working knowledge of anatomy. Colin chose a very interesting case to write up, a laparoscopic adrenalectomy for hyperaldosteronism. His understanding of the rational for surgery was clear and his differential diagnosis list was complete. He showed surgical intuition when he included a brief mention of the reason for placement of a drain and the requirements prior to removing it. Most students mention a drain was placed without mentioning its purpose, which Colin appreciated. Colin has a good and calm presence in the OR. He helped get patients in and out of the room to facilitate room turnover. He assisted with myringotomies, middle ear exploration and T&A's. Colin has an awareness and initiative not usually seen in medical students. In the clinic, he performed a thorough H&P presentation including a write up. He was observed doing an ear exam and he performed it with skill. Colin was able to carry out a Dix Hallpike maneuver for BPPV. His discussion of Meniere's disease was impressive for a student at his level. In the orthopedic clinic, he asked insightful questions. His efforts to prepare for clinical encounters were obvious. His questioning of patients demonstrated his knowledge base related to their presenting symptoms and physical findings. Colin helped with a hip replacement and a revision. In both his surgical oncology and vascular surgery clinics, he showed attention to detail in his history taking. He was well prepared for his clinics, which helped him formulate organized H & P's after he interviewed and examined patients. After his presentations, he asked great questions during follow up discussions. His performance improved with each clinic. In his limited operative exposure, he demonstrated understanding of the procedure and the relevant anatomy. Colin worked in the surgical oncology and plastics clinics. His presentations were organized and improved from his earlier patients. He was very affable and patients were happy to talk to him. Dr. Knight found Colin very engaged and motivated. Together they worked on a research project in which Colin was "fundamental" in its inception, development and completion. The project resulted in a peer-reviewed journal acceptance and for presentation at a national meeting. Colin did a good job and continues to work to formulate a differential diagnosis (based upon likelihood of condition and severity).

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Harry did an excellent job formulating differential diagnosis on the Urology service. He was able to prioritize likely disease processes over unlikely processes. He was able to take histories that highlighted his good knowledge base which is better than most. His relationships with staff were exceptional. Harry evaluated patients with anal cancer and GI motility disorders. After giving him feedback, he returned with great knowledge about their management and work up. Great review of the NCCN guidelines for CRC surveillance, which he gave as a short presentation. The staff found him approachable and helpful, the patients established good rapport with him very quickly. In his plastics surgery rotation, he showed initiative in the operating room and the clinic. While other students wait to be asked to scrub in he was prepared at the bedside gowned up ready to help keep the case moving along. With guidance in both clinics, he was able to focus his reading to improve his performance in subsequent clinical exposures. Harry had a strong performance with the ENT clinic. He demonstrated a broad knowledge in ENT above that of his class. His self-directed reading was evident in his participation in the development of the plan for the patients. When questioned about his reasoning for his plans Harry communicated his position with thoughtful reasoning. In a rotation where the students are normally shadowing Harry was able to make a significant impression on one ENT surgeon by taking initiative and remaining engaged. Harry's performance in the orthopedic OR and clinics was described in similar fashion. Harry went beyond the needed commitment as a student (behaves more like a resident) when evaluating patients, making a differential diagnosis and composing a treatment plan. When assigned to research topics he does so thoroughly. He would find time in busy clinics to discuss his finding, many times doing iso by applying information he had learned to a new patient from a prior clinic. He was able to evaluate and develop a treatment plan for anal fissures and gall bladder polyps on the level of an intern. He was so trusted by his mentor that he was asked to communicate to another specialist about the findings and recommendations on patients, which is a role usually reserved for residents. "Harry will perform and achieve fantastically at the residency of his choice" according to one general surgeon. Harry's most outstanding feature during his inpatient rotation was his initiative. He was always looking for ways to reduce the work load on the resident team. He sought out opportunities to participate in cases and consults. In addition when one of the seniors provided constructive criticism he made the necessary changes to his presentations. Multiple residents commented that he was interested in all aspects of team and was an enthusiastic participant on rounds. He contributed to the formulation of plans for patients. His technical skills were appropriate for his level.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Fleur is a joy to work with in the general surgery clinic and the operating room. She is self-motivated and asks questions above her level of training. She is a patient advocate and enjoys spending quality time with her patients. Her oral presentations are pertinent and she includes a wide differential diagnosis. In the endoscopy suite, she was able to recognize indications for endoscopies both upper and lower. She was able to maintain a conversation during complex abdominal wall reconstructions and hand surgery. Her write of TOS included an exceptional differential diagnosis discussion. Fleur worked closely with one urologist who was impressed with her degree of sophisticated questioning on urologic topics. In the operating room, she remained interested and maintained a relevant discussion on the pathology found and the indications for the procedure. During her time in the spine rotation, she was very sharp and bright and did her homework regarding spine interventions well before rotation. She showed amazing capacity to learn multiple complex spine issues in a brief rotation. Fleur arrived in the clinics and the operating room well prepared. She was noted to have appropriate physical exams including the vascular exam. Fleur delivered organized presentations with concise assessments and plans. She demonstrated comprehensive knowledge of some topics which confirmed she was doing outside reading to expand her fund of knowledge. During her time with Dr. G, Fleur was engaged and asked good questions that demonstrated understanding of the pathology of patients. She was reliable in her attendance to assignments for the day. Fleur's most notable quality as a student was her ability to establish rapport with patients and conduct a good pain interview. Fleur participated in the spine clinic with genuine enthusiasm. She was always well prepared for each session. After direction, she was able to formulate a differential diagnosis above her level of training

She  should make a fine house officer.

Pansy performed extremely well despite a challenging service. She was an eager learner who responded very well to feedback, and I felt that my early critiques were quickly incorporated into her presentations and her floor skills. She was excited to learn floor skills to make herself more helpful to the team. She is intelligent and hardworking and was a very pleasant member of the team. She was extremely professional and well prepared at all times throughout the rotation. Her enthusiasm to learn was apparent throughout the rotation, and I think that excitement and eagerness will ensure that she will continue to perform extremely well for the rest of this year and into residency as well.

Very good fund of knowledge. Made noticeable strides to fill in gaps in knowledge. Presentations were solid and management plans were appropriate for level. Very good in the OR in assisting cases, anticipating needs before they were verbalized.

Pansy was an engaged and enthusiastic student. While she is not interested in pursuing surgery as a career, she made a point of participating in the OR to gain diverse experiences on thoracic. Her oral presentations were good when I first started working with Pansy but they improved noticeably over the course of the service. She really paid attention to recommendations she was given and implemented them on rounds. I was always impressed by her ability to include details about patients in a concise, organized way and make nuanced plans for her patients in which she considered alternative outcomes based on the results of certain labs or studies.

Pansy gave a good talk to her peers on GERD.

very eager to be involved with the team. improved presentations. pleasure to have on service.

Motivated, caring, team oriented, always prepared. Will be a star.

A pleasure to work with! Worked very hard, including staying quite late one friday night for a lung transplant even though she was on switch day and I tried to send her home!Very good fund of knowledge, eager to learn. Will be highly successful in whatever field she chooses.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

Vincent (Vincent) was a fantastic medical student and a pleasure to work with. This was his first clinical rotation and he approached it with wonderful curiosity and dedication. His bedside manner with patients is remarkable and he shows great empathy in his approach to their care. By the end of his rotation, his presentations were clear, well thought out and showed a great deal of thought, evidence based medicine, and effort. He was an excellent team player, professional and respectful in every way and enthusiastic about sharing what he learned with the team and his co-students. He is a great pleasure to work with. 

Fund of knowledge: Vincent comes with an excellent level of knowledge for someone just starting his clinical year. he is easily able to follow along with high level conversations, remembers pathophysiology from his lectures very well, and explains clearly and succinctly disease processes we ask about. 
Patient care skills: Vincent has that wonderful, ideal kindness only some caregivers have. When he had a patient where ambulation and rehab were a concern, he would go on walks with her in the afternoon to motivate her. He is tender, sincere, and caring. Moreover he is an excellent listener and goes the extra mile. For an ESRD patient new to the US (here for dialysis placement), she asked about the possibility of renal transplant. He called the renal transplant office to learn more about the process and what resources would be best to give the patient and her family, which they were extremely appreciative for. My only hope is he continues to show these traits as he becomes busier and more senior. 
Presentations: Vincent had a surprisingly good first H&P presentation. he worked on it without much assistance until 8:30 PM, reviewed with our resident for around an hour, and really sailed. He also continued to get better at followup presentations. He has an ability to speak slowly, clearly, and succinctly that often evades most of us until we are more senior. As such his presentations are very easy to follow along. I have no doubt that as his clinical acumen grows he will become more comfortable with presenting plans. 
Communication skills: He did an excellent job asking questions appropriately and always told us when he would be gone. More importantly, Vincent is nearly fluent in spanish. He was an IMMENSE help in many situations, being able to help communicate information to our patients better than anyone else on the team. He was able to discuss his patient with consultants without any issue and present complex developments to the rest of the team. 
Professionalism: Exceptional professionalism, always self-directed and easily coachable. Made the most of his time and worked without complaint. Always pleasant to have around. 
Team work: Always had the "no task too small" mentality.  
Teaching: Did not have the opportunity to see him give a chalk talk. That being said I asked his multiple times to look up differentials for diseases and he always did a good job. He would also come back from preceptor sessions with good ideas for patients. 

Vincent Crabbe
Fund of knowledge: Good. Vincent asked questions that indicated a solid fund of knowledge and a sincere interest in advancing that knowledge past his current level of understanding.
Patient care skills: Vincent was thorough in his physical exams and history-taking, and can continue to work on focusing his evaluations on the patient's chief complaint.
Presentations: Vincent made significant improvements in his ability to present without relying on textual aids during rounds and was consistently formulaic in his presentations.
Communication skills: Vincent took an active role in communicating care plans for his patients with other team members, and he should continue to strive to take on more responsibility for his patients as he progresses through the year.
Professionalism: Excellent. Vincent actively sought out feedback and quite clearly incorporated what he received from all members in his subsequent presentations (e.g. presenting from memory, improving length) or performances of specific tasks (e.g. preparing notes early, closing the loop regarding completed care tasks).
Team work: Excellent. Vincent was an integral part of the care team for his patients and took it upon himself to identify tasks that he could perform that would help the team.  He clearly communicated his obligations to optimize the team's performance and his own medical education.
Teaching: Vincent would often share facts from independent research about clinical topics related to his patients, but should be prepared to offer presentations that might more thoroughly educate his team on the topic of interest.

Vincent was on my sister team, so I did not interact with him much, though his admission presentation on one patient was very well done. His assessment captured the key medical issues with his patient. 

I did not work with Vincent directly but found him to be very pleasant and kind, and I expect will improve with time. Overall he was very easy to work with and his Spanish skills are a huge help! He will require more training in a focused physical/history. 


ALLEN ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge: Vincent approached level. Curious and consistent in his knowledge acquisition. Read more than usual
Patient care skills: Vincent adequate job in the beginning which improved to a higher level throughout. Synthesis was good. Very engaged in the physical exam
Presentations: Vincent appropriate for this very early level of training
Communication skills: Vincent  very good verbal skills and mature in his efforts. Had appropriate confidence in his skills.
Professionalism: Vincent Mature approach and his skills incrementally improved with incorporation of feedback which he appropriately sought.
Team work: Vincent read appropriately and shared with team. Displayed, well, skills he had acquired in his work before Med school 
Teaching:Vincent extremely helpful and sought to assist Housestaff in the care of patients. He is very dedicated and his concern for patients as persons is evident. 

Vincent Thorton
Fund of knowledge
- Vincent was on par for his level and similar to peers, of note he was very much active in learning more about his patients diagnoses and learning the relevant pathophysiology along with asking relevant questions
Patient care skills
- Vincent would be proficient to complete the entire history without any nudging and identified relevant details for the patients initial and follow up presentations
- his physical exam will continue to prosper although at this time he has the basics of the general medical exam
Presentations 
- I could see a very quick and dramatic improvement from day 1 on-ward to his presentation skills including details presented and team plan. I suggested for Vincent to work on differential diagnosis and assessment more than his plan for each problem. His presentations were very detailed/accurate although needed to be more directed towards the admitting diagnosis. Also at times Vincent's order of presentation was jumbled with details from subjective, objective data, assessment, and plan; although he finished with a complete and concise assessment/plan.
Communication skills
- Vincent had great communication with the patient/team and was a valuable part in helping with translation of spanish speaking only patients
Professionalism- Vincent was very professional throughout his rotation and had a great enthusiastic to learn attitude.
Team work- Without any prompting Vincent would help the team with even the smallest tasks and go above and beyond without question.
Teaching- Vincent during his patient presentation would add knowledge and teach what he acquired in reading about his patients medical problems.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
Lavender Brown is a bright and motivated medical student with fine potential, who actively sought to maximize her clinical skills and fund of knowledge in this very important clerkship rotation.  Her working fund of knowledge ably grew during the four weeks, and she clearly responded to the constructive criticism and feedback given to her with improved understanding of disease states and their very tight correlation with underlying pathophysiologic principles of disease.  Indeed, as such principles were applicable to subsequent case studies in the course of this clerkship, they were ably and effectively applied.  Likewise, her clinical skills of comprehensive history taking, over time, showed appropriate balance given to the development of the present illness, but with sufficient acknowledgement and understanding of co-morbid conditions and ancillary illnesses.  In a parallel manner, with resident and hospitalist oversight and continued practice, her physical examination skills also nicely evolved.  Case studies became more methodically secure with balanced understanding of the primary process and the ancillary issues, and with sound development of a full discussion and differential diagnosis.  Indeed, it was gratifying to see this magnitude of growth in the four weeks of this clerkship.

Ms. Brown showed took an active interest in her team responsibilities, and communicated well, and often, to the residents and hospitalists primarily involved in the care of her patients.  She was also an engaging and active resource of important clinical follow-up information on her patients, on whom she regularly rounded.  She provided important information regarding their course of events and anticipated developments.  Her pursuit of the medical literature gave her solid footing of case understanding, information from which she generously gave to her team.  Her comfort level in clinical medicine, in this, her very first rotation of the major clinical year, demonstrably grew, and it was gratifying to see her fund of knowledge and its application achieve the station that it had attained.

AW, MD - Lavender presented a patient with a narcotic overdose succinctly and clearly. She is thoughtful, and interested. She ponders the issues and gives balanced answers.

RB, MD - Lavender proved herself to be a quick learner.  She is eager to apply her knowledge. She did well on her patient presentations. 

ZK, MD - Lavender has been a pleasure to work with.  She was always prepared with topics and gives excellent patient presentations.  She is eager and positive and visited her patients for follow-up regularly.    

CM, MD - Lavender is very professional and is a pleasure to work with.  She is eager to learn and asks questions.   She jumps at an opportunity to pick-up new patients.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

I think what was most impressive about Viktor was his presentations - ALWAYS almost completely by memory and making eye contact with the attendings and residents throughout. This was not the occasional presentation, either - the thought and effort that went into every single presentation that Viktor did was clearly evident. His knowledge base was also suburb but it was how humble and gracious he is that set him apart. I remember one day during rounds I couldn't answer a series of questions about the bleeding risk of ulcers that the attending had asked me. Viktor approached me after rounds that day and taught me about the Forrest Classification and did so in the most professional and gracious manner. It was an absolute pleasure working with Viktor and he will be a tremendous member of any house staff team. 

Viktor was an outstanding medical student. His notes were excellent and presentations were detailed and thorough. He always offered his help to the team and was constantly enthusiastic. He was a pleasure to work with.  Excels in each of the areas of fund of knowledge, communication skills, patient care, professionalism, etc.

Viktor had an impressive fund of knowledge given the point he is in his training. He delivered excellent presentations from memory and did a fantastic job synthesizing complex patients. He worked really well with the team and his fellow students and developed excellent therapeutic relationships with his patients, who really valued having him as part of their care team. He also did a great job building his fund of knowledge based on the patients he took care of and asked well thought out questions. He frequently asked for feedback and used it to improve this notes and presentations. Overall he was very hardworking and humble and a very valuable great asset to the team, functioning at the level of a sub-intern. 

Viktor: Viktor was extremely pleasant to work with. He was a team member, and spent a significant amount of time digging through the chart for patients with complicated past medical histories. Any questions that encountered during that process he was diligent about finding an answer to and always had thoughtful questions about his patients. He has an excellent bedside manner and was very helpful when it came time to organizing things for discharge such as making follow-up appointments and/or counseling patients on how to take medications. I think Viktor's fund of knowledge is well beyond where I would expect a student's to be given his stage of training.  


ALLEN ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge: Good depth, curious, looked up information on topics, honest if there were gaps
Patient care skills: Thorough with chasing down information, obtaining appointments as needed
Presentations: Clear, articulate, done from memory, able to leave out tangential information
Communication skills: Good with multidisciplinary approach, got along well with all staff
Professionalism: Always presentable, excellent attitude
Team work:  Viktorative with fellow students and interns, extremely helpful, would go the extra mile
Teaching: Very enthusiastic, looks up information, will be a great teaching resident

Overall, Viktor did very well during this rotation. He was always professional and worked well with the team.  His fund of knowledge was appropriate for his level of education.  Viktor was eager to learn and knew his patients well.  His presentations were well organized and thoughtful.  Viktor should continue to improve these skills.

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
It was an absolute pleasure to work with Viktor. He is insightful, thorough, inquisitive, respectful of others and humble. He is consistently pleasant and does not become discouraged in suboptimal situations. 
His fund of knowledge is excellent and he readily thinks about  appropriate differential diagnoses. 
He has excellent patient care skills and performed an observed history and physical on a patient who was willing, but hard to understand. Viktor developed rapport with the patient readily and the patient confided new information to Viktor. His physical exam was thorough and he was very interested in learning additional techniques.
Viktor writes extremely well and he readily incorporated constructive comments into his future work.
He presents easily from memory and his case presentations were thoughtful. It is apparent that he enjoys teaching and sharing information with his peers. He participates in the team discussions and asks excellent, thought provoking questions.
Viktor is very professional and even with a heavy work load, completed and turned in his assignments before the deadline.
I believe that Viktor will continue to build on his already high level of skill performance and will be be a physician who uses knowledge, empathy, and clinical acumen to engender trust from his patients. This is especially important at this time since many outside influences are attempting to reduce the importance of the physician to patient bond.

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: I enjoyed working with Neville for the last month at Stamford Hospital.  He has excellent interpersonal skills, and was an active participant in our preceptor sessions.  He has good medical knowledge.  His writeups progressively improved throughout the month, and he was open to feedback.  His final writeup and presentation were both excellent, and on a very interesting case of a patient who presented with Guillain Barre Syndrome.  He presented with confidence, and his reliance on his notes diminished over the course of the month.  His observed history and physical was challenging due to a patient who had a heavy Jamaican accent.  This seems to make Neville nervous, and the H&P was clearly not his best work...he took a very brief history, omitting several important questions, and his physical exam was done in a haphazard way.  Despite this, he did have nice rapport with the patient, and managed to come to a good differential diagnosis.  He did a nice job on a mini-presentation on Guillain Barre Syndrome.  Overall, Neville was a pleasure to work with, and I am sure he will have continued success.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

I worked with Mr. Malfoy in the Allen ICU.  He gave excellent presentations and his work ethic was admirable. 
He did a superb job fitting in and integrating himself with the ICU team.  He always ensured that all plans for his patients were carried out throughout the day.
His medical knowledge was appropriate for a student of his level of training. 

Draco did his internal medicine rotation with our team at the Allen ICU.  Overall, I was extremely impressed with his fund of knowledge and willingness to help the team.  He was a tremendous asset to our team and was eager to learn and teach other medical students lessons in critical care.  His fund of knowledge increased throughout the rotation and he was able to apply his fund of knowledge appropriately in clinical settings.  In addition, his presentations were organized and concise, and he was able to communicate with patients and their families on a professional and personal level.  He was a pleasure to work with overall. 

Draco's presentations are the best I have ever heard from a medical student. The presentations are thorough and organized. His pace and diction are clear and readily understandable. To his credit, an attending physician came into the ICU while Draco was presenting, and could not believe that he was a medical student.
In addition to his presentations, Draco is smart and motivated. His knowledge is at or slightly above his level of training. He is always willing to do anything to help the team and his enthusiasm really helped morale in a sometimes depressing unit. He readily accepts feedback and incorporates it into his practice.
Overall he was really a pleasure to work with. 


ALLEN ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge - good motivation / keen on expanding his fund of knowledge, but at times it shows that he does not have full grasp of the clinical situation
Patient care skills: Diligent in data collection, synthesizing/interpretation of data improved over the course of his rotation
Presentations: Dramatic much improved over the course of his time on the rotation --- succinct / organized, clearly put effort into practicing/improving his presentations
Communication skills: reasonable
Professionalism/team work - friendly and easy going, asks questions openly 

Draco was an enthusiastic student who was very interested in picking up new knowledge.  Excellent H and P's Outstanding presentations.  He did not miss any aspect of even the most complex cases.  He was very tuned in to feedback.

Strengths:
Presentation Skills:  Succinct, well-practiced, complete.
Teamwork: Eager to lend a helping hand, participate in looking up topics, assist with procedures.
Always positive attitude- one of the most positive students I have worked with, pleasant to work with, curiosity about disease states and consistently asking questions for clarity when needed
Areas for Improvement:
Fund of Knowledge:  Clinical decision-making, synthesis of information to form a diagnosis.

ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

Dudley is a fantastic medical student, who is always enthusiastic and brings daily positivity to the team.  He works hard, gives thorough and clear presentations, is up to date on current medical literature, and takes initiative to be as helpful as possible. 

Dudley was a great addition to our ICU team. He was enthusiastic and always willing to jump in and help the team. He knew his patients incredibly well. He asked thought provoking questions on rounds, brought in primary research to share with the team and had a great fund of knowledge. He is well on his way to being a fantastic clinician! 

Dudley Dudley

Communication skills: Dudley did a wonderful job consulting and speaking with services.

Team work: Dudley is such a wonderful team player, top notch!! Always willing to help others. 
Teaching: Does a great job working with others. 


ALLEN ATTENDINGS

Dudley was a medical student during the last rotation in the Allen ICU.  He had an excellent fund of knowledge with clear presentations and communication skills.  He was a team player with a very professional attitude.
It was a pleasure working with him.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
Bronx VA House staff

Thank you for giving me this opportunity to evaluate Lee. 
I have had the chance to work with him on the medical floor of Bronx VA hospital. It's been a pleasure. Lee's patient care skills are the worth mentioning here. His professional way of dealing with patients helped him gain the trust of patients and obtain detailed history and examination. 
He is a very well dressed individual who is always open to constructive criticism and always working to improve his knowledge. 
I wish him a very best of luck in his future. He will make a really good physician. 

I had the opportunity to work with Lee Jordan for a period of about a week. 
In that time, he demonstrated a willingness to learn, and showed a good fund of knowledge. He portrayed a good knack at obtaining history and performing physicals, following up with accurate presentations, adequately depicting what was going on, and demonstrating an understanding of the pathophysiology.
He was able to appropriately communicate findings, problems, solutions, to members of the team.
He showed A good team approach, integrating easily, also interacting  naturally and easily with fellow students. 
All in all, motivated, hardworking.
I wish him all the best.





Bronx VA Attendings 

It was a pleasure to be Lee Jordan's medical preceptor during his time at the James J. Peters VA Medical Center.  He had an excellent grasp of Internal Medicine for someone so early in his clinical career. His presentations were lucid, complete and well-organized.  He had a solid grasp of pathophysiology. Furthermore, Lee impressed the the housestaff with his warmth, empathy and enthusiasm. Overall, he compares favorably with the best students I have taught during the past 35 years.

answer_text: Gregory was an absolute joy to work with. He is extremely conscientious, with a thirst for knowledge and a motivation to assist his patients in achieving the best outcomes. question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
Student: Gregory Goyle 
*Evaluation by medical attending Dr.R: 
Fund of knowledge and curiosity/motivation: Gregory has a solid fund of knowledge for his level of training and sometimes even superior. Reads constantly on his patients and other topics that rise regarding other patients. 
Patient care skills: Excellent patient care skills. Presents multiple patients thoroughly every day. Great presentation skills. Monitors his assigned patients meticulously. Very curious. Thorough physical exam

Communication skills: Great rapport with the team and patients. 
Team work/Professionalism: Team player. Great relationship with the interns and resident.  Receptive. Punctual and professional. A delight to have on my team. Will make an outstanding physician. 

*Evaluation by Dr. F PGY2: 
I have been with Gregory for almost 2 weeks now and I have no doubt he will be an excellent physician be it in the Medical or Surgical field. He comes early and joins the resident sign outs.  He studies diligently and meticulously all the cases assigned to him.  He is a very hardworking student, always asking if there is needed to be done. He follows up on his patients and very much involved in the care of all the team's patients. He is very eager to learn, shows genuine compassion and  is very pleasant not only to patients but to the whole medical/nursing staff.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
Student: Dean Dean
*Evaluation by medical attending Dr.  
Fund of knowledge and curiosity/motivation 
Good understanding of understanding of basic sand applied sciences. Appropriate (and sometimes exceeding) to his level of training. Asks appropriate questions concerning patient management, and rationale for medical decisions.
Patient care skills: 
Excellent patient care skills.  Follows and monitors assigned patients diligently. Thorough physical exam,
Proactive in doing/assisting in minor bedside procedures. Went out of his way to assist us in obtaining out-patient medications for one of our patients. 
Communication skills: 
Excellent communication skills and good rapport with the patients assigned to him. Presentations are informative and through. 
Team work/Professionalism  
Is doing well in our team. Interaction's with other health care staff have bee, professional. Is punctual and conscientious 

*Evaluation by Dr. , PGY2 on the team:
Dean is very active and always enthusiastic to learn and help. Each day he took care of 3 patients and presented to the attending with his own excellent management and plan. He took history and did physical examination thoroughly. He also built up a good relationship with patients, listened carefully and solved out the problems. He is also a good team player. He never hesitated to provide help in patient's care and management as needed. 
As a senior resident of our team, I highly recommend Dean. I am very impressed with his performance and appreciate all his contributions.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Dr N: Katie bell is a very bright, focused, caring and committed medical student who began this rotation with a strong commitment to maximizing her clinical experience at Stamford Hospital, and indeed, she effectively did this through her many case experiences and her proactive involvement in clinical medicine.  Her learning was predicated on optimally understanding the linkage between the overt medical conditions of her patients and the underlying pathophysiology responsible for these states.  She comfortably and effectively immersed herself in all environs of learning, and was eagerly participatory in teaching rounds and discussions, whether or not the specific cases discussed were patients in whose care she was directly involved.  Her commitment to learning and feedback resulted in progressive and continued growth in history taking, striking that balance between the primary focus on the major reason for admission, but putting this information in the context of all other important historical facets.  She also sought to augment her physical examination skills, and sought and eagerly accepted feedback regarding the development of her skill set.  She gave fine and commanding presentations, with proper balance, emphasis, and thoroughness of detail and correlative evidence based resource information.  She explored the medical literature in depth, and always came up with fine differential diagnoses, with thoughtful discussion of each of the possibilities.

Ms. bell is a fine communicator, and related very well and supportively to all of her patients, eagerly sharing information with them as it became available, and always apprising them of the plan of care and anticipated developments.  She also communicated well to members of our house staff, and the attending physicians and consultants with whom she proactively engaged in conversation.  Her appearance and manner are highly professional, she showed integrity, responsibility and reliable in all of her actions.  She very much thrived on feedback with resultant changes brought into place by her commitment to strive for excellence.  She was very much a team player with her residents, and related very well to her student colleagues with whom she had excellent working relationships.

Commentary made by a senior attending physician was that "Katie did an outstanding job presenting a patient with dyspnea with great understanding of the pathophysiology involved. She is a quick thinker and well informed. She is most interested and related unusually well with the patient."

A PG-1 resident wrote that "Katie is very smart and has great presentations. She is always very well prepared."  

One of the two Stamford Hospital chief residens wrote that "Katie is a pleasure to work with and is very hard working. She is thorough with her evaluations and able to concisely present the key points during rounds. She appropriately follows-up with her patients and communicates with the entire team and nursing staff. She has excellent communication skills and is a team player. Katie will be a great doctor one day as she learns more and is able to translate her medical knowledge into clinical practice."

A PG-1 resident who worked closely with her noted that: "Katie knew her patients inside and out and was always willing to go back and get more information from the patients.  Her presentations on rounds were polished and her notes were excellent; she always knew the plan for each patient she followed.  Her discharge summaries were extremely thorough, accurate, and a great help to the medical team.  My only constructive criticism would be to speak louder and more confidently, because what she has to say is very valuable."

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Lee Jordan is an exceptionally mature, thoughtful, and intelligent student.  Lee's performance was superb throughout his medical rotation at the Bronx VA.  
Lee's fund of knowledge of basic and clinical sciences is more than sufficient to evaluate patients with complex medical problems.  His grasp of basic science and clinical medicine is first-rate. He demonstrates insight and clinical judgment and is able to distill what is most important and integrate complex medical and psychosocial information to inform differential diagnosis.  In taking a history, Lee gathers relevant data comprehensively and accurately using a hypothesis-driven, thoughtful, empathic and skilled approach.  He performs a complete and accurate physical exam employing relevant maneuvers and interprets findings correctly.  He acquires and interprets data in formulating sophisticated diagnosis and management plans that take account of patient-specific factors and anticipates possible outcomes.  
Lee generates appropriate and prioritized differential diagnoses and understands sources of bias in interpretation.  His presentations are consistent, organized and succinct, and delivered with great self-assurance.  He produced excellent preceptor write-ups, admission notes, and follow-up notes with concise formulations and appropriate scholarship.  Lee demonstrates highly sophisticated understanding and integration of multiple perspectives of patients, fellow students, and members of the team, and raises the level of discussion in rounds and preceptor sessions.  By virtue of his very excellent communication skills, he has a positive impact on patient care (behavior change, goals of care, delivering bad news).  He shows great energy, empathy, warmth and humor and relates well to patients, students, and staff.  He consistently demonstrates a high level of professionalism, as he is able to earn the trust of the team by assuming responsibility, accepting and incorporating feedback, being industrious, reliable, enthusiastic, helpful and respectful.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Ms. bell is a solid and spirited learner and gained vastly from her many clinical experiences and opportunities.  Her very thorough case work-ups are testimony to her commitment to continued study and pursuit of pathophysiologic linkage to the underlying disease processes.  This is always a relative area for improvement in all medical students with whom I have worked, and I have no doubt about the strong potential and future success of Ms. bell.

ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

Pansy was my student on Allen ICU and I truly enjoyed working with her. She was very professional and she showed up to work eager to learn. She was very helpful in the ICU with tasks and always sought out procedures to perform such as arterial blood draws. In terms of presentations, I was very impressed with Pansy's thoroughness and confidence. She knew her patients well and her attention to detail was impressive. Pansy's fund of knowledge is where I would expect for a student early in clerkship year, but I was very impressed by her constant drive for improvement. For example, she would go home and read NEJM review articles on acid-base disorders and hypoxemia to improve her knowledge. Overall, I was very impressed with Pansy, and I would be very happy to work with her again.   

I worked for a brief time with Pansy. Her fund of knowledge was very good, and she was functioning at a level appropriate for her time spent on MCY. Her presentations were very well organized. She was always very eager to learn and to help out the team. Very good team player! 





ALLEN ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge : OUTSTANDING, one of the best students I have ever worked with. New about topics and looked things up independently. Answered appropriately on rounds. 
Patient care skills: Outstanding- very careful, thorough, excellent bedside manner.
Presentations: Outstanding- simple, concise, accurate, to the point. 
Communication skills: Outstanding- her best strength. Clear, articulate, confident, without being overbearing. 
Professionalism Outstanding
Team work:  outstanding- very helpful, engaged
Teaching: outstanding
Pansy was definitely one of the best students I have ever worked with overall. Hard working, smart, engaged, great to work with.  

Fund of knowledge:  solid fund of knowledge, able to discuss broad differentials and appropriately focus them

Communication skills: good communicator with team and family, 
Professionalism positive attitude, pleasant to work with, hard working 
Team work: helped team with all aspects of care
Teaching: provided excellent presentations on topics determined by the resident on clinical questions presented on rounds.
