question: Write ups
label: 3

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
Bronx VA House staff

Patil is very passionate physician. Her fund of knowledge, curiosity to learn is awesome. She is an outstanding , intellectual student with very humble beginnings.  She is very hardworking. 
Patient care skills: Patil had very good  history taking skills with accurate information including her physical exam, drawing the differentials from her history. 
Dr. Patil has great presenting skills and was great in interactive sessions. 
Communication skills:  Patil has excellent communications skills and very passionate with her patients, colleagues, residents, fellows and attending. Her professional attitude is very good and she is focused and at the same time she is very friendly, and enthusiastic in learning. 
Team work: She is a great team player and has great leadership qualities with a concept of working together and leading the team. 
Also she shares her knowledge and discuss various cases with fellow team members. 
Finally I am privileged to work with Patil, and it was immense pleasure. She is one of the most compassionate individuals towards patients. I wish her all the best for her future.  

Patient care skills: Great job in collecting history and physical exam findings and able to identify key physical findings.
Presentations: Clear, concise, and accurate presentations.  
Communication skills: Excellent communication skills including patient, team, and staff. 
Team work: Great team player, always offering her help, 
Teaching: Participated in teaching rounds and helped with research for presentations. 

I had the pleasure of working with Ms. Patil Parvati on the medicine floor. 
Her fund of knowledge is good and she was always curious to learn. 
She was a consummate professional always being on time and courteous with all her colleagues.
One incident that stood out for me was the way she handled the situation of an agitated patient. It was early in the morning even before Ms. Parvati was scheduled to come in to work and one of her patient's was suspected of having a stroke. When she came in early and became aware of the situation, she immediately went to the patient's room. I being the on-call resident/intern, was called to see the patient. That's when I had the opportunity to witness not just her patient care skills but her amazing communication skills. The patient was agitated and was not letting anybody near him. But when we walked into the room, it was clear she had a built a relationship of trust with her patient & was able to talk to him in a very personable way to calm him down. She demonstrated the important ability of staying calm amidst chaos. She demonstrated good physical exam skills and good knowledge of her patient's previous medical history, the changes she noticed in his physical exam, current treatment plan and goals of care of the patient. The way she handled herself in the situation and her ability to form a relationship of trust with her patients will take her a long way. I would be more than happy if I had someone as my Doctor with her communication skills and approach. 

She is very ambitious and hard working student, very knowledgeable and approachable. She has an amazing relation towards both residents and patients. 

Briefly, Patil Parvati, We call her P"; is a exceptional student who I believe can  "walk on waters" might be a understatement.
Well is all seriousness my feedback is as follows:
Fund of knowledge : She is always interested in learning more and brings back diseases to the pathophysiology; not only learns but teaches in the process. She ties the knowledge to real patient by explaining / counselling the patient in lay language.
Patient care skills: She is above average in History taking and her examination skills are exceptional. 
Presentations: She is a confident storyteller; understands pertinent + and -ives.
Communication skills: excellent
Professionalism: Respectful and calm soul. Very professional. 
Team work: never delinquent; understands her role in given team work; leads by example when put to it.

Bronx VA Attendings 

I worked with Patil. Parvati during her first week on the wards on the medicine service at the Bronx VA.   
She quickly adapted to the inpatient service and was eager to take care of the patients on her team and learn about their diseases and medical history.  
Her presentations were clear, and she was appropriately able to hone in on the relevant details and establish a differential diagnosis.  I often noticed that she was asking her senior resident questions about the patients she was following.  She was eager for feedback about her presentation style and continually wanted to improve her skills from the first day.  

It was a delight supervising Patil Parvati as ward and teaching attending while she rotated through our medical ward 7C at the JJP VA Medical Center. I worked with her from January 17 to 31, 2017.
She has an astonishing medical knowledge including of many of the latest research studies. She leaves out no opportunity to expand her knowledge by reading up on all patients and their clinical problems whom she is involved in. Her patient presentation skills, both written and verbal, are at a high level, even though this is her very first clinical rotation. Her history taking is detailed, yet she knows how to separate important information of high priority from secondary data. She goes through great length to obtain details on significant remote medical events through our extensive medical record system to get a comprehensive picture of the patient. In particular, she skillfully incorporates details on the patient's psychiatric and psychosocial history into her report. Her physical examination is just as thorough, and she knows how to emphasize abnormal and relevant normal findings in the context of the patient's clinical presentation. Her progress notes are at the same time detailed and concise and are well organized. And again, she constantly seeks feedback on how to improve her note-writing skills.
In her first clinical rotation, Patil adapted quickly to the new work environment working closely with her team of residents from day one. She eagerly took on new patients whom she would follow longitudinally engaging closely with the physicians who saw her patients in follow-up after discharge. Patil relates well to her patients and their relatives, and her genuine empathy comes across naturally. She has an extraordinary ability to communicate with patients on their level. When we asked the patients, it became clear that they had a good understanding of their illness and its treatment. She is also a great team player, and her hard work and collaborative spirit was appreciated by residents, nurses, social workers, and attendings alike. She also tries to understand the meaning of illness for a patient on a spiritual and
philosophical level. She shared several papers describing stories of patients (some of them physicians) who not only coped with their physical disabilities but went on to accomplish great achievements in their fields.
Patil gave an extraordinary presentation to the whole team on a patient with idiopathic vomiting, including data from the very latest literature on the topic. With great ease, she moved between very different aspects of the disease, from psychological aspects down to the receptors involved in various antiemetic drugs. This was a scholarly presentation of a level we see rarely even with residents or fellows.
Patil' pleasant personality is matched by her self-confidence that gives rise to an assertiveness that, employed with characteristic gentleness, serves her well when she advocates for patients, asks questions, or makes contributions to the medical team's treatment plan.
One area which Patil will improve on is to project her voice well, so everybody hears the important things she has to say. We agreed that one way to go about practicing this is to go to the banks of the Hudson River and sing contemporary Brazilian songs in a way that the people in New Jersey can hear them.
Overall, Patil has shown to be an exceptional student with an inquisitive mind coupled with a steep learning curve, a strong commitment to caring for a patient in a holistic fashion, and a great sense of team spirit.
We hope you will send her back to us for future clinical rotations.

question: Professionalism
label: 4

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

Fund of knowledge:  Luna is motivated and curious.  She is always looking things up to aid her learning and is always asking appropriate questions.  Her fund of knowledge is appropriate for her current level.  
Patient care skills: She takes complete history and physical exams.  She is a good historian and thorough in collection of her information.  She is able to synthesize information well.
Presentations: clear, accurate, and succinct presentations that have improved much through the rotation.  She is currently on her first inpatient rotation
Communication skills: Good communication skills with the team and consultants and the patients. 
Professionalism: Always professional and has a good attitude.  Integrates feedback well 
Team work: Great team member 
Teaching: shares knowledge with the team about subjects that she looks up.  Did a comprehensive presentation on COPD etiologies and management.

Luna (Luna) Lovegood
Patient care skills: Luna showed great empathy and caring in working with her patients. She assisted in caring for a particularly difficult patient in the ICU who had a complicated psychiatric and substance abuse history, and remained calm and collected in working with the patient. She has excellent bedside manner and technical skills.
Presentation: Luna's presentations were clear, and she continued to gain confidence in her presentation skills throughout the rotation.
Professionalism: Luna maintained a positive attitude throughout the rotation and demonstrated enthusiasm for learning and participating in patient care. She collaborated with the other medical students on the team, all of whom were sub-Is, and graciously took the opportunity to learn from their experience.
Team work: Luna was an active team member and was extremely helpful in obtaining collateral information about our patients, which is an essential component of ICU level care. 

Luna did a great job on her time in the Allen ICU.  The ICU is an extremely challenging place to work early in clinical rotations, and during Luna's time we had very complex patients.  Luna quickly adapted and in no time was mastering complicated medical topics.  She was extremely responsible, thorough and always eager to help.  She was also very responsive to feedback and it showed in how quickly she learned to present and manage very complex patients.  

Luna (Luna) Lovegood
- Fund of knowledge: Luna has a great fund of knowledge, and was very proactive in reading about her patients and supplementing and building on what she knows to round out her understanding of her patients. She was very motivated in immersing her self in really getting to know her patients.  
- Patient care skills: Luna was very diligent and thorough in her H&Ps. She was dedicated to spending additional time with her patients to fully understand their presentations, and in several instances her conversations with her patients and their outpatient providers directly impacted our treatment plans (for example, in collecting history about prior ARVs her patient had tried to help us craft a new regimen for his HIV given newly discovered tenofovir toxicity). 
- Presentations: Luna gave excellent presentations. She was thorough and succinct, and even in the setting of sensitive bedside presentations she was able to present cases in a way that was sensitive to the patient yet honest and thorough for the team. She handled herself extremely well! 
- Communication skills: Luna had excellent communication skills. She continuously checked in on her patients, and developed warm, caring therapeutic relationships with them which I know the patients appreciated. She was also instrumental in helping to communicate with outpatient providers and family members to help make their transitions of care more seamless and effective. 
- Professionalism and attitude: Luna was always very professional and respectful to everyone around her. She was very dedicated and hardworking, and her excellent work ethic came across in her interactions with the team. 
- Team work: Luna was an integral member of our team and did an excellent job of helping to carve out her own effective role on the team. She was proactive and accomplished tasks she could help with without even being asked. She certainly helped make our work (and the care of her patients!) easier and more efficient. 
- Teaching: Luna was very proactive about contributing to our teams' education as well, both through using her presentations as opportunities for reading and teaching points, and through topic presentations she gave during rounds.  
Overall, Luna was a key member of our team and an excellent medical student, and I thoroughly enjoyed working with her!


ALLEN ATTENDINGS

Fund of knowledge-average
Patient care skills-average
Presentations-this was a weakness.  She completely read an entire presentation from her computer and was switching between screens to look for data.  She did not seem to have memorized any of the presentation.
Professionalism-average

She was professional with a good attitude (professionalism).  She was effective and always willing to help (teamwork).  The one or two presentations I heard were clear and accurate, not too lengthy (appropriate), but not necessarily from memory.  

Luna did not get the opportunity to be observed too long but her one presentation was thoughtful and well formatted.

Luna:
Fund of knowledge : outstanding, often had intern level understanding of situations
Patient care skills: excellent- helped the residents considerably
Presentations: outstanding- very clear thinking and all relevant details presented
Communication skills: excellent, only weakness is that she is a bit quiet, but works very well with patients and families
Professionalism : excellent
Team work: outstanding- helped out everyone a lot
Teaching: outstanding- presentations excellent 

Fund of knowledge great fund of knowledge and she continues to read on new topics
Patient care skills: thorough histories, did not watch her do PE
Presentations: could be long, repeating same info several times, continue to practice presentations focusing on pertinent details. No need to report everything the patient tells you, but try to paint a picture of what you think is going on to guide to your top diagnosis within your differential. practice out loud, this will help your efficiency 
Communication skills: soft spoken, but respectful. interacts well with staff and patients
Professionalism hardworking with a positive attitude, encourage you to become more outspoken
Team work: per team helped with all aspects of patient care
Teaching: did several small presentations on questions raised during rounds the previous day in concise, easy to digest modules 

Luna Lovegood demonstrated excellent bedside manner, empathy, and solid knowledge base, and enthusiasm during our busy ICU rotation during which we interacted for under a week. She was initially guarded, much as we all were this early in our training but displayed a real sense of caring, warm bedside demeanor and a strong interest  in learning and teachability. Superb beginning, portends a very promising future. 

Luna did a very good job in the Allen ICU during her MCY rotation.  She participated in rounds and academic discussions.

question: Teamwork and Professionalism

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

Penelope was incredible. For some of our most complicated patients she really took the time to read and think and pushed our differential as a team, most memorably when she synthesized a patient's delirium, negative tox screen, and complex social history into a compelling diagnosis of clonazepam withdrawal. In advancing her patients' care she was our de facto sub-I for the two weeks she was on service. She was able to manage multiple complicated patients with ease. She is also a pro at a-sticks, has an impressive fund of knowledge, and is sharply attuned to team dynamics. Really a pleasure to work with. 

Fund of knowledge: Penelope's fund of medical knowledge was excellent. Not only did she enter the rotation with a substantial grasp of pathophysiology and management, but Penelope consistently read up on patients and conditions. She shared her learning with the medical team, acting not only as a curious learner but also educator 
Patient care skills: empathic, patient-centered, took the time to talk to patients and hear their concerns which often led to new clinically-relevant information being unearthed
Presentations: succinct, contained all relevant information, accurate
Communication skills: practice closed-loop communication, reliable, comfortable talking to consultants. Was especially impressed one busy afternoon when she provided signout to accepting team for transfer for a patient she had not formally followed, which demonstrated how engaged she as in all patients' care
Professionalism: outstanding. Worked well with all members of interdisciplinary team. Responsible, thoughtful, kind, team player. Took on tasks not exclusive to her dedicated patients she was following.
Team work: as above, exceedingly collaborative. 

Penelope shows clear enthusiasm for Medicine and goes out of her way to make sure that she is learning, requesting and giving feedback, and taking care of her patients. She is working hard to prepare herself for residency by taking on more patients and more patient care tasks. She is rapidly developing her clinical knowledge and develops thorough plans for patients' work-up. She can continue to improve by building her confidence with less common diagnoses and by practicing using open-ended questions in patient interviews.

Penelope was an exceptional medical student during my time working with her over the course of a week in the Allen ICU. Her presentations were extremely succinct, well organized and thorough, which was perfect for the ICU setting. It was very impressive how she also managed to present mostly from memory, which is something very difficult to do in ICU patients with many ongoing active issues. She chose to admit and follow patients that were particularly interesting and very challenging from a diagnostic and management standpoint - in particular she worked up a young patient with severe acidosis (pH<6.9) with acute ketoacidosis of unclear etiology and helped tremendously with her management by finding case reports of very similar presentations. She continued to follow the patients after completing the rotation and updated me on their condition after I had left the service as well.  She was an avid self-directed learner and often looked up journal articles and reviews related to active issues with several of her patients - this was extraordinarily helpful for both patient management and education of the entire team. Penelope was truly a team player and it would be great to work with her again in the future!
(L, M.D)


ALLEN ATTENDINGS

General-Penelope was enthusiastic throughout her rotation but sometimes she had trouble finding her place within the team. 
Fund of knowledge - curious and motivated.
Patient care skills: took good history and reported okay physical exams. 
Presentations: clear and succinct, also accurate however not from memory. 
Communication skills: she made honest attempt to communicate with the team, but sometimes spoke up at odd times. 
Professionalism - not particularly self directed, has some preoccupation performance. 
Team work: definitely tried to be team player
Teaching: do not remember if this occurred or not so cannot comment. 

Fund of knowledge -	Intellectually curious, showed that she was reading about her patients. One patient in particular was complicated medically, unclear etiology of her metabolic disarray, delirium and respiratory failure.  While the whole team up to the attending was stumped, Penelope kept up with the team bringing up possibilities in the differential diagnosis, suggesting workup to help narrow the Ddx, and taking it upon herself to read up on some of the rarer possibilities.  She was also very consistent with asking questions to fill knowledge gaps. 
Patient care skills - In the above case, Penelope diligently pursued collateral information on her patients to help us better understand the clinical context and to add to or narrow our Ddx. 
Presentations -	I honestly don't recall that her presentations were from memory, but they were clear, accurate and succinct.  On occasion she would need to review in the EMR for details that she did not know off-hand that were relevant to the presentation, but that is part of gaining knowledge of clinical relevance (see patient care skills). 
Communication skills - Excellent communication skills.  Had a great rapport with the multidisciplinary staff. Was actively involved w/ consult services.  Consistently developed an outstanding rapport with patient families and as such able to get relevant details that were important to patient care. 
Professionalism - Excellent contributor to the team effort. Integrated well into the team as an MCY student in a busy ICU environment. 
Team work - Excellent contributor to the team effort. Integrated well into the team as an MCY student in a busy ICU environment. 
Teaching - No fellow students. But readily shared knowledge gained from reading specifically about patient, as well as information / collateral history obtained from family and OSH providers.  

Fund of knowledge : very good fund of knowledge and curiosity about physiologic processes. Penelope's curiosity about medicine is impressive, throughout our time she asked great questions and independently researched different topics.
Patient care skills: took complete ownership of her patients, spoke to families and took the time to make patients feel comfortable with the ICU.  Her compassion is truly amazing.
Presentations: Good presentations. Constantly sought feedback on how to improve presentations.
Communication skills: works well with entire multidisciplinary team. Takes time to introduce herself to nurses and ancillary staff.
Professionalism always professional. Engaged and thoughtful )
Team work: ally was an integral part of the team and worked very well with everyone. She volunteered to help in any way she could and was always enthusiastic.
Teaching: independently investigated different patients and offered valuable insight into patient care.

question: Write ups
label: 5

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

Seamus's enthusiasm, eagerness to learn, and teamwork were such a wonderful contribution to the team. He has a good fund of knowledge and a solid foundation. His patient care skills are more than diligent - he once picked up a major finding on history that both residents missed and led to a completely different path for the patient. He was tireless in his efforts to gather collateral, was clear and professional. He will make a wonderful physician in the future, and I was so thrilled to have worked with him. 

Professional, and always willing to help the team. Because of Seamus's detailed history taking, we even discovered that a patient had severe depression and suicidality, something we as the residents had missed; which completely changed the patient's treatment trajectory. Overall Seamus had a great attitude, gave great presentations on rounds, built therapeutic alliances with patients and families, performed detailed histories and physicals and was really nice to work with. 

I worked directly with Seamus and found him to be an essential part of our team by the end of my time with him. He was curious and had a good fund of knowledge. He was diligent and careful with his history and physical exam, and his patients universally loved the sensitive and professional care he provided. His presentations were well-organized and became increasingly focused as the rotation progressed. It was a pleasure to work with Seamus and he will be a great resident. 



ALLEN ATTENDINGS

Seamus was an actively contributing member of our medical team, eager to admit new patients and pick up patients of his own. He followed his patients and presented them very well each morning, though there were occasional details missed. Seamus was clearly reading about his patients at home, which was phenomenal, and he would also read studies that we mentioned on rounds and bring in his perspective on them the following day.


Seamus was always engaged and asking about pathophysiology. He would often take it upon himself to look up the rationale behind decisions and then share with the team. In one impromptu discussion about a patient with an UGIB, Seamus recalled a study he had read about UGIB management and was able to recite the study findings and explain the rationale with ease - the residents did not even know the study in the same level of detail as Seamus did! He also gave an excellent presentation on secondary progressive MS that was clear, concise, and relevant to our patient. His presentations were overall good, but could continue to focus on using the data to tell the patient's story that makes the overall differential and conclusion obvious to the listener. He was always professional, always willing to go above and beyond to help out the team and his patients, and will be a phenomenal resident.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text:
Penelope is an exceptional student. She has a very strong foundation of knowledge that exceeds what I would expect at her level. She clearly has a deep interest and love of physiology. This strong foundation of knowledge feeds her exceptional clinical reasoning skills. She is able to take very organized histories because she is clearly formulating a differential diagnosis in her head while speaking with the patient. Her write ups were outstanding. The histories were very detailed but relevant and organized. She knew all of her patients very well. Her PEs were also very detailed and always included relevant positive and negative findings. Her assessment and formulations were where she really shined. I was truly impressed by her level of reading and understanding of clinical problems. She did two weeks in the ICU and was able to get a handle of very complex patients. SHe had a very complicated patient with a metabolic acidosis and osmolar gap. She wrote an outstanding write up on this problem and what she thought was going on based in physiology. 

She is also a pleasure to work with. She is great with patients and her fellow students. She clearly loves to teach and did multiple informative presentations to the group. She truly seems to love to learn for learning's sake.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
Dr N: Hermione Granger is a hard-working, conscientious, interactive, and responsible medical student, with an excellent work ethic, who came to this rotation with a highly evident commitment to compete each day with the knowledge and gratification of newly acquired information, and the gratification of making a difference in the lives of the patients with whom she was able to effectively interact as part of the patient care team. Her learning grew continuously and seamlessly each day of this rotation, and it was nurtured by her commitment to understand underlying pathophysiologic principles and the relationship of those principles with the overt clinical diseases states in which her patients presented. Her standards of performance and commitment to continued and progressive growth and development were highly evident throughout.
Relevant to patient care skills, Ms. Granger showed fine skill in history taking, and comfortably covered all of the often multiple medical issues her patients faced, but still securing the preeminence of the fundamental clinical problem while adequately including all other medical issues and needs that had to be addressed. Her physical examination skills grew well, and as an integral component of her much sought feedback to all components of her educational experience, she would seek the counsel and mentorship of residents and attending physicians to confirm the continued refinement of her physical examination skill set. Along with her resident teammates, and as an important member of the patient care team, Ms. Granger took ownership of her patients and actively participated in the case management process. As a result, she had fine mastery of each of her cases, with solid command of her oral presentations, replete with appropriate emphasis, sequence, and balance. Likewise, her written case studies were thoughtfully done, a result of obvious hard work, dedication, and incorporation of evidence based literary resources that greatly enhanced the flow and critical understanding of the many components of her differential diagnosis. Her clinical enthusiasm was evident in the manner of her presentations, and her responsiveness to queries at the end of the presentation from her student colleagues.
Ms. Granger is an excellent communicator. Thoughtful and attentive to the comments and queries of others, but likewise very participatory and engaged in case discussions and teaching rounds, it was evident that she well understood both the dynamics and the indispensability of the rounding process, with the natural flow of relevant clinical pieces of information that were brought to heightened levels of discussion through a mastery of the underlying subject matter. Ms. Granger is also highly professional in manner and conduct, with demonstrable integrity in her commitment to study and learn, and the necessity of its applicability to the care and well-being of her patients. She focused much on the magnitude of her responsibility, and her passion for medicine was underscored by her general concern for thoughtful case work-ups and appropriate studies, continuous efferent response to information and data that was generated, and the necessity of an overall care plan in anticipation of completion of all that could be done on the in-patient service. Her teamwork was evident in her relationship with her student colleagues and with her residents, who gave her high words of praise.
A, MD - did not present a patient to the group. She readily understood medical issues and is average in her knowledge base. She accepted feedback readily.
M, MD - Hermione is an impressive student with a compassionate personality. She is comprehensive in her presentations and follows up closely with patients.
D, MD- Hermione is an intelligent student who is very helpful on the team. She gave a great presentation on refeeding syndrome; it was also well organized and informative.
J, MD - Hermione was a pleasure to work with. She was hardworking, very proactive and always eager to learn and present topics during rounds. When she presented her patients during rounds, it was thorough and very organized. She knew her patients well. Her medical topic presentations were excellent. I would be happy to work with Hermione again! Overall Hermione was one of the best medical students I have had the opportunity to work with. In addition to helping the medicine team out with routine tasks like calling consults and following up labs, she would help the other students out as well and was a great team player, which is always a great thing to see.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
NR, MD: Oliver Wood is an intelligent and responsible medical student who began this rotation with a very strong foundation of knowledge with the additional amplification of his commitment to correlate underlying pathophysiologic principles with the clinical scenarios of the presentation of his patients. He also sought to regularly and consistently augment his foundation of knowledge, and this was consistently done throughout the rotation. He showed much curiosity, and was intellectually rigorous as he held himself to high standards of professional performance. His patient care skills were strong and sound, and as I had the opportunity to serve as his mentor in Primary Care Medicine which he completed just prior to beginning this clerkship, I noted very solid and sustained growth in history taking and physical examination technique. This was evident in his thorough development of the fundamental primary clinical issues, and with additional important ancillary history that created a fuller, three-dimensional understanding of the extent of all clinical issues. His oral presentations were clear, accurate and relevant to each case at hand. It was evident through the material he obtained from his patient questioning was insightful and that his physical examination skills were replete. Through his oral and written case studies, it was also evident that he assiduously utilized available literary resources and that he provided a sound differential diagnosis with thoughtful reasons both for and against a given diagnostic entity.
Mr. Wood has fine communication skills, as he frequently rounded on his patients to regularly garner new and insightful information. Further he empathetically and supportively provided them with important follow-up relevant to their hospitalization. His communication skills additionally extended to the other health care professionals involved in the care of his patients, including residents on his patient care team and supervisory hospitalists who additionally served as team educators. This underscored his commitment and bonding to the patient care team and his work ethic, attitude and professionalism. He very much sought and deeply gained from feedback that was provided to him. Noteworthy was his response to such feedback in the demonstrable growth in his skill set and clinical mastery. He additionally loved to teach and shared knowledge he had attained with his student colleagues.
AW, MD
Oliver did an excellent presentation of a difficult AIDS and addicted patient with great insight. He readily explores alternate possibilities, is comfortable with the issues and is eager to learn.
* All students worked well together and shared their thoughts.
SC, MD Oliver shows great enthusiasm to learn about his patients. He is very professional and has excellent bedside manner. I would encourage him to continue reading and increase his fund of medical knowledge on the pathophysiology of the disease processes which his patient's exhibit.
TV, MD
Oliver has been a pleasure to have on the team. He shows interest and enthusiasm in all of our patients and has rounded on all the team's patients with me. He carries at least two patients and participates in our admissions. His notes are relevant and well-presented. Oliver shows empathy with his patients and visits them multiple times throughout the day.

question:
Narrative Comments

Please comment on this student's performance in each competency. Comments should refer to specific behaviors, reinforce/clarify your above ratings, and particularly address areas of strength and weakness. These comments may be included in the Dean's Letter.
answer_text: Oliver is an interested, curious and engaging student.  He brought a unique perspective to our preceptor sessions.  Oliver often was the one to ask out-of-the box questions, and to have the view from 10,000 feet when analyzing case presentations of his peers.  His own case presentation was certainly challenging in that the individual he chose was a very complicated man with advanced HIV disease, inoperable rectal carcinoma, poorly controlled diabetes, and multiple hospital admissions for recurrent rectal abscesses and bleeding.  Unsurprisingly, this patient had significant socio-economic challenges to managing his own care.  Oliver did his best to present from memory, but this was certainly difficult, and although it was hard to parse out the pathophysiologic  "pivot points" in this case, Oliver did a good job identifying the areas of concern in his social support that could be improved upon, thereby improving adherence and the patients overall health.   Oliver's written cases showed consistent improvement during the course of the clerkship.  He responded well to feedback, and was eager to learn.  Oliver's topic presentations gravitated to papers analyzing interventions at an institutional level, whether outpatient clinic programs for obesity management in diabetics or skilled nursing facilities using education programs for their staff to improve care and communication with family of advanced dementia patients.  In each instance  he identified the challenges of such research, and why answering the questions posed by the papers are all the more important because of those challenges.  Oliver demonstrates an adequate fund of knowledge for his level of training and is interested in reading and learning more.

question: Areas for Improvement Please comment on areas where this student's performance could be improved. These comments will be shared with the student but not included in the MSPE (Dean's) letter.
answer_text: Oliver would do well to evaluate patient data up close and break down the issues for more effective analysis.  Although in general, Oliver was able to develop a good formulation and differential, attention to specifics (such as lab values) were sometimes less detailed than expected.  Granted many of the cases in question were complex, but that requires that much more effort to work through in a granular way.

answer_text:
Cho Chang: 

A very eager and enthusiastic learner with genuine intellectual curiosity. Her knowledge is appropriate for her level of training. Discussions in her write up improved significantly with each submission which reflected growth of knowledge and her ability in applying that knowledge in her work. Her discussions both in oral and in written presentations displayed the expansion of the depth of knowledge as well as the familiarity of the illness. Demonstrated a remarkable improvement in prioritizing differential diagnoses as well as the treatment approach.   
Took into consideration the risk benefits of treatments. A patient she was managing with cancer with metastatic disease to the vertebra resulting in imminent lower spinal cord compression, the    
Team was aggressively pushing for surgery even when the patient was reluctant. Taking everything about the patient into consideration, including the fact that he had been bed bound with inability to ambulate for months, she made a legitimate argument regarding the risk of performing the surgery with the patient refusing and what benefit it would bring the patient. When the medical team was trying to convince the patient, she was the first person, who felt benefits did not outweigh the risks. Subsequently the Neurosurgeon who evaluated the patient, came to the same conclusion as her.
She is almost at the level of an Educator

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
MD: Neville Longbottom is a conscientious, bright, and thoughtful student began this rotation with a sound infrastructure gained from his earlier basic science education as well as the more than ten months of this major clinical year that had already transpired and which included a wide spectrum of antecedent clinical experiences. In addition, there was definable growth and refinement of this foundation base, with gratifying and demonstrative linkage of newly acquired clinical growth to underlying pathophysiologic principles. In a parallel manner, his clinical command relevant to his required five formal case studies, and the associated history taking and physical examination skills also demonstrated definable growth in accrual of technique and focus, as well as in demonstrable confidence and command. Along with the house staff team, with whom he worked closely and assiduously, he very much felt ownership and responsibility of these cases, and strove for thoroughness and refinement. His ease of accessing the medical literature, and finding relevant corroboration to strengthen his differential diagnoses were also fine traits that readily grew throughout the rotation. His presentations showed case knowledge, not overlooking all aspects to relate, but clearly with the appropriate balance and emphasis relevant to the predominant and presenting clinical issues. His written case studies, as well, were thoughtfully done with much effort and energy that went into their creation.
Mr. Longbottom is a fine communicator, and his frequent clinical rounding on his patients provided support, empathy, and reinforcement of the quality of care that they were receiving along with the anticipated future studies that might be necessary. He regularly communicated with his student colleagues, and their relationship as a group was mutually supportive and collegial. He was also an important asset to the patient care team as he regularly rounded with them and provided follow-up clinical and resource information. He was professional at all times, with demonstrable responsibility and commitment. He very much accepted and integrated feedback into all of his activities and responsibilities. MD - presented a patient with progressive dementia and severe hypertension. He fully understands the basic medical issues and has very good judgment in assessing problems discussed. He is thorough, thoughtful and well balanced in his conclusions. He is curious and eager to learn. MD - Neville always willing to put in extra effort to do more than what is required. He is a great student that is very helpful in ideas for managing patients. Neville prepares well for presentations and delivers information effectively.  MD - Neville is a hard-working medical student and was very nice to be around. He worked hard on his write-ups and he gave a very good presentation. He was eager to learn and to try and take some of the work off of the team's plate. MD - I had the pleasure of working with Neville for 2 weeks during his Internal Medicine clerkship rotation. He had a positive attitude and was very determined to excel; he was hardworking, a team player and was able to complete multiple tasks in a timely manner. He had excellent presentations during rounds that were very educational and which reflected his knowledge and hard work. Neville was an essential part of the team and I am sure he will continue to shine during all of his rotations.
MD - Neville has shown interest and enthusiasm in taking on patients and being part of the team. He's presented very well on topics assigned during rounds. He always asked good questions. I would recommend that he improve his medical knowledge and continue to read and know more details about his patients.

question: Comments from house staff and attendings
answer_text:
ALLEN HOUSESTAFF

Cedric has improved over the course of his medicine rotation, particularly with regard to oral presentations and organization of admission presentations. By the end of the rotation, he was able to obtain a very thorough history and organize it well into an HPI which was well-presented from memory. He was very open to feedback and responded well to feedback throughout the rotation. He was able to bring primary literature to rounds when asked to do so. He should continue to expand his fund of knowledge and, as he gets more comfortable on the medicine wards, work on being more proactive to help his patients and team.
